I split the spinach salad usually and my fave is their lamb Raghu. But also their Halibut in olives is amazing if you like tomato based dishes. The gnocchi is also melt in your mouth and their mushroom pasta is great for vegetarians. Yes I go a lot :) Great for date night or intimate BFF chats or celebrations.
author: Vicky S.

description: Happened here based on Yelp, looking for a nice Italian dinner for an Anniversary dinner while in SF.  Loved it!  It's small, and has a definite  'European' feel.  There the night before Thanksgiving, so obviously not tremendously busy, but seemed mostly locals and groups of friends.  Seems a real family-run spot. Food was delicious!!    Had the Caciucco di Viareggio (the origin of Cioppino). The broth was amazing!  Seriously I order cioppino whenever I can, and this was the best I've had.   We also had the Risotto alla Monferrina (sausage and saffron).  Really good,  but overshadowed by our other meal..   Prices were very reasonable, especially considering the quality of the food, and plenty to eat.  Great little place, just down the street from the Moscone Center in SoMa.
author: Toby M.

description:
Three reasons to go to this restaurant:
1- Olive/olive oil dip with bread from heaven
2- Excellent lasagna
3- Friendly service
author: Ari G.

description:
I've passed by this restaurant too many times to count on my commute to work and  en route to Giants games.  If there's anything that this restaurant needs is a bit more signage to attract attention from the street level.  That aside, the dinner that I had this past weekend after a Giants day game was very enjoyable and delicious to boot.

We got an order of grilled and fried calamari as well as the burrata.  The burrata was not rich but very satisfying on baguette bread.  They gave a pretty hefty amount of it too so one order really can be shared among four people.  The grilled calamari shined a bit more than the fried because I could actually taste the freshness of the squid.

In terms of main courses, we ordered the lasagna, porcini with black  truffle oil pasta, ravioli, linguine with clams, and the spinach salad.   Mostly everyone I talked to really enjoyed their food.  The servers were also very much on top of their game.  They came to do water refills frequently and brought out new silverware after our appetizer plates were taken away.

On average it was about $35 per person for a genuinely enjoyable meal within a spacious not too loud dining room environment.  This place certainly is more than qualifies as a date-worthy destination and for larger groups too and for anyone who likes to have choices of both Italian meat courses and seafood courses.
author: Ben H L.

description: The lasagna was 5* as was the service. Our Italian waiter + rest of the wait staff were exceptionally kind. Felt like I was transported to an authentic restaurant on the Italian countryside :-). Grazie!
author: Meg B.

description:
Horrible. Just horrible. We stumbled on this place just walking around. We shared the Straccietti al Ragu di Agnello and Tagliolini di Mare with my girlfriend and we both had food poisoning. Which dish it was from, only god knows. Our whole Saturday was spent in bed, vomiting and with fever.

On top of that, I thought food was very bland and tasteless. Service definitely matches the food; the server came and asked if we wanted more bread and we said yes. He nodded but the bread never came.
Even once was too many.
author: Mark C.

description: Great place, service and food!  Loved the ambience as well!
author: Kali L.

description: Owned and operated by Italians (Milanese). One of the owners waits tables, and his cohorts are Italians. They are very polite and family friendly while serving impressive Italian food with very generous portions.
author: Owen S.

description:
Came here on a Saturday evening around 8:30 we had reservations so we got seated right away.

Ordered the meat lasagna excellent
Lamb ragu was good
My friends liked the rabbit.

I would come back just for the meat lasagna and ask for extra cheese and sauce. 

The servers were on top of their game :)
author: DOM d.

description: First time here and it was amazing!! Get the gnocchi sorrentina for sure. It was definitely worth the money. We sat at the bar with lucca and he was charming and wonderful. We will be back for sure. They were out of one of the dishes we wanted so we will be back to try it. 5 stars!
author: Stacey H.

description: Disappointing.  Food was bland, texture was weird.  Seafood was overcooked.  Shrimp was mushy.  Maybe the executive chef was out sick that day???  Service was friendly though.
author: Francine K.

description:
AMAZING. Very cute and romantic restaurant, for those looking for a great Italian food place in the city for a date. I came in with my sisters after a 7 hours drive from LA area, and made it just in time for our reservation. We were seated right away and our waiter was very attentive, patient, and informative. 

I'm embarrass to say this, but be pretty much cleaned the plate within 10 mins. It was dead silence at our dinner table.
author: Annie B.

description:
I didn't know this place existed until last week! To think that it was walking distance to my work of 5+ years... geez I've been missing out.

The S.O. planned a romantic evening by surprising for a dinner + a concert and he chose this place b/c it had good reviews per Yelp... Thanks fellow Yelpers for guiding the man!

We arrived early and it was pretty dead. I was concerned but then later on during the evening... it started getting busier.

S.O. and I shared the following:

- Burrata (mozzarella-butter cheese~Parma prosciutto~cherry tomatoes~arugala) = DELICIOUS! The mozzarella was very creamy and fresh. They gave a generous portion of prosciutto which I loved and their cherry tomatoes and arugala salad on the side... yep I actually ate it! 

- Sfogliatine con gamberi e asparagi (puff pastry~asparagus~shrimp~crab reduction)  = S.O. mostly ate this but I did take a bite... it was good... light and very tasty! . 

- Pennette al granchio con la rucola (crab~arugula~cherry tomatoes) = I loved it! They gave plenty of crab meat and it wasn't frozen either! The pasta sauce was very light and the cherry tomatoes were icing on the dish! 

- Profitterolles alla vanilla (pastry puff~vanilla ice cream~chocolate) = I had some but the S.O. ended up finishing it. It was good but by this time, I was so full and I was buzzing!

S.O. also brought a bottle of wine ($20 corkage fee which is normal) and the pairing of the wine to our dish was just perfect. 

Service: friendly and prompt!

From the look of the S.O.'s face: the bill was probably way under what he estimated it would so he was happy!

Will probably be going back here if or when the S.O. and I have run out of places to eat around the work neighborhood.
author: Cath M.

description:
We came here for a deal on Savored. We shared the beef carpaccio, lamb ragu, salmon with saffron sauce and tiramisu. The place was almost empty when we arrived at 6:30 on a Friday night, suspicious...

The beef carpaccio was decent, although way overpriced for a few slivers of meat and a little lettuce and cheese. There was nothing distinguishing about it. The lamb ragu pasta has freshly made pasta. The sauce was OK, but the pasta was gummy and overcooked. We asked for our salmon to be less cooked but it still came out overcooked. The saffron sauce was good and I suppose it masks the dryness of the fish if you put enough sauce on it. 

Overall, the place was overpriced and the food unspectacular and underwhelming. If the service was better, especially with an empty restaurant, I would give it a 3, but everything about it was below average. I would not recommend it at all.
author: Alice W.

description: The sausage Risotto was delicious! Also enjoyed the bread and its dip that came with it and my Cesare salad. Great ambiance, cheerful staff, good stuff!
author: Brit L.

description:
So this was the 4th time we'd made a reservation here - first three had to be cancelled for various reasons- and I was so ready to finally taste the treats I'd only read about on the menu.  We expected traffic driving into the city for a 6:15 reservation, but the roadways were so clear.  Great, except we arrived about 40 minutes early.  We even found street parking about 1/2 block away.  What to do with all that time???  Strolled into Zeke's sports bar.  Eclectic and interesting group there enjoying very cheap, and kinda watery, drinks, but who's complaining when you get a well gin and tonic and a Tanquaray maritini for total $10.

Walked into La B right on time, and it was completely empty.  during the entire 90 minutes were there only two other tables were occupied.  Even on a Tuesday night, no place can survive with that small a turnout.  Wondering if that's why they cut back on some of the more expensive ingredients (details to follow).

I had a Caesar.  It was large with lots or fresh lettuce, but totally overdressed with a dressing lacking in garlic and, WHAT, no anchovies.  My husband had the spinach salad and enjoyed it, although said it was underdressed.  We shared Calamari grigliati-grilled squid~arugula~chickpea purée starter, and it was hands down the star of the night.  We got eight baby squid, bodies only, that were perfectly fresh, perfectly grilled, just olive oil, salt and pepper.  I could have eaten a plate full of them.  The chickpea puree, unfortunately had no flavor at all - not even chickpea flavor.

I'm not much of a pasta gal, but I'm TOTALLY a mushroom/fungi gal.  I decided to order against type and get the Tagliatelleai porcini e tartufo- wild porcini~black truffles~white truffle oil.  I was sooo disappointed.  There were no black truffles!  Should I have said something?  I also couldn't detect the truffle oil, and the porcini were not very assertive.  The sauce tasted of raw flour, which I think they used to thicken it instead of reducing it to intensify the flavors.  The pasta texture was perfect, just the right amount of chew, but the dish was woefully underseasoned.  I think if they'd reduced the sauce properly, there wouldn't have seemed such a lack of salt.  My husband got the Vitello alla valdostana- rolled veal~spek~fontina cheese~white wine.  He enjoyed it, although it was slightly oversalted.  The texture of the veal was perfect, maybe a touch too much of the cheese.

I don't usually get dessert, but felt cheated because my entrée was so insipid, so ordered the Panna cotta- vanilla cream pudding~cherry coulis.  The panna cotta was about average, but the cherries (I think they were the prized amarena) were exquisite.  Too bad there only three.

Our waiter was sweet and very cute in an androgynous way.  He was a little awkward, kind of there when we didn't need him and not when we did, but I could tell he was trying, and I give points for that.

On the way home, we decided if we'd combined the two entrees and then split them, we both would have enjoyed them more.  Once again I find myself thinking, if I'd had lower expectations, I would have had a higher rating.

Food:  19/40
service: 15/20
ambiance/intangibles:  17/20
value:  16/20
Overall:67/100
even though this would be 2 stars, my overall feeling was definitely in the 3 star range, so I'll overrule my formula and say 3 stars, although it would not be above the middle of my revisit list.
author: Diane B.

description: This is an excellent restaurant.  We have been here twice and had the halibut in tomato sauce, swordfish, soup and pasta.  The halibut in tomato sauce was outstanding.  So well done.  The vegetarian minestrone is amazing!  The bread and tapenade were excellent as well.  The service was very good.  Its a small place so I would make reservations at peak times.  We will be back!
author: Larry R.

description: I took my wife and another friend to La Briciola for dinner.  The food was good but the service was a little slower than I had hoped.  I think they may have been short-staffed.  The cost was about what you would expect from a trendy SF SOMA restaurant: Overpriced. Dinner for three with a bottle of wine and dessert was $179.00 before tip.   I enjoyed the food but I will probably not be going back.  Also, if you are spoiled by California wines, Italian wine is always a bitter disappointment.
author: Paul R.

description: Amazing bread and olive and olive oil. My friend and I had two full baskets. I got the vegetable bruschetta (vegan) and the linguine in eggplant and tomato sauce (vegan). I was really happy with my meal and the waiter was really helpful and knowledgable of the ingredients in the dishes, which always makes a vegan happy.
author: Lucas F.

description:
Had no expectations of my dinner on a Thursday night. Picked La Briciola due to its Soma location, not too far from Caltrain 4th and King. Took the express from Hillsdale to The City. Arrived at the restaurant at 6. Made the train home at 7:30.

First, there are the people. The service was very good, chatty, and casual. The menu is divided into a daily menu, and then a more general regular menu. All in all, there are enough choices to keep you reading for several minutes.

Second, there are my choices. Wine: 2010 Sangiovese La Carraia, Umbria, Italia: raspberry, cherry, and pepper, with balanced acidity, medium body, and moderate tannins...smooth, mild, and well-flavored.

1. Orecchiette con salsiccia e rapini ear-shaped pasta~sausage~
broccolirabe~olive oil. The pasta was al dente, the "hot" sausage was mild, the vegetables semi-crisp (2/3 cooked), and the sauce left plenty of room to taste all of the ingredients. Needless to say, I finished the plate.

2. Rockfish (special), nicely sauced, semi-crisp veges, and very nice creamy mashed potatoes. Very well flavored and tender.

Double Espresso.

I recommend this place. For itself, for the people, and you don't have to trek over to North Beach for good Tuscan wine or Italian cuisine! The restaurant space is nicely designed for conversations, and there is enough space so you aren't bothered by other diners. 

Great place to take a date or a spouse.

Enjoy!
author: Reyn J.

description:
Needed to find a nearby place for a lunch catch up sesh with a couple former coworkers.  La Briciola had reservations available and Italian cuisine always seems like a good choice.  

Service was very attentive, and you gotta love the Italian accent!  I like how they have some lunch specials in addition to their regular menu.  It was a tough choice but I went with the truffle paperdelle.  My dining companions went with the seafood risotto and the spinach salad with penne bolognese.  Loved the bread and olive oil.  The spinach salad was pretty basic with some simple dressing, some nuts and cheese but was fine.  My truffle pappardelle smelled great and had tons of porcini mushrooms.  The pappardelle was freshly made and delicious carby goodness and listed black truffles and white truffle oil.  However, I didn't see any black truffle shavings, perhaps it was a mix of black and white truffle oil.  Though it smelled truffley, I didn't really taste much.  So that was a bummer.  I had a taste of the penne bolognese and I must say that was delicious.  I heard the risotto was pleasing as well.  

La Briciola is a cute place with great service and hearty portions.  I would come back, but not order the truffle pappardelle. Prices are a comparable to similar places around the area.
author: Cat C.

description:
I have walked by here hundreds of times and it's been on my list for a couple of years.  I finally popped in and am not sure how I feel about it.

To say it as best I can, the staff was genuine and friendly, charming and attentive.  The food was not bad, but it wasn't great.  I may have had high hopes though.  I appreciate the pastas being fresh and most everything was scratch made, but the flavors were lacking and unmemorable.

+Sea Bass Ravioli was cooked perfectly, but flavors were mild - could be a good dish for someone with cholesterol issues or watching their sodium intake
+Squid Ink Risotto had good flavor but it could have used a little more time to cook as the "bite" was harder than al dente

I feel these two items can be improved as the errors were forgivable.  I would come here again because I had a nice social experience, but I can't say I'm craving it.
author: Alex T.

description: Pretty good stuff. Had a Cesar salad some bread and some pasta that was nicely done. Good stuff. I'd go back. If I had more time I'd have tried the lasagna but the menu said they needed 20 minutes.
author: Chris X.

description:
Bread at the table = delicious.  Dipping sauce = addicting.  (Olive oil and minced olives.)  

Bruschette assortite: zucchini, eggplant, fresh tomatoes on toasted bread.  It was good, but the tomatoes were not flavorful at all.  :-\  

Ravioli con pomodoro: spinach and ricotta filled ravioli, fresh tomato sauce, and basil.  Delicious pasta sauce, and it tasted so fresh!   He cleaned off the place, and practically licked the plate.  (Used bread instead, haha!)

Orecchiatte con Salsiccia e Rapini (Orecchiette with Sausage and Broccoli Rabe) = olive oil, pan tossed, savory heaven.  I almost ate all of it...alas, I took home leftovers.  

Prices = moderate.  

Service = nice and friendly.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Great solid italian place best for last-minute gatherings without all of the fanfare since the location is a bit out of normal pedestrian traffic.

Super reasonably priced. We ordered quite a few things. I would avoid the grilled fish (mooshy shrimp, probably didn't have high enough temperature grill) and warm octopus (bland), Steak was average, but the pastas and carpaccio are great. large portion best for sharing. the squid ink risotto was phenomenal.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Had lunch Friday 4/17. From the moment i entered the dinning room Luca, a partner, demonstrated old-school hospitality. I really appreciated his professionalism. Once seated the great service continued. I for one am glad this place exists: a classic Italian restaurant. Veg Crepes with wild porcini sauce and white truffle oil was great. As was the hand made wide noodle with lamb sugo. If u need a break from "modern" ideas as to what constitutes service and food, run to La Briciola.
author: Mr. L.

description:
Accommodated a group of 7 for dinner. Intimate restaurant. Quiet to hold a good conversation. Food was good. Service was good.
Had the ear-shaped pasta with sausage and brocolli. Others had tagliatelle with lamb ragu and they enjoyed it. Had 2 bottles of wine and great catch up. Love the location since it's close to SoMa and Downtown.
author: Linda K.

description:
Came here for dinner with a friend after having a few drinks nearby. We decided to share the lamb ragu and the sea bass stuffed ravioli with lobster. Both were very delicious (but unfortunately came out at the same time and the second plate I tried was cold by the time I got to it).

Nonetheless, great pastas and would come again!
author: Siv L.

description: This place is real, authentic and quality. Good people who know Italian food. Unique menu. The rolled swordfish was wonderful.
author: Todd B.

description:
We came here to celebrate my birthday a day early with my parents and sister. At 5:30pm, right when they opened, we walked in and were promptly seated. The guy was clearly Italian from his accent and he was so sweet and welcoming. Here's the rundown:

Food:
To start, they brought out some fresh bread (room temp) and olive oil mixed in with crushed olives. Normally, I'm skeptical of these types of oil mixtures, but this one was really tasty. The olives were so good, I piled them on my piece of bread before devouring it.
My mom and sister started with the Minestrone dell'ortolano soup and seemed pleased with it. My dad got the Zuppa Contadina soup and let me try some; it was pretty good.
For entrees, my mom got the Ravioli di cernia (seabass ravioli), which I tried a bit of and it was GOOD. Definitely better than the Straccietti al ragú di agnello (lamb ragu) I ordered. My sister got the Pennette al granchio con la rucola, which was also pretty good. My dad got the Linguine alle vongole, and was quite happy with it start to finish.
For dessert, my mom ordered the Panna cotta and my sister ordered the Soufflé al cioccolato. I tried some of each. The Panna cotta was creamy, without being overly sweet, and was covered with a cherry sauce that was delightful. The soufflé was quite chocolatey and could even give the chocolate lover a chocolate food coma.

Service: The host, servers, and busboys were impeccable. They were all very personable, friendly, and well-timed. We enjoyed our meal for a little under 2 leisurely hours and were quite pleased.

Ambiance: This is a cute restaurant along the same block as Garaje and HRD. I've passed by it so many times, but finally got to try it out. It could be cute for special evenings out with friends or nice date nights (they light tea lights at every table and there's cozy corners everywhere).

Will I be back? While I thoroughly enjoyed the experience, there's many other places to try in the city and nothing WOWed me enough to make me want to return immediately.
author: Leana L.

description:
Great neighborhood Italian bistro with excellent food, cozy ambiance and attentive service - will definitely return.

Burrata with prosciutto and arugula - 5 stars: creamy, fresh, simply outstanding
Spinach salad - 3 stars: pretty standard
Seabass ravioli with lobster reduction - 5 stars: innovative pairing and cooked perfectly al dente with little chunks of lobster in a light and flavorful sauce
Seafood mixed grill - 4 stars: generous portions of grilled swordfish, salmon, prawns, veggies; very good
author: Jia H.

description: Great service but terrible good. I love truffle oil and the truffle pasta was so al dente that it just tasted like a big pile of goo - inedible.
author: Elana R.

description:
An intimate welcoming Italian restaurant ...... understated and comfortable.

This is good Italian food...has a Tuscan style....all our dishes were good however a couple of notables to share were the squid ink pasta with seafood in a white wine sauce....and plenty of crustaceans including mussels, clams, shrimp and calamari all a wash in this bowl of foodie joy!

Our other recommendation is the sea bass ravioli.....terrific.

There is an extensive wine list and while it is not wine I readily recognised, what we had on the good recommendation of our server was excellent....nothing better when good wine knowledge is shared like this!

Quality service that is delivered with sincerity....
author: Mick A.

description:
On the night of the Giants' World Series victory, there was sure a lot of screaming and high-fives all over SoMa. Jamie W. and I were caught in the midst of the hoopla and found ourselves in the relative quietude of La Briciola. Fans were relentless in their enthusiasm and kept banging on the front window behind me as we were eating. I felt like Tippi Hedren when she was cowering on the sofa in that Bodega Bay house in "The Birds" as the seagulls were pecking their way through the front door. But I'm no bottle blonde, and that kind of frenzy only happens once every 56 years. 

Ah, I remember the big plastic tomato in front of its former identity, Vino e Cucina. It was hard to miss when you were driving by. Back then, it was just a casual Italian eatery that somehow slipped my mind. In fact, I wasn't aware that it turned into an upscale northern Italian ristorante until quite recently. It's nicer inside, rather modest in culinary execution but nice just the same. We first shared the $14 Fagottino Ripieni, which were two crepes turned into little pouches holding some mixed vegetables in a creamy pool of wild porcini sauce and drizzled with a white truffle oil (see photo). The dish was charming and delicious. 

Entrees were solid as well. Jamie ordered the healthy-looking $17 Orecchiatte con Salsiccia e Rapini, which was a plate of ear-shaped pasta mixed with a mild sausage and broccoli rabe (see photo). Fresh-tasting but lacking a certain oomph to make it truly memorable. I had better luck with the $17 Straccietti al Ragú di Agnello, a hearty, rustic dish made up of hand-cut pasta mixed in a homemade lamb ragu sauce (see photo). This was really classic Italian fare, and the pasta was prepared with an ideal al dente texture. Service was attentive and not at all wearing on our frazzled nerves. The waiter even boarded the window to prevent the rabid Giants fan from interrupting our meal. 

FOOD - 4 stars...classic northern Italian well turned 
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...a calm enclave away from World Series madness 
SERVICE - 4 stars...attentive but not intrusive 
TOTAL - 4 stars...definitely worth a return on a quieter evening
author: Ed U.

description: Took our niece, who just moved to the City.  Great as always.  The seafood mixed grill and porcini pasta were perfect, great wines by the glass as well as bottles.
author: M W.

description:
As if I'm visiting a great Italian friend... this is the place!
Intimate setting, fantastic, fresh and quality dishes with a beautiful presentation.
I especially like the soft lighting.
Let the pros pair the wine :)
author: Teresa S.

description:
Great little restaurant.  Came on a weeknight and the service was good.  Food was what we expected from an Italian restaurant.

Atmosphere was relaxed and slightly romantic.
author: John P.

description:
I would have rated La Briciola a little higher had it not been for the fact that they neglected to post some important ingredients on their menu. Warning: For those who DO have crustacean allergies, do not order the risotto-- it comes with a lobster reduction sauce that was not otherwise specified on the menu. (I wouldn't have an issue with this normally, and I generally ask ahead of time anyway-- but it was listed on another item on the menu, so i'm curious as to why they didn't list LOBSTER REDUCTION under their risotto? Some people who are allergic to crusteans generally like eating seafood and would probably want to eat the risotto anyway?) I wish they would have listed it, as they did on other menu items-- but I wanted to write this up so that they know that they could be liable for a lawsuit (so post it on the menu or tell your guests ahead of time!!!!) The only reason I found out about the lobster in the risotto was that I tasted a bit and then asked the wait staff to please inform me, and when it was confirmed-- prompty exchanged dishes with my boyfriend. 

Other than that, La Briciola was average. The wait staff took forever and got my order wrong (I ordered the seafood risotto and got the sausage risotto-- but  knowing what I knew about the risotto, I would have preferred the sausage.) While they were prompt and apologetic about it, it left a bad taste in my mouth.The bread was fantastic, as well as the olive oil and olive spread that comes with it, but not enough to forget about the allergy fiasco and the long LONG wait time to order (it took around 30 minutes for the wait staff to come back around after we weren't ready the first time.) My boyfriend thought his pasta (the tagliatelleai porcini e tartufo) was not flavoured well enough-- and also that the mushrooms used in the dish were either way overcooked or just canned (they were mushy.) And the risotto was too salty and did not come with enough chunks of seafood with it. 

Idk. I'm sort of disappointed in La Briciola-- the menu looked so delicious and inviting! Ingredients sounded fresh and amazing. What should have been a foodie's delight (especially with all the amazing ingredients listed) ended up being a disappointment and almost-disaster (imagine if I ate the entire risotto WITH the sauce? Yikes.) The best thing about dinner was the appetizer and the bread. (The proscuitto di parma was delicious) But that wasn't enough to save the almost-disaster that took place.
author: Christa Lei S.

description:
This is a charming and friendly restaurant in a terrible location.  It makes up for the latter with very professional service and excellent food.  We had the lasagna with meat sauce and the grilled rabbit and both were solid.  

La Briciola deserves a solid 4 stars, we would definitely return here to try more things off the menu.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Disenchanted, dissatisfied, displeased.... dismiss this place! 

Attended a birthday dinner with a group of 17 people. Yes, I know that's a lot of heads to serve all at once. But I believe they had enough staff to support the restaurant (4 waiters, 2 busers). The service was extremely slow and somewhat rude. We had to ask multiple times for water, bread, and an extra chair. The food came out about 75 minutes after we ordered. The quality was lacking, reminiscent of lean cuisine. 

But here's my biggest gripe... (passive-aggressive nature coming out). I had brought a bottle of bourbon to enjoy with my friends. The waiter saw it and asked if it was liquor, I said yes. He snapped back with "you can't serve that here". I acknowledged his statement. Then 15 minutes later, as he's taking our orders. He sees that the bottle is still in its original place on the table. He very rudely demands that I put the bottle away. No "please" or "do you mind"... just "that bottle needs to be off the table". My blood was BOILING!!!! I had to gather every ounce of restraint not to slap the guy and choke him out. I haven't had such a rude and horrible experience at a restaurant in quite some time. 

I encourage the general public to eat elsewhere. The food quality (if any) doesn't warrant this kind of service.
author: Stephen Y.

description: This place is fantastic. Start with a bottle of Barbaresco and some bread with olive oil. The carpaccio was wonderful with the bread. I had the t-bone - done to perfection. The wife's gnocchi was also great - not pastey. Just right. The owner was warm and gracious. Mille grazie.
author: Tom G.

description:
The food is pretty bad...bland, poorly cooked.  Then...WE FOUND A HAIR IN THE PASTA.  Didnt look particulalry like hair from the head either....

Despite this they charged us for the one food item in which we didnt find a hair...guess we shouldve looked harder cause im sure it was probably full of them!
author: Max S.

description:
Made an OpenTable for 4, which was honored, but the food was not good for most in my party. Squid ink spaghetti was plain tasting, per the two that ordered it, so they would not ordered it again.  My T-Bone steak was not medium rare and so over-charred that is all I tasted during my meal.  The grilled calamari was good, although it too was heavily charred, which made the steak worse.  The only food my party said they truly enjoyed was the fresh warm bread, but that is because of the olive tapenade that accompanied it.

Decorum was nice but service took too long and I had to ask multiple times for the same thing like the wine menu then the dessert menu.  Once they took away the menus, they didn't seem interested in offering another bottle of wine to our table.

I do not have a desire to return here due to paying $60 for a unsatisfying meal.
author: Kirstin K.

description:
3.75 stars.  This place turned a perfectly horrid date night into another wonderful SF memory. 

The dimly lit dining area is cozy and immediately sets an intimate stage with even a bit of storybook charm.  We showed up early evening and it was quiet enough to carry on easy conversation.  

Our servers were unobtrusive but generally helpful although not what I'd call warm.  But don't get me wrong, service was good... but he wasn't going to break out the kiddie pics from the wallet, either. 

As for the food... The gnocchi was pretty solid, but the tagliolini di mare was the star of the show.   Perfect for the light rain outside.  I wasn't so impressed with the grilled squid and chickpea pureé; I'm pretty sure I've done better squid in the backyard with alder, a little garlic and an herb bouquet. 

They had an Italian red by the glass from Abruzzo that was solid accompaniment with dinner and seemed like a good value.  I'm only a dessert guy when the moon is properly aligned, but my date appreciated the classic tiramisu just the same. 

All in all, an out of the way, last minute reservation ended up being the second best idea of the night... but I wouldn't find that out until later. 

If I have time and intent the next time I'm in SF (and in SoMa) , I just might make the hike for lunch.
author: Mike S.

description:
Came here for my boss' birthday lunch, made a reservation for party of 5 at 11:30am on a Wednesday.
We were the first guests to arrive, so I figured great we'll be in and out of the restaurant in roughly an hour or so, with time to share a dessert. This was not the case. The waiter's demeanor was a bit sour and though he wasn't rude, he also wasn't friendly. It took about 15 minutes for the waiter to take our order, when there was no one else in the restaurant. The bus boy did bring us fresh hot bread with oil and kalmata olives in the meantime, which helped with the waiting. The food came quickly once we ordered but it wasn't worth the prices. I'm glad we stuck with the Lunch Menu instead of the higher priced Main Menu. The Bruschette Assortite Zucchini and the bread were the highlights of the meal. I ordered the Scaloppina Di Limone, the veal was over cooked but the lemon caper sauce was tasty. The veggies, broccoli & spinach were overly steamed and bland. The bus boy and another gentleman served us our food and the waiter never came to check on us until after we finished eating, about 15 minutes after we were done. He never asked us if we wanted to see the dessert menu but simply brought  us the check. I didn't make a fuss since we had to get back to the office and we passed up the hour mark from when we sat down in the restaurant. The slow un-attentive service really brought this place down for me. When we left there were only 2 other small tables in the restaurant.
author: Anica S.

description: Came here with my family while in San Francisco for the marathon! Very friendly and very authentic. Nice ambiance. Great service! I'd come back if I lived closer.
author: Lauren M.

description:
I was invited to La Briciola for a birthday dinner party. The restaurant is small, intimate and romantically lit. Our large party took up half of the main room. We had a reservation and our table was all set and ready to go once we got there. The staff was very accommodating and the waiter we had was super sweet. 

They gave us complimentary antipasti platters of different types of bruschetta, enough for 20 people. I ordered the truffle, porcini pasta as my primi. I didn't really get too much truffle oil flavor, so I was a little let down. I always tend to order rabbit when I'm at an Italian restaurant. This night was no different. I got the rabbit confit. It was cooked perfectly and had a lot of flavor. The portion was pretty large for a secondi. The confit was served on a bed of cooked root veggies which were also very delicious. 

My friend brought her own customized birthday cake and the whole staff came out to sing happy birthday to my her. They also helped us cut the cake and didn't even charge extra for that. We had a lot of cake left over and gave some to the staff. They were super excited and thanked us profusely. Great place for a group dinner, but I'd like to return for a date night in the future.
author: Liv A.

description: My husband and I went for the first time for his birthday this week. We were looking forward to trying a new neighborhood restaurant - particularly because we love Italy and Italian food. The bread / tapenade, service and portions were all as advertised (by other reviewers). However, the quality of the food was sadly lacking. The spinach salad had large, hard chunks of candied nuts that were almost impossible to cut through, and too little goat cheese for that mound of spinach leaves, but that was the best thing we had. The vegetable crepes were smothered in a very rich sauce, and were filled with what seemed like, more of the same - nothing that could be identified clearly as a vegetable.  I think most of the seafood in the caciucco had seen better days ...I actually spit out a bite of fish that was very clearly bad. The broth though, was tasty. The lasagna noodles were over cooked and overall, it was very greasy. For the price ( $160 including wine), we expected more ...quality, not quantity.
author: Sharon K.

description: I would give it another try, had them put together a fresh pasta and salmon dish (not much salmon), it was decent. I didn't like my salad very much.
author: Tiff W.

description: The staff were extremely attentive, pleasant, and fun.  The food was wonderful and the desserts were amazing.  Overall a great experience.  Would definitely go back.
author: James S.

description: The service was good. Bad the food quality was very bad, we couldn't eat even a bit a lamb shank, which was on the specials. The calamari and anti pasta was bad too.
author: Adithya R.

description:
We wanted to have some Italian food, so came to this place b/c of the great yelp reviews.   We ordered the following dishes:

1. appetizer: Calamari grigliati (grilled squid) --best dish of the night

2. Tagliolini di mare: the picture looked a lot better than its taste.  The pasta was not cooked right.  some of the pasta were still uncooked!!!!  flavor was very subtle.

3. Risotto al nero di seppia (calamari~ink sauce~scallop): on the menu, it said calamari with scallop!  guess what? my dish came and there was no scallop! instead they put two pieces of shrimp. i asked the waiter what happened to the scallop, and he said they ran out!!!  that is pretty bad!  they should've told me before i ordered the dish.  the flavor of the dish was okay, nothing too special.

4. tiramisu: not bad.  but by this time, i was already disappointed by the main entree...  :(

would i come back again? probably not.  I am sure there are better italian restaurants in SF!
author: Tiffany H.

description: I really love the swordfish special. I can only order that because it is so good.   The staff is very friendly.  Nice quiet place to bring your parents or a date.
author: Michele A.

description: Had a great meal with a party of 13. Service was superb. Swordfish special was excellent, as was the hot bread and olive oil/olive dip that kept coming. Grilled calamari appetizer was amazing! No canoli tonight, but loved the tiramisu. Other entrees were thoroughly enjoyed by the rest of our party as well. Recommend this place without hesitation!
author: L F.

description: Stopped by here randomly one evening with a friend. Blown away by the authentic, handmade pastas and flavors. Great (delicious, limited, affordable) wine selection. Will be back!!
author: Jonathan R.

description: If you're looking for the classic San Francisco bistro that the tourists have yet to discover, this is the place. Small, quiet, great food (the seafood lasagna, though a pairing I had never had before, was outstanding), attentive service. Conveniently located, a 20-minute walk along 3rd Street from either the Montgomery Street BART station or from AT&T Park. This was my wife's and my first visit, but we'll be back. Reservations recommended.
author: Garry H.

description:
Made reservations through Open Table for an early dinner before a Giant's game. Had a fantastic experience. When it comes to Italian, I like the simplistic dishes with minimal sauce. I almost always get the Vongole (clams in white wine) at every establishment. I would have to say it was some of the best I've ever had at Briciola. When there is so little sauce, you have to cook the pasta just right, and they did just that!

Loved the olive and olive oil dip for the bread. Portions were great, not to big, not to small. My boyfriend got the truffle mushroom dish which was superb! Very rarely does someone order something I'd rather have.

Skipped on the dessert, because we were headed to the Giants game. In and out in 40 minutes! I hear that service can be slow during lunch, but it was fantastic during dinner. Service was authentic, overall had a great dining experience.
author: Diane P.

description:
We love this place.  Great service, excellent dishes, and a very good wine list.  I take friends here, have business dinners here, and everyone becomes a fan. 

Try the sea bass ravioli -- excellent.
author: Jason R.

description: This place sucked like a Black & Decker on steroids. The service was awful and the food was bland. We came here for a friend's birthday party and, aside from me, everyone was the satsfied-with-McDonald's type--you know, easy to please when it comes to food. So it says something when even the birthday boy didn't like his steak and told me he'd had better. I was inclined to agree, as my orechiette with broccoli rabe was basically starch cooked in water with some green leaves in it. As mentioned, the service was pretty bad too--rude and inattentive. Skip.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Nice Ambiance, sweet staff, definitely Italian! We had an 8pm reservation, and we were running late. Luckily, they were too. We were seated at 8:45, eek, a little later than we hoped. They were very sweet and gave us complimentary prosecco while we waited which was nice. 

Everyone in my party ordered a delicious meal, except me. And the meal was in my honor! I ordered halibut and it was swimming in a boiling broth. The halibut was overcooked, waaaaaay too hot to eat, and mushy. Also kind of flavorless. The 5 other meals that were ordered, filet, lamb, a sampler, were all delicious.
author: Lisa R.

description: We decided on this place after checking reviews on Yelp! and some of the "other guys".  Pretty disappointed.  Charcuterie was so-so, puff pastry app had cold sauce and pastas with no flavor.  Rolled veal was decent as was the creme caramel.  A saving grace was that they serve Duchess de Bourgogne.  I hear there are way better options in the area for Italian.
author: B J M.

description:
We came here for lunch for a party of 8 on a Wednesday.

It took about 30 minutes before anyone came by to give us water or take our orders, then another 30 minutes for our food to come out.

People came in after us and left before us, all the while, we have not had any food yet. We have now been sitting at the table for an hour with no food.

When the food did finally come, everything was on the salty side. The vegetables were not fresh (frozen vegetable medley is not the same thing as broccoli raub). The lasagna came out looking like a goopy puddle of mess.

I understand that serving a large party is difficult, and maybe this was just an off day, but everything seemed to be particularly bad. At the end of the meal, when it was brought up to our servers attention that everything seemed to be running very slowly, we were given the excuse, "Well, you ordered the lasagna, that takes a while." There were also apologies for the wait, but it seemed more like a brush off.

I came in with very high expectations and walked away hungry and displeased.
author: Eric C.

description:
Meh... I came here for dinner with a friend.

+ ambiance (quiet, small, intimate)
+ good service
+ good bread

-/+ crostini misti di polenta: the dish was okay. I only liked one (chicken) of the 3 toppings (chicken pate, porcini mushrooms, sausage)  
-/+ straccietti al ragú di agnello (hand cut pasta with lamb ragú): the hand cut pasta was really delicious, but I didn't like the ragu
author: Margaret R.

description: Delicious! Authentic Italian food was so good that we forgot how much the bill was! From appetizers to desserts all was excellent in taste and service.  Great dinner to celebrate collage graduation
author: Gila s.

description: I thought I would update to 2018, We still love our neighborhood  Italian restaurant that  we can walk to.  Now we no longer have to drive to North Beach. Food is delicious, great customer service. The staff is warm,welcoming and Italian. I have noticed people have said service can be slow, but in Europe they don't hound you at your table which I like I'm not sure what all the complaints are about, One  can always ask the waiter to bring you a check and I'm sure they would if you let them know it is important to you. This is the kind of place I question writing a yelp review about because I don't want everyone to discover it and then have lines to get in
author: Susan S.

description:
Recently had lunch here with a friend and it was great! We split the Spinacina spinach~honey caramelized walnuts~goat cheese - light and delicious!

I had Straccietti al ragú di agnello hand cut pasta~lamb ragú  - the hand cut pasta was so tender and soft and the lamb ragú was excellent - I would have it again!

My friend had the Lasagna di mare bechamel~shrimp~salmon~swordfish. WOW! It was amazing...I had a bite and I can smell the delicious aromas of the fresh ingredients! 

I know some people may not be use to seeing this style of lasagna (it was covered in sauce rather than on the drier side), but the taste was lovely!

It seemed like a normal amount of time when they brought out our main dish, so if you have time constraints, please be aware or just let your server know!

I would totally go back!
author: Juliet W.

description: I got the Lasagna di Carne  Besciamella which great but my friend got violently ill from the filet mignon. I don't know what happened but its a shame. I probably won't come back.
author: Carl N.

description: Hands down the Best Lasagna I have ever had in my life!!  The fresh Bread with the olive oil that has spices and minced olives is also phenomenal!!! Also recommend the Spinach salad with Goat cheese and walnuts!  So so Good!!!
author: Roby A.

description:
In the car, on the way home, and the whole group is telling me to write a review. So here we go...  Fantastic, personal service, and amazing food. That, in a nutshell, makes for a great dining experience.  Our waiter was incredibly nice - shared his opinion about the best items - and helped us have a great time, including the kids. That was a surprise, since this place is regarded as "not good for kids". Note: they made plain pasta with butter sauce for our 4 year old.

Anyway, our group of 3rd generation Italians were very impressed - with both the service and the food.  The sea bass and lobster sauce pasta, as well as Lamb ragu, and grilled squid were just fantastic!  

We can't wait to return, and "will" bring the kids!  A truly wonderful family dining experience.  Bravisimo!!
author: Christian P.

description: We came here based on the yelp reviews, since we were visiting from out of town.  It's a great little Italian place.  My husband had the squid ink risotto.  I had the seafood lasagna.  Mine was better, but they were both delicious.
author: Cara W.

description:
I'd definitely come back to La Briciola. I dropped in on a weekday night with two friends.  It was definitely a casual dinner, so I was a little wary of the higher prices at La Briciola. The dishes, however, were delicious.

My friend and I split two seafood pasta dishes (one ravioli, one lasagna). I'm hazy on the exact fish that were used (want to say lobster in the ravioli and sea bass in the lasagna), but both were great.

Service was attentive, restrooms were nice. You'd definitely score points here on a date.

Four stars overall, I'd give a fifth if I felt like I was getting more value for my money. (most dishes were north of $20).
author: Bill H.

description:
Very nice Italian option in the city.
Great choice of meats and pastas, as well as wine.
The lamb pasta and the mushroom pasta are delicious!
author: I B.

description:
The appetizer and entree were 3 stars. Salad and Lamb Ragu.
Dessert was 5 stars. Tiramisu
Service was -7 bringing the grand total to 1.

I was there in a large group and service was just terrible. Maybe it was because we were a large party and gratuity was already included or service is just bad in general. Everything was super slow and we never got water or additional drinks though we asked around 3 times and finally just gave up. It's a shame, with better service, this place could be great.
author: Sunil R.

description: The waiter didn't know a thing about the wine (luckily my friend did), but the food tasted good and the bread wasn't bad.
author: Chia-Fen Y.

description:
I've never had Italian food be so fast before. It's entirely possible they just wanted to get us out of there--we went on a busy Wednesday night (what, does all of SF want Italian food on Wednesdays?) and were seated immediately. We only ordered entrees, no antipasti or primi or wine, and we were in and out within 40 minutes...there were _4_ of us. Nice, guys.

The bread was awesome, and served in an oil+olive tapenade. Yes, please.

We ordered the tagliolini di mare, the bucatino, and the gnocchi. All good, but the gnocchi was a bit squishy. Ye be warned. 

The good: zippy, zippy service.
The bad: little fanfare, but whatevs. We make our choices.
author: Amanda B.

description:
I actually rarely eat at Italian restaurants, but had a very special occasion the other weekend -- I had to carb up for a half marathon for the next morning! Woo.

Anywho, the place was just okay, in my opinion. Maybe I'm not too enthusiastic about eating pasta at a restaurant since I feel like I could have cooked something somewhat similar for way cheaper. Afterall, Italian restaurants make the most profit since they're ingredients are rather inexpensive... or, so I've been told.

I ordered the smoked salmon pasta and it was pretty good... The salmon was too salty to eat on it's own, so sadly the ratio of pasta:fish was not enough... which, resulted to a lot of salty morsels at the end and a lot of leftover fish to waste :( A few pieces of pasta were a bit undercooked, too. But, in the end, I loved the sauce and the flavor.

My friend ordered the pasta with crab. Haha, sucks for him, he had to actually open the crab pieces himself and I stole a few pieces. But eh, I wasn't a huge fan of the flavor. It was definitely mild compared to the salmon pasta.

Service was mediocre... it was pretty crowded that night and we were pretty much neglected the whole time. 

Overall, just an okay restaurant...
author: Janet H.

description: A great family reunion, special event dining location located conspicuously under the high way, tucked away. Inside, it is a Italian pasta restaurant, homey, dimly lighted (some folks might have trouble reading the menu, use your iPhone light torch... With class), a long selection of Italian wines, a very fatty tiramisu, an excellent cured meat board, ... And folks who sound really authentic... Whatever that means. If you are looking for great Italian pasta with a great price and significant portion? This is your place! Bring the uncles and aunties
author: Dilys S.

description:
I've been here twice and on both occasion received excellent tasting food.  Even the bread, served as appetizer was extremely delicious.  Apparently, they just warm it up in the oven, but it tastes delicious: somehow it has the right texture and consistency without being dry at all.  Exactly the way i like it.

My Meaty lasagna was savory and creamy at the same time, nicely complementing the sheets of lasagna dough.  You could really taste the meat and the salty delicious flavor.
author: Pascal A.

description:
My office just moved into the neighborhood so I've been exploring all the good eats in the area. This is definitely one of my favorites!

I met this lovely woman while waiting for my friend at the bar. She's been friends with the owner and waitstaff for 10 years following them from restaurant to restaurant. I believe La Briciola is the 2nd. Every visit, she orders the lamb ragu without fail. So, I had to follow suit and um..............it was amazingly tasty. SO glad I ordered it esp since lamb is typically not my favorite meat.

Since then I've ordered the seafood risotto and the seabass ravioli. Both are very good but my absolute favorite is the lamb ragu. It's a must order! 

On one of my visits, it took our food awhile to come out so our waiter comped our appetizer. I really appreciate when restaurants acknowledge their faults and try to make up for it.

Also have to give a thumbs up to the waitstaff. I've had the pleasure of meeting 2 of their long-timers, both with a very european charm....and funny too!
author: Emily Y.

description: La Briciola is gem of an Italian restaurant in the heart of SoMA.  This place is great for lunch and dinner.  The food and atmosphere are exceptional.  The staff was overly friendly as well.  I definitely would recommend lunch or dinner here.
author: Ryan I.

description:
Another one of several restaurants that participate with Savored (http://svrd.co/oCOhwV), a $10 reservation through their site will knock 30% off your dinner bill. With La Briciola being on the less expensive end of their restaurants though, you're not saving all that much until you hit a party of three or more people.

Coming with a high school friend though, we ended up ordering the sfogliatine, a tasty puff pastry that was filled with a shrimp, crab, and asparagus reduction; a lamb ragu pasta and a porcini and truffle tagliatelle that were both okay; and profiteroles and tiramisu for dessert, that were also just okay.

So, puff pastry aside, nothing here really stood out, but nothing was too terrible either. With reasonable prices, and good serving sizes, expect to get a pretty good deal here. Unfortunately, I know there's much better in the area (even if it's at a higher price point), so I'm not sure how likely I am to come back, but I'll give them the benefit of a doubt and thrown down three stars for them.
author: Johnny W.

description: It was a good romantic place. The food was pretty tasty and beautiful. The service was also good. I would recommend this place if you like Italian food
author: Sara K.

description:
One week before birthday dinner: Researched restaurants. Studied menus. Okay, La Briciola it is! And to my surprise, they easily agreed to accommodate my party of 20. 

Night of dinner: Walked in. Intimate atmosphere. Place is definitely smaller than what I had imagined. More suitable for dates and smaller parties. My table was set up in an awkward L-shape. Sat in the inner corner seat to interact with both sides of the table.

Service was pretty good considering our large party and the packed restaurant. Our food came out pretty fast. 

Sea Bass Ravioli with Lobster Reduction (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iH0f1TMuwLOb5hXz4Y4UOA?select=eMxfssp5HuTpo8LMqXPgEA): The seabass stuffed in the ravioli was flaky in texture. Overall it was a tasty dish. The sauce was light and complemented well with the ravioli. There were only 6 raviolis though and I did find a piece of scale in my dish.

Smoked Salmon Farfalle (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iH0f1TMuwLOb5hXz4Y4UOA?select=hjzAWu6uLjMDj99OYfWNiQ): Sauce tasted similar to the ravioli. Very simple dish.

Chicken Breast with Mushrooms (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iH0f1TMuwLOb5hXz4Y4UOA?select=HWH5nzsHzfwGPqwzUvozvw): The chicken was very tender, and the mushroom sauce was thick and flavorful. Reminded me of the HK style teriyaki chicken dish.

Tiramisu (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iH0f1TMuwLOb5hXz4Y4UOA?select=2stPtCekaR6cBWRkXE5UmQ): Delicious! Light and fluffy! A memorable tiramisu.

Prices were reasonable; entrees range from $15-$30. But I thought the portions were small and the dishes were simple. Too simple. I left the restaurant feeling unsatisfied.
author: Marti L.

description:
For these prices, the food was really disappointing.

Barata- bland and the texture was off. It was a little too runny even when it cooled off which makes me think they did something weird to the mozzarella. Accompanying salad of arugula and tomatoes was good though. 

Seafood salad- so so disappointing. I basically only ate the calamari pieces. The clams in there were so fishy tasting it was hard to bear. 

Lamb ragu over hand cut pasta- the pasta was good, al dente was done very well. Lamb ragu sauce was something I could have done at home on my own. It was odd because the pasta was more like lasagna noodles so it was fork and knife necessary.

tl;tr- would not go back
author: Katie C.

description: This place is awesome. The food is so delicious! The crew also is really nice and helpful whenever you have doubts on what to order. As an italian i can proudly say that this is authentic Italian food. Highly recommend.
author: Francesco F.

description:
My husband and I had a great time at Briciola.
The food was really good!
author: Mayra N.

description:
Came here with my girlfriend - it's a great date spot.  I am not an Italian food connoisseur, but I did thoroughly enjoy their dishes.  We made sure to order a lot of bread and dipped it in all of the sauces possible.  I think that's how I got the most full from the meal.

The waiter really took care of us.  He was quite awesome, and even had an Italian accent.  I feel like the dishes could have come a bit hotter, since I like my food steaming hot when I receive it.

Nonetheless, you can't complain about such a quaint atmosphere and a bottle of fine wine with your significant other.  I would probably only come here if you are going on a date.  It's a warm cozy place and you won't leave disappointed.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Stormy and I just got back from a weekend in the City and this little out of the way bistro was the high spot. We had great honest Italian dishes here including a wonderful gnocchi (which were light as air which is definitely hard to do).
The wine list is wonderfully approachable as well.

Recommended.
Oh, BTW, take a cab.
author: Duane H.

description: I ate lunch here a few years ago by myself, tired and grumpy and hungry after being stood up for lunch and within 15 minutes, my mood had changed, it was solid and impressive and I vowed to try it again for dinner.  Now, although a few years have passed, we had a chance a few nights ago.  Even the leftovers are satisfying.  Here's the scoop that raises the bar for me to 4 stars; the flavors aren't so concentrated that the textures of the main ingredient are overwhelmed.  This shines through in their gnocchi, which could be described better as cuscini di nuvole (if translate has it right).  The sauce is light, not too 'tomatoey,' just a spectacular dish.  We also tried an eggplant pasta medley that was satisfying and cooked to perfection.  This is a wonderful little gem out by the ball park that would please anyone, anytime, any day.  Give it a try.
author: Peter P.

description:
What a treat!   A real Italian dinner before the San Francisco Giants game on a Saturday night.   Skip the ballpark food and live it up.  We celebrated our daughters 13th birthday with this fantastic group of incredible staff and owners.  

We had the salumi large plate for four. Delicious.   Salads and minestrone soup.  Whallla!  Then we family styled 4 dishes:  lasagna,  fettuccine and clams, and the authentic Italian truffle and wild porcini mushrooms.   BaZing!!!!!!

Did we mentioned the Brunello bottle of Italian Red?  2007????

The celebration of a birthday with a celebration comp'd dessert. 

Hats off to Team Crumb!  Truly authentic Italian and professional! !

Grazie!!!!!!!

Buona Sera!
author: Hot O.

description: Went' here for team lunch. It was easy to get reservations, service was great and the food was better! Loved it and would definitely recommend for large parties with both vegetarian and gluten free options
author: Tasneem M.

description: Quaint charming rustic authentic Italian. Quality wine list. Helpful attentive staff.
author: Sameer C.

description: We wanted a great Italian dinner in the south of Market neighborhood. This restaurant was, at best, mediocre.  The restaurant has a pleasant but unimaginative decor. The waitstaff was attentive. Food: Lamb was accompanied by carrots, potatoes and broccoli in high summer in San Francisco. Really? Are we in Wisconsin? The porcini pasta was soggy and sour. Dessert was indistinguishable from store-bought one.
author: Jen S.

description: Excellent food. Homemade pasta was wonderful. The gnocchi were like pillows in your mouth. We all very much enjoyed the meal. Waiter was also kind and patient. Lovely atmosphere. Great for a date!
author: M C.

description:
I live a block away from this place and have walked by to and from work countless times. From the outside the place looks tiny and dingy. I was very skeptical of the positive Yelp reviews. 
Finally, on a lazy evening, we decided to try it out and were very pleased with our dinner. 
We love the variety of dishes on the menu and everything we ordered were delicious. The service was excellent - our server was welcoming and very attentive. 

We are bring our family back this weekend and no doubt will be regulars.
author: Mimi T.

description:
I've come here twice and ordered the Tortellini in Goat Cheese Cream Sauce both times.  It comes drizzled with a pesto oil around the plate.  It's delicious and comforting but definitely leaves you feeling like you've got some cheese clogged in your arteries.  Your kidneys may also curse at you for the sodium intake so order this one with caution if you're sensitive to heavily salted food.

Good thing I'm not so the saltiness didn't bother me too much.  All in all, a good little Italian joint.  Not super awesome but definitely A-Ok.
author: Maggi K.

description:
First time here but it's a cute and friendly place. Pretty romantic vibe and the staff was super nice.

We got:
Calamari (not the fried ones) - I was a huge fan 
Seabass/lobster Ravioli which was delish
Straccietti (lamb ragu) which was pretty good too

Wine selection was great as well. Unfortunately didn't have time to indulge in the dessert menu as there were drinks to be had elsewhere. 

All in all...for the boys I'd say this is a solid place and a great venue to take a date :)
author: Kathy L.

description:
They get 2 only because the food was OK.
But the service is another matter.
I went with 3 others.  All ordered without substitution but 1 diner's food came a full 5 minutes after the other 3 orders.  Also, "brain dead seating" policy - the place was almost empty - maybe 5 tables - and they sat a very noisy group (from the moment they came through the door), right next to our table for no reason whatsoever.  We had to pick up our plates and go to another unoccupied table in the middle of our meal, just to be able to converse.
Too bad, because I had been here once before without major incident, though I do recall that even then, one of 4 orders came out way after the other 3.  They have to get their act together re delivering all diners' food simultaneously.
author: S K.

description: Came here about half a year ago but still remember it fondly. Cute and (possibly, if you wish) romantic ambience. Great for a small group social gathering (wine night!), that first date, and an anniversary. Loved the wait staff - attentive, helpful, and awesome! Only gripe I had was my boyfriend's seafood risotto...it literally tasted like the sea. I'm all for essence of the sea normally, but this risotto tasted like it had been swimming in the bay before it was reluctantly fished up. Risotto aside...this place is just NOM!
author: Charlene H.

description:
Came here for dinner after seeing a movie at Metreon with a large group.  

Reservation was easy even on a Saturday evening.  

The menu was divided into "ocean" and "land" and was pretty extensive.  If you don't know a lot about different pasta names, you can ask the waiter - they are friendly.

Their services, ambiance, menu options were all very good (I give them 4 stars)

Their food was only okay though.  Most of our pasta was bland and it just wasn't spectacular. All of us got pasta so I don't know what their other entrees are like either.  

Bread that came out at the beginning was nice though.

I can't say anything about their wine list as I wasn't drinking that night.

Would I return?  Maybe.  Their service and authentic Italian vibe is enough for me to want to return even though food wasn't spectacular (maybe it'll be different next time since other yelpers seem to have had a good time there)
author: Sujan H.

description:
Had a large reunion dinner for a group of about 13. We had a reservation and were seated on a Thursday evening no problem. The group split the grilled calamari and burrata appetizers, which were really great. There were a lot of us so I don't blame them but the main dishes did take longer than some of us more hungry folks had hoped. I had the vegetable-filled crepe, which I LOVED! It was like the beautiful delicious love child of a dumpling and a pot pie. I honestly don't know what else to say about it. The accompanying pancini sauce was great as well. I'm usually not super enthusiastic for traditional Italian so this new (to me) dish was pretty exciting. We also split the chocolate soufflé and tiramisu. Personally, the chocolate was too dense for me but I enjoyed the tiramisu. 

For the check we managed splitting the bill down to 4 cards, and they processed it very smoothly so props to them. Our waiters provided great service without being overbearing with their check-ins.
author: Tina W.

description:
I came in for lunch with a few co-workers and unfortunately our experience wasn't so good. The ambiance of the place is nice--clean and well lit, however the service and most importantly the food left a lot to be desired. 

We waited probably about about 45 mins to get our food--which is a long time considering the restaurant was about half empty. When the food did arrive the results weren't impressive. I ordered the red snapper lunch special with broccoli and potatoes. The potatoes looked fine but the broccoli and looked dry and colorless. The fish was decent if slightly on the dry side. A few of my co-workers opted for the lasagna, which was an odd soup-like dish that was spread across the plate. I've never seen lasagna prepared this way. I'm glad I didn't order the lasagna. 

Considering the cost of the food--the service and the preparation were not up to the standard it sets for itself.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I feel kinda bad for giving this place only 2 stars because I feel like there must be something I'm missing with all the great reviews.

Truth is, I thought my dish was only mediocre. I came here for lunch with a coworker because the line at Darwin Cafe was too long. Cute place with good service but the pasta felt undercooked. The sausage was good though. I had the Conchiglie con salsiccia (shell-shaped pasta, sausage, marinara sauce) from the Lunch Special menu. My coworker also wasn't super impressed with his dish (Penne pasticciate al ragu - beef bolognese, tomato sauce, beschamel).

I may come back to try something from their dinner menu, but don't know about lunch.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
'Love' is very often the word I associate with food that I enjoy. Somehow I am hesitant to just say I love La Briciola. 

I adore this restaurant. It was such an exciting feeling to discover something great unexpectedly.

Their rack of lamb was one of the most perfect dish I have had in a really long time. Everything from the texture, taste to presentation were simply flawless. (I even finished off all my vegetables on the side) I could not believe such a wonderful dish could be found at a restaurant in this price range. 

The sea bass ravioli and filet mignon were also top notch. (Thanks to my dinner companions allowing me to sample and photograph their entree)

On the menu there are first and second course section but both are actually regular entree portion. If you are not a big eater the three course dinner might be a challenge.

Bring your date, your friends and your family to this classy restaurant. I promise you will not be disappointed.
author: Mona W.

description:
I enjoyed La Briciola. Their service is great and their food was very tasty.

I'm not entirely sure that the price justifies the experience, but I wasn't disappointed either. Let's call this one 3.5 stars.
author: Jimmy S.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday with a friend with no reservations and the place wasp pretty empty. While the place had a romantic atmosphere (dimmed lights, candles on table), I wouldn't bring a date here just cause of where the place is located. The streets are pretty ghetto around here. Also in terms of atmosphere, if you're unlucky enough - as I was - large parties can prove to be quite obnoxious with their volume due to how small the place is.

On to the food: My friend and I ordered the carpaccio with arugula and parmesan cheese, and the fried calamari for appetizers. The carpaccio was pretty standard. Nothing that I haven't had before at other locations. The calamari was very lightly breaded (almost to the extent of no breading). I personally like my calamari with more breading so I was a bit disappointed. The calamari comes with their homemade marinara sauce, but it was a bit on the watery side. Salt and pepper -- simple stuff, would have made the calamari better as it lacked any flavor. 

For my main, I ordered a sea food stew which comprised of lobster, muscle, clams, shrimp, and broth. I was disappointed yet again. For the most part, everything in the dish was overcooked, the shrimp especially, and it was a bit on the salty side. Though bread is at the table when you start your meal, I wish our waiter would've brought more bread for my stew.

For dessert, I shared a tiramisu and this was definitely the saving part of the meal. BOMB. I'm a fan of rum in desserts and the tiramisu here had a whole lot of it. I approve. 

Our bill came out to $100 with tax and tip. I've had better meals for this price. I don't think I would come here again, but if you're here, I strongly recommend the tiramisu.
author: Austin W.

description:
You know you use yelp too much when you don't really look at the menu but instead just order the item with the most yelp highlights.  So Lamb Ragu it is.  The ragu was pretty flavorful (translation= strong lamb taste).   If you don't like lamb, this isn't for you.  But in contrast this works very well with the homemade noodles.  These are wide noodles so the sauce works well to flavor them.  The noodles were a bit too soft for me, seemed slightly doughy.  

Can't end a meal without dessert.  Ordered the gelato with strawberries.  The strawberries were fresh but the gelato didn't taste like like gelato should but instead tasted more ice cream like (translation = you can assemble your own at home).
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I was looking for a decent Italian restaurant in SF, and Yelp ppl recommended this place, so I made reservation and drove 40+ min to this place... and what I found was... just. crap.

Carpaccio di manzo - decent but overpriced
Gnocchi Sorrentina - don't get it.. Chef Boyardee's ravioli is superior 
Linguine alle vongole - i can make better than this
Risotto al nero di seppia - overcooked n boring 
Crème Caramel - eh. 

I asked to have the Vongole spicy, and there was no single 
peperoncino in my dish. What a fail. Water was the best part of this dinner. 

Bottom Line: waste of time and gas. and moneyy.
author: Sunny K.

description:
We had a reservation for a special occasion, and despite there only being one other party,  we were seated in an unappealing station (kind of by the door) I can't remember much beyond the burrata appetizer, which was delicious.
Shared a cioppino, which was hit or miss. Some of the bits were perfectly cooked, others too much so. The broth was lackluster, but definitely fresh. 
Got to try other people's food; it was okay.
I did not care for the wine by the glass.
Service was ok.&--
Might come back if someone else were paying.
author: Rachel D.

description:
Color me disappointed. Not in the food but in our server.  His name according to the receipt was Gianluca.  Wow.  Send that guy out for reeducation on manners! I'm talking Clockwork Orange style reprogramming.  Let me tell you the tale. 

My wife and I both work in S.F. and drive in together.  On this particular night in which we were served by Rosemary's baby, we had decided to eat before driving home because traffic was a reenactment of the opening of "I am Legend" or "World War Z". 

We ate our main meal at a nice little eatery near my wife's place of work.  After we had finished our meal, traffic hadn't improved.  I suggested we get something else.  My beautiful bride expressed a strong desire for Tiramisu.  My deft fingers played across the screen of my mobile computing device putting Angelina Jolie's character in Hackers to shame (low bar to clear).  With the assistance of Yelp, I located an Italian restaurant nearby that had Tiramisu on the menu.  

We made our way to La Briciola.  Entering the establishment I noticed the place was maybe 35% full.  The waiter/host Gianluca told us we could choose any seat we would like.  We moved to the back of the room to get away from the open front door.  

Gianluca provided us with menus and left.   When we looked at the menus we realized that menus didn't offer dessert.  When the busboy (who was great) came to offer us water and bread, we requested dessert menus and he quickly obliged.  

We made our selections quickly and Gianluca was quick to return as we had placed our menus on the table.  My wife ordered first.  She told Gianluca that she would like the Tiramisu.  He quickly responded "This is a restaurant."  We prodded for more information, "Ok?"  Gianluca volunteered more details... "This is not a cafe!"  My wife asked "So...we can't just order dessert?"  Gianluca replied "No."

"Okay, we'll we will leave."
"Well. since you are already here..." replied Gianluca.

He was apparently doing us a huge favor.  I asked him if he was the owner or manger and he said no.  

I would have asked to speak with the manager if my wife wasn't with me.  I didn't want to embarrass her.  However, I would welcome the owner to contact me.  

The panna cotta and tiramisu were good, but spoiled by the eloquent disdain of Gianluca.
author: Lloyd H.

description:
We discovered this place during a recent trip to San Franciso. It was a terrific, truly authentic experience - honestly, the closest that I've found since we were actually in Italy. The ambiance was romantic but inviting and the service was spectacular.

We made a reservation for two through Yelp only about 30 minutes prior. When we arrived we had to wait an extra five minutes past our reservation but to make it up to us they offered us a glass of prosecco to enjoy while we waited.

We had the burrata appetizer - incredible burrata
My husband ordered their meat lasagna special. It was really good and had great flavor that went far beyond the everyday lasagna. I ordered the squid and scallops inked risotto. This was the only place that they fell a bit short - the risotto could have been a bit more tender and there were only two small scallops in the dish which acted more as a decoration than a piece of the meal. It was still good but I think that I could have found something that would have been more on the level of the burrata and lasagna.

Overall, I would definitely recommend it and go back. I'm hoping to find a chance to return the future and take another stab at ordering.
author: Mandi D.

description:
Food was good, but not spectacular.  Ambiance was nice, but not amazing.

Had a good time catching up with some girlfriends last night w/a bottle of wine.

Everything we had was quite tasty..but didn't lacked some UMPH to push it to a 4-5 star review. If I was in the area would not hesitate to go, but would not go out of my way to go back.

- crab pot pie
- lamb ragu
- sea bass ravioli with lobster reduction
- burrata
- brushetta (prob least impressive) 
- tiramisu, chocolate souffle
author: Melody T.

description:
Authentic Italian. We dined here for the second time after three years, and La Briciola confirms to be an authentic Italian restaurant, among many that pretend to be like that. As an Italian born and raised, I can tell that the dishes were prepared according to the tradition and with very good quality ingredients. The lasagna was outstanding, exactly the same that I could expect in a traditional Italian home (and that takes a lot of time to be properly prepared).
Interesting wine list, with some "excellent" bottles (although, expect to pay a good amount of money if you want one of them). I would definitely recommend La Briciola
author: Giorgio R.

description:
11.05.11

Small neighborhood Italian restaurant, halfway between the ballpark and office buildings.  Blink and you will miss it.  So don't blink.

I've had this place bookmarked for 2.5 years, and finally had a chance to try it on Saturday.  I was very pleasantly surprised by the ambiance.  Perfect for a low key date or a small group dinner.  Mixed in from a Cal football crowd (which is what we were).

Started with the bottle of petite syrah - yum o.  Also had the calamari to share, and that was lightly battered and fried, not too oily, definitely flavorful.  Good appetizer to begin the meal!

Entrees: seabass ravioli [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iH0f1TMuwLOb5hXz4Y4UOA?select=FvGjVK_z2hT68ehpcWzYgQ], tagliatelle [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iH0f1TMuwLOb5hXz4Y4UOA?select=CZJ6S9GbZV6Yxcovla0iSg], gnocchi [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iH0f1TMuwLOb5hXz4Y4UOA?select=yBuuhVrmMxGXRfWjkXeBkg], and your seafood platter extravaganza [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iH0f1TMuwLOb5hXz4Y4UOA?select=kMJdNMwm09PPncEmqzYxZg].  Portions were just right, definitely not too small, and not too much that you're uncomfortably full and have to waddle out the door.

Fabulous experience!  Especially the part where my credit card wasn't chosen for roulette :D

Total damage for four: $180.
author: Jenny L.

description:
- Ambiance (4/5)
La Briciola, upscale and cozy, belies its name meaning The Crumb, in Italian.  It must be one special crumb.  

- Service (3/5)
The service is cordial and they brought out a tiramisu on the house for our friend's birthday.  However, some of the service was a little slow.  Drink orders came and went quickly, but it took a long time before we could make our dinner selections.  Food also came out pretty slowly.

- Bread (3/5)
The bread has a nice crust, though the interior itself isn't particularly dense or soft.  

- Tagliere di Salumi, $14 (3/5)
A few large pieces of prosciutto not sliced particularly thin-- it was good prosciutto but could've used a more delicate touch.  The marinated vegetables were a nice add!

- Gnocchi Sorrentina, $19 (3/5)
Always nice to get handmade pasta.  I liked the simplistic approach, but the gnocchi itself was a little heavy.  Personally, I think great gnocchi should be light, smooth, airy pillows!  

- Value (5/5)
For SF, for an upscale feeling Italian restaurant, pasta dishes at less than $20 are a steal.

- Final Word
As a New Englander, I've got high expectations for Italian food, though I've learned to adjust those expectations a little bit here.  That being said, the gnocchi just isn't quite there-- a bit lighter texture, and La Briciola gets upgraded to a 4.
author: Jeff J.

description: This place is a gem. The lamb ragu pasta reminded me of my Nonna's sauce, so delicious. The service was great and the servers very friendly. The Tiramisu was to die for; just the right amount of sweetness. Definitely recommend this place if u r craving great Italian food.
author: Danny P.
