description:
We dinned at La Bricola recently and had 2 of their specials. I was quite pleased!
The bread + olive oil dip is superb! The pasta we ordered was a little bland, but still tasty, and the lamb shank special was just what I was looking for! Boyfriend was a little underwhelmed, but I was happy. Wine is a good price + servers are nice!
author: Nelli S.

description:
La Briciola is a very traditionally decorated Italian restaurant, so homey it reminded me of the restaurants in Burlingame and San Mateo. I read many reviews of La Briciola being mediocre, or slow. Turns out, the service is NOT slow! With so many great Italian options nearby I doubt I will be returning anytime soon.

The pros:
The prices are reasonable. The service was perfectly fine, I didn't notice it being particularly slow or unusually friendly either. The burrata cheese was super creamy and delicious, on par with Ristorante Milano. The proscuitto was a little skimpy, and too gamey for my taste. The ingredients arugula, and spinach in the spinach salad were INCREDIBLY FRESH. The wine list is amazing - they have Opus 1 from 2008. That said, it was mostly downhill from here. 

The cons: 
The orecchiette pasta with sausage was terrible. It had zero flavor because there was zero sauce. The halibut was decent, pretty well cooked but I just wasn't a fan of tomato based sauce. The squid ink risotto was terrible. First, it was rice pilaf - not the short grained risotto - and it was totally undercooked (and I like my pasta al dente!). It tasted less than average and had very minimal seafood mixed in. Cheap! And it wasn't creamy at all.

Needless to say, I didn't stay for dessert.
author: Jess C.

description:
Absolutely delicious pasta and impeccable service! 

I ordered the Tagliatelleai porcini e tartufo, which was rich in both black truffles and truffle oil. Our appetizer, the beef carppacio, was equally incredible. 

The ambiance offers a very homey and intimate vibe, but I can also see myself revisiting again for a romantic date.
author: Vivien S.

description:
Maybe it's unfair for me to review an Italian restaurant in SF.  I'm from the East Coast where they have actual good Italian food.  I've been to places with friendly staff and inspired menus.  Italian food in SF is just never gonna compete with that.

La Briciola is a decent spot - reasonably tasty food and prices that aren't insane.  I was put off by the rudeness of the staff and a few of my dinner companions commented on it.  I'm not sure what put the bee in their bonnet but they weren't much fun.
author: Ivan L.

description:
Found this little hidden gem of an Italian restaurant while looking for a place on Yelp (of all places). Don't let the sketchy neighborhood fool you. Inside it's charming, the food is excellent and the service is great too!

I had a delicious spinacini salad to start (spinach, goat cheese, walnuts) and then followed it with orecchiette with sausage and broccoli rabe. I also managed (ha) to drink a couple glasses of a delicious and reasonably priced Barolo.

I saved enough room for dessert and enjoyed their version of a molten chocolate cake. Not quite flourless, but a good facsimile and IMHO better than most desserts at Italian places.

Oh, and did I mention the service? Great. Never bothersome, but I also never waited when I needed something. 

I'd definitely go back another time and bring a group, seems like a great place to have a big group-style meal - somewhere just between casual and fancy.
author: Joshua B.

description:
I came here for a quick dinner tonight and was impressed with the decor of the restaurant.  It was a little empty when I came because it was getting close to 9PM.  The waiter was quick to take our order, but kind of slow at the end of our meal to grab our CC for the bill.

For $19, I got a shallow bowl of pasta with mussels, clams~calamari, and shrimp mixed in a light, semi-watery sauce.  The dish itself was decent, except for a couple of things.  One one shrimp that had its shell intact was not fresh at all.  The meat was falling apart and was soft.  One of the mussels was actually a bad mussel because the moment I put it in my mouth, a stench escaped the shriveled, brown-orange mussel and hit me bad.  Not cool.

Still, I have to rate La Briciola at least 3 stars because I think the workers here are nice and their overall service wasn't that bad.  I think sometimes you just get a bad mussel and shrimp mixed in with some of the good stuff (there were a lot of good, fat, bouncy shrimps in the mix).  Also, they offer you a lot of bread to go with their delicious bread dip.
author: May W.

description:
We were attending an event in SOMA today, thanks to Yelp reviews, I chose La 
Briciola. It is rare to find a restaurant where every dish exceeds expectations.The food was excellent: perfectly cooked/extremely tender chicken breasts with porcini mushrooms. I intended to eat only half of the chicken, but this was not possible because it was just delicious! My other two family members had wonderful pastas, also cooked perfectly with flavorful sauces. The Creme Carmel and Tirimisu were both wonderful, not too sweet; salads were tasty and fresh. 

We were fortunate to come on a night when the 2 owners were there, what delightful men! Our chats with one owner made the entire experience fantastic. We will not only recommend La Briciola to friends, we will drive over an hour to come here again, hopefully many more times!

This intimate gem cannot be missed if you want to try a restaurant which brings you back to Italy, even for a few hours.
author: M. G.

description:
Came here with my girls for lunch.

Arrived shortly after 12 and man was this place empty. There was only 3 tables here the entire time we were eating. 

The ambiance is very nice and has the feel of a nice romantic place one would come to on a date. I also like how the tables were spacious. 

We were given a basket of bread that was already in small pieces. I like that. Came with a side of olive oil. The bread was tasty even without the olive oil. 

We all ordered off the lunch special menu. I ordered the 

Penne alla carbanara egg, pancetta,  parmigiano 12 - The food took a while to arrive so use the bread to keep you busy. The entrees are a bit small by American standards but it is just right if you don't want to be fully stuffed. Enough room for dessert if that is what you desire. I enjoyed this immensely wouldn't mind if there was more. I didn't feel that there was any egg but the pancetta added a great smoky taste to the sauce. 

It is slightly pricey for the quantity but the quality made up for it. The waitress was attentive and helped us make change. 

A bathroom for men and a bathroom for women. Inside the female restroom is a stall and a sink. 

I wouldn't mind coming back in the future when I have money.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Went here the other night.  Easy to get table, excellent service, and food came out pretty fast.  Always a fan of an Italian restraunt w/ italian waiters from Italy.  Had the seafood stew reminded me of the Almafi.  
Again great service, good wine, and great food all make for perfect dinner.
author: Leonard C.

description:
After some last minute dinner planning, we ended up here based on JL's suggestion.  Probably would never have noticed it otherwise.  

AMBIANCE: Moderate lightly, borderline dim.  We arrived a little late to our 6PM reservation... but realized that reservations were definitely not necessary-- the entire place was empty!  JL was initially worried b/c he had noticed all the opentable rezzies being snapped up, but clearly La Briciola has plenty of tables saved up for phone/walk-ins.  As our meal progressed the restaurant slowly filled up, but it was at most maybe at 50-60% capacity. 

SERVICE: Very friendly and "Italian."  I wasn't entirely sure how authentically Italian, but either way they were courteous and very patient with us (we took our slow sweet time).

FOOD: We ordered two apps to share and each had a pasta entree.
- Tagliere di Salumi ($14): Yummy assorted meat plate.  We shared a small between 4 people and it was more than plenty.  I particularly liked the thickly sliced salame.  JL was a fan of the peppers.
- Polpo con fagiolini e orzo ($14): I was hoping for tender octopus, so I was pretty disappointed in this dish.  The octopus meat was tough, chewy, and barely warm (English description states "warm octopus").  The shaved fennel was yummy though. 

- Orecchiette con salsiccia e rapini ($18): J's dish was unfortunately extremely bland.  I liked how the pasta was cooked though-- perfectly al dente.  The broccoli rabe added a nice bite of slight bitterness, but I felt like it should've been paired with a richer sauce... instead of nonexistent sauce... The sausage was only ok flavor-wise.
- Ravioli di cernia ($19): Definitely the better pasta dish of the two IMHO.  Robust flavors, but pasta was overcooked, which didn't help the already mushy texture of the seabass filling.  I really liked the drizzle of basil oil along the edge of the plate, which added a bright fresh flavor to the somewhat fishy tasting dish.

I also sampled the Straccietti al ragú di agnello ($18), which was too gamey for my tastes, but is probably popular amongst most diners.  The lasagne JM ordered came as a HUGE rectangular portion, over which they shaved a very generous amount of cheese.  He scraped up every last bite, so I assume he enjoyed it.

OVERALL: Decent neighborhood option, though not a restaurant I would trek all the way from the southbay for.  The pasta seems to be made in house, as it was very fresh, and I would recommend one that is listed as having a sauce or reduction, as the one we tried with only olive oil listed was quite flavorless.
author: Susanna W.

description:
Amazing!  Definitely a hidden gem......

I agree with other yelpers, don't let the outside fool you.  Honestly, the outside of the restaurant is kinda ghetto because it is located in the old building.  But it is different when you walk into the restaurant.  The decor of the restaurant is not amazing but can able to give you a cozy and relaxing feeling.  

Everyone was so friendly, polite and welcome.  Upon sitting, the server delivered the basket of bread (a lot) with a side of olive oil.  The bread was so good; warm, crusty and soft at the same time.  

We have ordered:

Bruschette assortite ($9.00) - zucchini, eggplant and fresh tomatoes were on the toasted bread.  It was so good.  All ingredients were fresh and tasty.

Pepata di cozze e vongole ($14.00) - steamed mussels and clams.  The portion was pretty big.  Good to share with your date or friend.  The sauce was flavorful but not too heavy.

Gnocchi Sorrentina ($17.00) - potato dumplings, fresh mozzarella and basil with tomato sauce.  OMG it was so good.  The Gnocchi was so light, soft and melted in your mouth.  The sauce was flavorful.    

Too bad that we were so full and had no room for dessert......

Overall, I had a wonderful dinning experience.  Everything was awesome.  Amazing food, good service, cozy atmosphere, reasonable prices......I will definitely be back for sure!
author: Liza T.

description: I like the approach of modern regional Italian that has spread across SF. Briciola opened a few years ago and I had gone during July 4th when I found Commis to be closed. Carpacio and Burrata are solid. The seafood stew was unfortunately overcooked but still had good flavor. Service is humble but friendly. My guess from some of the reviews is the consistency needs to be targeted. Hope they get on a good course as it's always good to have another Italian option in the pocket.
author: Kim N.

description: Not recommended, food was very under seasoned. I usually don't put salt in the restaurant but it was so bland! And I'm from Chicago so I had some good italian food before. We ordered seafood tagliolini and lamb ragu. Not worth it.
author: Claire C.

description: Best Italian restaurant in San Francisco..  We love the black spaghetti seafood.  The service was wonderful.  Thank you Luca and Alfredo for your service.  Almost forgot we also like the tiramisu,  will be back for more tasty food.
author: Anna C.

description:
This is my problem with Yelp: some people give 5 stars to restaurants that really deserve 3 stars. Quince, Coi (on the upper side), La Ciccia (mid-range), and House of Xian Dumpling (lower end) all deserve 5 stars! La Briciola? 3 Stars. It's not great, but it's not bad. 

On the plus side: the interior, mood and lighting is wonderful (it's better than the food), and the wine list is good and very reasonably priced.

On the "okay" side: the meals in general need much more garlic and FLAVOR; when one depends on grated cheese to become the main taste, then you know it's not that great); the free dipping olive oil with black olives (tapenade) need better quality oil.

On the less than impressive side: the service was slow and, as a result, the dishes seemed to have been kept warm in the back.  Thus, they got a notch dry by the time we got served; and my salmon was over cooked.

Final Grade: B to B-
author: Randy M.

description:
We found this place on Yelp, which is probably the only way anyone ever finds it.  The location is bizarre, but the food was delicious, the atmosphere was cozy and the service was outstanding.  We went almost a year  ago and my husband still mentions how we need to get back there some time when we are in the city without the baby (which should be in ten years or so).

Also, the Yelp sidebar is showing me a review written recently by some crackerjack culinary connoisseur who gave this restaurant one star, calls it a tourist trap and says "if you want proper italian, go to North Beach".   Hahahahahaha.  Yes, sir.  You do that.  Take your friends too, so that the  rest of us won't have to sit next to idiots while we eat.
author: Angela R.

description:
Came here on a rainy October afternoon for lunch with my honey. Saw that it was well rated on yelp, decided to give it a try. We were not mislead!  

For the Antipasti, we ordered the stewed clams and mussels and the grilled calamari. Both were out of this world. The clams/mussels were very flavorful due to the savory broth that it came in. The calamari were grilled to perfection, tasted very fresh. 

For the Primi, I had the Seafood Risotto, chock full of large prawns and clams and calamari pieces. The most amazing thing that made me feel like I hit the authenticity jackpot was the fact that there were 2 huge prawns with THE HEAD STILL ON!! That tells me that the chef must know that the shrimp heads impart the most flavor if left on. And it was true. The Risotto tasted like it should: Seafoody, not fishy; rich, and very filling due to the generous amount of seafood in it. My honey had the Lamb Ragu with Penne, and he thought it was deliciously al dente, with the ragu not overpowering the pasta, just light and flavorful, but filling as well. 

The service was wonderful and warm, with the staff speaking to you in Italian, being very attentive to the fact that we were water guzzlers. Our glasses were never empty. Didn't have room for dessert this time. Maybe next time! We will be back.
author: Mei W.

description:
tip: park around the corner on Stillman for free for an hour

great place to eat with significant other, good dimly lit ambiance, full bar.  you're sol without a reservation.  the tables are configured with just enough room to squeeze through but not so close that you could hear everything the other tables are saying.

this place delivers simple Italian fares, nothing is really complex.  Grilled squid with chickpea puree was very tasty although the puree could be served without it.  squid was charred in some places but i guess that's a given.  puff pastry seafood was great, had bits of crab and shrimp.  It tasted like a clam chowder in a puff pastry. clam linguine was not as flavorful as I thought.  it was heavy on the wine side, can't really taste the clam broth (if it even had any).  Some clams had sand in it, but i guess it's not their fault.  beef lasagna (special of the day) was very simple but decadent.  I like the fact that it had many layers and there's no cheese inside (although they offer cheese on top).  the lemonade is actually lemon soda which is great.

would i come back to try the many other menu items? sure. 
but then i would rather try the many other great Italian restaurants in the city before coming back.
author: Jacky K C.

description:
I came here for dinner with a couple of friends one night, as we were in the SOMA area and wanted Italian. We made reservations and were seated almost immediately, though it wasn't busy right away.

While the meal wasn't terrible, La Briciola is certainly missing many key points such as good service (the entire time, our waitress seemed rushed, frantic, and wasn't very friendly), quality food (our pastas were ok -- I had a ragu, my friends had the orecchiette and fettuccini -- with al dente noodles that were too chewy and certainly not homemade tasting), and overall ambiance. It felt like a place people had decided on because they were nearby or had a large group to entertain. I didn't get the feeling that La Briciola was your neighborhood Italian restaurant and frankly, won't need to come back here.
author: Johanna L.

description:
Food was edible, not outstanding. Ambiance was nice and cozy. Waitstaff was useless and SHADY!!! Let me say it again in case you misunderstood... FREAKING SHADY!!! Can I give them negative stars?

Came as a group of 14 for a birthday dinner. Had no issues bringing us wine but took numerous requests before we got water and bread, think our appetizers came before the gave us water or bread. They then proceeded to screw up on our orders. We had to remind them to bring out dessert for the birthday boy, even though they reassured us before he got there that they'll make it happen. GRR!!!

The bill with gratuity came out to a little $632. We split the bill 13 ways came out to $50 a person. Two couples paid with credit cards, and the rest in cash, totaling $650. The waiter ran the cards, and came back with partial cash claiming that we're short $22. We counted the cash; there was only $310. He explained that he took out the "gratuity" amount  from the cash. WHAT?!?

First of all, we triple counted the cash so we know we weren't short. Secondly, it was an even number as we round up to tip them extra, how is it that all of a sudden we now have a odd number? (310 + 116= 426) Thirdly, why take out  amount returning a partial amount of the cash and claiming we were short? Either way, the numbers just didn't add up. 

Per the birthday boys request, we let it go as it was not a huge amount. But it really isn't about the money, more of the principle of it. As patrons of a fine dining establishment, we truly didn't expect unscrupulous behavior from the waitstaff. They may have gotten lucky that we let it go and chose not to take it up with management but they can be sure that there would be no returns from any of us. We have nothing but bad things to say about this restaurant to all our acquaintances.
author: Wendy Y.

description: Cutest little Italian restaurant tucked away on 3rd and Bryant in SoMa! Good for date night or family/ friend dinners. It's small and cozy and the wait staff is so friendly. The food is also really good - recommend the seafood risotto and the tiramisu for dessert!
author: Riley C.

description:
Really nice waiters and good service, but I felt like the price was extremely high for what you get.  

The food was ok.  Just ok.  Nothing special or anything.  
The portions are extremely small for the big price you pay.  Like seriously, how much do noodles cost you to get?  You can put double the amount that you did and that would take away less than a dollar of your already huge profits.
author: Tim L.

description: Great place for dinner.  The arugula salad was enough for two people and very good.  A little heavy on the vinegar but still good.  The linguine with clams was also very good and filling.  The pasta was cooked perfectly.  the dish was garlicky though, so probably not something you'd want to order if you're on a date!  Also had the panna cotta which I would definitely order again.
author: Debbie L.

description: Pretty nice cozy restaurant nice option for first date!!!The food is pretty great they have one of the best backed salmon dish
author: Emanula M.

description:
Walking around the neighborhood, you would never expect to find a nice Italian restaurant with great food and great  atmosphere in this part of SOMA.

My GF and I got to the restaurant around 7:30 and it was pretty quiet.  Not that it was empty but there were definitely a number of open tables.  However, by the time we left (approx 9), it was pretty packed.  So I'd recommend a reservation if you're coming by on a weekend evening.

The food is pretty good.  We started with the spinach salad and the crostinis.  I really liked the chicken pate crostini.  Somehting about it just worked.  The spinach salad was also nice but nothing to write home about.

As an entree, I got the Tagliolini di mare, which was very good.  The pasta had great texture and there was plenty of seafood in the dish.  The one weird thing is they didn't give me a bowl/plate for me to put the mussel/clam shells.  Not horrible, but would've been nice.  My GF got the risotto with sausage which was also very good.  Nice and creamy, perfect for a cool evening.
author: Larry L.

description:
DELICIOUS Italian food. It's as close to Italy as you'll get without going to Italy. The gnocchi (both of them) are delicious - my favorite is the one made with spinach in the sauce. The ravioli is really good too and the panna cotta is amazing.

I've gotten take out from here a few times, and then came here for my birthday. Fantastic service, super friendly waiters, great ambiance, delicious food - what more can you ask for?
author: Sami A.

description:
Briciola, you almost had me.  4 years you've been hiding from me on a dark street in middle-of-no-where SOMA, just hoping I wouldn't find you.  Oh, but I found you, alright...like my dog sniffing out a delicious piece of spam from a mile away.  

I found you and your amazing Barata...the Barata that is so perfectly chewy that it challenges the phase transition between liquids and solids.  Your perfectly al dente Linguine with Clams that still haunt my dreams, teaching me you CAN taste a garlic, olive oil, and white wine, even when sleeping.  Or maybe your incredibly tender Baked Halibut that I later tried and wish I had ordered...but nonetheless found a good home in my friend's belly.  After that food, the randomly obscure Belgian / Flemish Ale and crazy rich-but-tasty chocolate cake that you served me was just a cherry on top...you had me at Ciao.  

Oh Briciola, I will return soon...and then again soon after that.  Next time I will try your Pennette al Granchio con la Rucola, something that you could not offer me last time...and I will not have your overly salty Seabass Ravioli the next time I come.  But we are friends now...BEST FRIENDS...and friends don't hold grudges over petty things like that.  Until next time, Signore Briciola..
author: Rosers M.

description: I don't go to most places twice. It's my second time going here and I have got to say it's pretty good! Love the ambience, so relaxing, charming, prefect for wine and a casual dinner! The service is just as amazing as the accent! And I must mention Raihondo having served us twice, continues to make our experience perfect! Come here with your date, an old friend or for a girl's night out! You won't have the ideal dinner you've planned out in your mind, but if you sit back and let the evening unfold, you will have a quiet nice one!
author: Nimeela D.

description:
Me and my wife went there on Christmas Eve.
Being italian, we really enjoyed speaking Italian to the staff. 

The food was really good: I enjoyed a wonderful Italian Cheese sampler appetizer and Gnocchi con Taleggio - I highly recommend both. My wife instead went for Octopus and then Ravioli con Cernia - Not superb but also recommended. For second entree we enjoyed Tonno con Sesamo - Delicious but maybe small portion.
At last, we ended everything, as in tradition, with an original Espresso.

Definitely a place to check out, especially if you want to try Italian cuisine.
author: Paolo I.

description: excellent bread, fabulous tagliolini and squid ink risotto. i loved how friendly the service was.
author: Judy L.

description:
This was our second time. The first time we had stumbled in out of the rain and found ourselves in a quiet bit of Tuscany (as reimagined for SOMA). Several of the staff speak Italian and the food is a tasty blend of very traditional Italian with some local artisanal offerings and local seafood. 

The hearty sourdough bread and aromatic olive oil with a touch of olive tapenade was awesome. My partner had the vegetable-stuffed crepes, which we'd also had the time before. They are good, but the cream sauce makes them very filling; they'd be much better to share than to have for one person as an appetizer. Or perhaps the crepes and a salad as the whole meal. I started with the warm seafood salad: sauteed or braised calamari, peeled prawns, and mussels, in a light seafood broth with a bit of garlic. The best part (well, the most interesting part) was thinly shave fennel in the seafood salad that seemed to have been braised in the shellfish broth, such that it took on the seafood flavors while retaining a faintly crisp sweetness. I sopped up every bit of the broth with the bread. (I miss real sourdough down in LA, Nancy Silverton's La Brea Bakery notwithstanding.) 

For pasta, I had tagliatelle that tasted homemade (delightfully chewy and tender) with porcini and truffles. My partner had the classic orecchiette wtih rapini and sausage. He felt it was a tad on the salty side, but I thought it was just right. The rapini was perfectly al dente, the sausage both sweet and savory, and the orrechiette balanced out the other two. :Last time we had shared the bruschette misti, a lamb chop special (meltingly tender), and the rabbit. I'd happily have had the rabbit again (or the lamb chops, if they'd been on offer), but we wanted to explore the menu further. 

No room for dessert this time. We will certainly be back. Service is excellent, atmosphere romantic, food consistently great.
author: Cage H.

description:
It's always a nice surprise to find an authentic Italian place in the city. Appetizers, entrees, and desserts were really good and, of course, espresso!
Among the things I tried and recommend there are:

Fagottini ripieni, Straccietti al ragú di agnello, Tagliatelle ai porcini e tartufo,
Linguine alle vongole, Risotto di mare.

I went there couple of times with group of friends, and service has been good both times, albeit the place wasn't very crowded (I read few bad reviews complaining about that, so can't really tell). 
Decorations are what you would find in a typical Italian restaurant, which I would describe as essential.
If you want real Italian food, I think this is very close to the best you can get in town.
author: Steve E.

description: OMG i FOUND A HAIR IN MY PASTA!!  this place is DISGUSTING-- worst thing is that before i found the hair i found that the food was also mediocre.  the area is also super sketchy...come at your own risk.
author: Melissa K.

description:
Cute hidden gem!!  Great ambiance.  I took my boyfriend here for his birthday dinner and it was romantic and delicious. 

We started with some champagne.  They didn't even give us dirty looks when we were overly gushy.  I loved the complimentary bread and olive oil that had chunks of olive in it (I also love olive tapenade so this makes sense).  The burrata appetizer was amazing!  I also had the filet mignon which was ok. 

Overal, a decent experience and I would go back again to try more items on their menu!
author: Janet Z.

description:
Occasion: Dinner with visiting friends 

What I Had: Gnocchi Sorrentina 

Food Review: The Gnocchi Sorrentina included pomodoro, fresh mozzarella, and basil. Portion size was decent, and the food came out promptly. I think the gnocchi tasted especially good because I hadn't had gnocchi in a while, but other than that, nothing stood out. 

Service Review: I'll give our poor waiter credit for being so understanding with our little party as we were rushing to catch my friend's flight. 

Venue Review: The interior of the restaurant is clean and classy, but it's a shame that it's located right next to an overpass. 

Overall Impression: Not wowed, but it's near my apartment and decent Italian!
author: Rachael K.

description:
Avoid this typical North SoMa tourist trap!  

Uninspired, boring dishes.  I've had better food on cruise ships.  Subpar service.  Expensive for what it was, this should be listed on Yelp as $$$ and not $$.  

If you want proper Italian, go to North Beach.
author: Phillip S.

description: I love the waiter and service! Really awesome! I live the pasta offered here too, and the dessert is on the house for me and my friends! Will definitely come back!
author: Bonnie W.

description:
Among the many dinners I have had recently, this one really stands out!

The place is hard to find, but once you enter you will be transported into a world of personalized service and perfectly made delish food.

Dinner here was with a group of friends who love and enjoy food.We were a group of eight and amongst us some are regulars here. The owner instantly recognized them and was personally looking over all our needs.

They made a mistake in bringing the dish I ordered. I wanted the vegetarian version of the gnocchi as against the one with meat. And it may have been my error as it's hard to pronounce the names of dishes that are in Italian. However, I loved the number of dishes on offer and the swiftness with which the chef politely changed my dish. I didn't even have to wait for a few minutes after my friends had begun eating, and I was soon eating my extremely delicious gnocchi that just melted in my mouth. A good restaurant is not about being apologetic and delaying the order further, but acknowledging and correcting the mistake swiftly as if it never occurred and that is where this place is an example. Have I used the word exemplary already?! :)

My friend had a taste of Ravioli and the sauce was just perfect and another friend got a mushroom pasta that was heavenly.Overall, everyone of us loved what we ate and how it was served to us. Did I forget to mention the complimentary bruschetta and the bread that was served as appetizers. They were so tasty that we were almost full even before dinner.

A friend ordered some coffee after the dinner and I must say it was as good or even better than the blue mountain coffee that I so enjoy and recommend.

We will go back here and you must go too!!!!
author: Harsha G.

description: We were here for a work lunch. Service to start was a bit slow and the timing from the food to come out of the kitchen was not optimal as one was delivered 5 minutes before the others. It felt as if there was a staff shortage but it was busy with many large tables. However, when it arrived. the  food was very good. I would try again based on the high wuLity of the food and it's a lovely space.
author: Kristin N.

description: A true hidden gem. Delicious authentic Italian food. So glad we decided to have my birthday dinner here last night! Our waiter was awesome & pleasant. We ordered the lobster ravioli, Ceasar salad, and puff pastry that looks like a pot pie of some sort. All delicious! We ate everything!
author: Marie H.

description:
"Just okay" is how I'd sum up this place. I came for a team lunch before the holidays. It was troublesome from the beginning! My co-worker that made the reservations had a hard time with the customer service when she called to place the reservation AND when she called to confirm the reservation. When we got there, we experienced a really subpar waitstaff. We waited almost an hour from the time we ordered to the time we received our main dishes.

And when the food came, it really wasn't worth the amount of time it took for us to receive it. I'm pretty sure they forgot our order since we had to ask them a few times. (Though I don't know how you can forget an order for a party of 8!) For main courses, I tried the tagiliatelle with truffle (really flavorful but a tad too salty), the seabass ravioli (too fishy) and the risotto with sausage (definitely a no). 

So our mistake was picking this restaurant that was much too noisy for exchanging conversations across the table. Their mistake was having only two servers during the busy lunch hour. Lose-lose, and I don't think I'll be coming back.
author: Shira C.

description: Went here for a friend's birthday party. There was a large group of us - 10 people. We were placed in the back nice and private. The wine list is great and we had a good bottle of Barbera (only $38!). We were really looking forward to the food. I ordered the risotto with sausage (risotto is my favorite dish, I always order it when on the menu and grew up with my dad's homemade risotto - yum!) The risotto came out looking more like Indian saffron rice than italian risotto - not creamy, almost crunchy. My friend next to me got the gnocchi and it was flavorless in a runny red sauce (should have been in a creamy sauce or bolognese sauce if you ask me!) The service was good but the food was just not up to par. I will not return....
author: Annette K.

description:
Our food was amazing. We had 6 dishes served family style and the meal was perfect. The staff and management did everything the could to help us after we had an emergency getting to the restaurant.

I will recommend to everyone!
author: Joshua B.

description:
Although it's just down the street, we have never tried La Briciola and last Friday night we finally came with some friends. 

This is the perfect neighborhood restaurant! 

Our waiter was Italian and pronounced all the dishes with the proper Italian accent. 

Although my friend made a reservation, it wasn't needed as the walk-ins would be welcome even on Friday. 

The food: 

*complimentary bread with olive oil that still has a delicious olive taste to it 
*cheese plate-probably my least favorite dish; the cheese was yummy but it was quite a small plate for the price 

*Seafood lasagne-made fresh and tasted it. The sauce was so good 

*Seabass ravioli-equally delicious; wanted to lick the sauce off the plate. 

We didn't get to try dessert this time but will definitely be back to try some of their other food! Would highly recommend this cute local restaurant!
author: Betty C.

description: Great little spot, Giovanni the waiter/manager is great! excellent food and service at a reasonable price.
author: Kevin K.

description:
My friend took me here for my birthday on a Saturday night.  We didn't have to wait  even though we didn't make a reservation.   

Service was awesome.  Our waiter was extremely friendly and attentive.   

Nice ambience. The pictures don't do the interior justice.  It was very intimate and cozy with the right amount of classiness.  The menu was also simplistic but very elegant.   

The food was alright, a bit pricey for regular dishes that you could get at any other Italian restaurants.   Here's what we ordered:  

- Filet Mignon
- Linguine alle Vongole
- Squid Ink. 

Overall, decent food, nice venue, a bit expensive, but superb customer service.
author: Thuan T.

description:
Calm, quiet ambiance to enjoy a great Italian meal.  The spinach salad is a delightful start to the meal.  The goat cheese is so smooth and creamy.  Get the gnocci = Potato Pillows of Perfection. It's seriously the best gnocci I've ever had. I love veal and paired with the speck, it is a perfect introduction if you have never eaten it.

I also tried a new wine, Vermentino, delicious!

Just go, enjoy, and get swept up in the Italian ambiance and language spoken by the employees.
author: Valerie O.

description: Last night we dined at this restaurant,  and the staff was responsive and the service was good.  However, I ordered linguine and clams, and I was very disappointed.  The clams were a bit large and the pasta was very bland.   My husband had lasagna and I thought it tasted much better than my dish.
author: L B.

description:
Really neat menu, split into two parts "earth" and "sea". We didn't try any of the seafood, but the selection was impressive. Also a nice wine list if that's your thing. The decor and service were both excellent. Nice high ceilings, comfortable atmosphere. This place would be great for groups of 6-10 people. Our food came out promptly, and the wait staff came to our table several times to check on us.

The food we had wasn't worthy of 5 stars in my book, but was still quite good. We tried the Caesar salad, stuffed veal, and lamb ragout. My only real criticism is that all three of these dishes had too much cheese. The salad had big chunks of cheese, and the stuffed veal was covered in a pretty cheesy sauce, and the stuffing itself was, well, you guessed it.

I would probably come again though --- especially if I'm with a group. The service and ambiance were great, and the other diners in the restaurant looked to be having a great time!
author: Laurent L.

description:
I usually don't notice or comment on the service at restaurants since I mostly care about the quality of the food. However, this restaurant was remarkable in terms of its service. I came here for my birthday for a surprise celebration dinner. The waiter who was serving the people next to us dropped a glass of red wine and it splashed on my favorite white coat. I spent most of my dinner in the bathroom trying to wash off my coat. The waiter did not even apologize and he acted extremely haughty and entitled. 

In terms of the food, it was just ok. I don't think that it stands out compared to other Italian restaurants that I've been to. I had the lamb ragout. It was just so-so. I would never return to this restaurant since I had such a poor experience.
author: Kim K.

description:
I thought it was just okay. I liked the atmosphere - it was cozy and intimate - but the food was so-so. 
My friend I shared a warm seafood salad to start. The portion was larger than I expected, and some parts were really good, but the mussels tasted undercooked and fishy. 
I got a the seafood lasagna for the main course. It wasn't what I expected, but it would've still been a solid dish if it wasn't so salty. I couldn't stop drinking water the whole time because all the salt made me so thirsty.
author: Rowena L.

description:
After searching for about a week, I finally found a nice romantic restaurant to go to in SOMA. My Girl Friend and I had went back and forth and we came to the conclusion that La Briciola would be a wonderful experience. We made our reservation 7:30. Unfortunately, on the night of our reservation we were running super late. I called La Briciola and they were very accommodating in changing our reservation to 8:45.

So when we arrived to the restaurant, there was plenty of street parking. After walking inside the restaurant, at first thought was that this was a cozy, yet romantic place. We were seated at our table after a 5 min. wait for them to set-up the table. We  were given our menus and we were conflicted because many of dishes seemed very intriguing by their written descriptions. My GF got white wine and started with an Italian beer. My GF got  Ravioli Con Pomodoro (ricotta, spinach ravioli? and I got the Vitello Alla Valdostana (rolled veal, ham, and fontana cheese with béchamel sauce).

When we got our food, the presentation was very neat and composed. The plates were not too much or too little of portions. I found my dish quite delicious and my GF was very pleased by her meal. We ended our food experience, by splitting the Soufflé al Cioccolato which is a chocolate cake. 

We found this place the perfect place for a quaint romantic dinner or chill place to have a glass of wine. Every customer seemed to be enjoying themselves. The staff was very cool and organized. I highly recommend for couples.
author: Thomas M.

description: This is a very pleasant restaurant, nicely decorated, clean, open space. Very attentive service. Not ridiculously expensive either. My partner had the lasagna which she loved. I had the squid ink spaghetti with seafood and was not overly impressed. Clams, mussels squid and shrimp. I had one clam and one mussel that were only opened a tiny bit, so I put them aside, as I don't like to fool with shellfish if you know what I mean.... Anyway, the pasta and sauce were kind of bland and nothing memorable or special. Nice selection of wines even by the glass.
author: Jamie M.

description:
The food was average at best. Everything was a little too oily and a little under seasoned. The only reason I'm giving it 3 stars is because of the great ambience. Very romantic setting and the servers were beyond nice. That being said, $60 dollars for 2 people without even ordering drinks is much too expensive for the experience. For that price, there are much better alternatives in the city.

San Francisco is one hell of a food town and La Briciola is not competitive in any of the categories that I judge restaurants by.
author: Mat K.

description:
Location is on the shadier side. Keep your eyes OPEN, because it is quite easy to miss the restaurant even though it's right on the street. 

I was rather excited to try La Briciola, but it turned out to be just alright. The service was at par, but the food was mediocre. The vegetable crepe was good and tasted like a pot pie. It's great for sharing, otherwise it's just too rich for one person. 

I tried the sea bass ravioli. I love sea bass, so I was not indecisive in any way. No surprises, nothing to crave for, nothing to come back for, it was just biting into a ravioli with flavorless sea bass. The sauce was very much needed for this dish, and normally I don't seek extra sauce and am okay with bland food. Not this time. 

Complimentary bread & olive oil upon seating. Ambience is dim and serene. I felt like I was eating in the dark-exaggeration.
author: Anna S.

description:
3.5 stars 

Talk about choices. 

La Briciola is an authentic Italian restaurant, you can just tell from their menu. (yes, I was mesmerized by our server's ocean blue eyes on top of his Italian accent) The variety of dishes can make you dizzy with choosing your entree but it's conveniently divided into two sections: food that comes from the land (chicken, vegetarian options, etc) and from the ocean (clams, mussels, etc)  

The trio of polenta is good for sharing: each topping was unique on its own: the first had chicken pate, the second porcini mushrooms and the last had chopped sausage.  The polenta was soft and not too mealy; my fave was surprisingly, the porcini mushroom. It had a nice chunks of well seasoned mushrooms, it could almost pass as thin slices of meat. 

Our warm octopus orzo appetizer had cannellini beans and barley in a lemon-olive oil vinaigrette. It had generous slices of octopus, but not a home run on taste. Especially after we squeezed more lemon on it, the dish ended up being too sour.  

My linguini with fresh clams in a white wine reduction was done al dente and again, generous portion but this was a bit under seasoned. My friend wasn't jumping for joy for his squid ink risotto, but it did have that creamy consistency and big cuts of calamari. 

I was excited seeing profiteroles on the menu but sadly, this was dry. Even with the pool of melted ice cream and chocolate sauce, it was tough to cut. So, if you need dessert, stick with the affogato instead.

The dishes are on the pricier side of things, especially the selections on the seafood menu. Service was professional and efficient which warrants the half star. However, if you're in the neighborhood and have serious pasta cravings, head over to COCO500 instead.
author: Janice C.

description: Cute restaurant, easy to find, good food, veeeeeeeery slow service. Our waiter was charming once he actually came over, but for a lunch in SoMa on a weekday, you have to be able to get people in and out quickly.
author: Barbara S.

description: I had higher hopes. The best things about this place were the staff and the ambiance - Classy establishment for sure, but the food itself was nothing special especially considering the prices.
author: Logan S.

description:
Good service, but definitely not a place to go for lunch.  We ordered two lunch specials: 1.) Mozzarella Panini that was okay, but not worth the $13 price tag. it came with a nice greens salad, and stale french fries.  
2.) Chicken Milanese with Vegetables and potatoes($15).  The sides were nice, but the chicken was hard, dry, and overcooked.  horrible.  The worst i've ever had.  
A word of note: we did go the day after christmas, but that should not matter.
author: S e.

description: Recently had dinner here.  Sampled 5 different pasta dishes.  All were excellent.  Ravioli in Lobster Sauce was delicious - especially the sauce which had a great essence of lobster.  Linguini Vongole was also very well prepared with a generous serving of clams that tasted nice and fresh.  And the gnocchi were soft and fluffy also in a delicious sauce.  I don't know why so many Italian restaurants can't seem to get their gnocchi right (i.e. too dense or doughy).  These guys do.  Oh by the way - their Caesar salad dressing was awesome - on the tangy side, which is how we like it.
author: Lewis C.

description: Slow service, small portions, soupy lasagna. Would not repeat.
author: Kimberly N.

description:
Would you expect an Italian restaurant to smell like Garlic??  Well, this place smelled like mildew.  You would expect to get some Italian flavors in your dish...all you could taste in these dishes was salt!
The service was good though...so for that they get all the stars.
author: Rene G.

description:
It was right under my nose the entire time!!!

Food = 5.0 - I've walked/rode/jogged by this little Italian place for years and never knew what I was missing until this weekend.  The burrata and prosciutto are just as good as anything you would find at A16 in the Marina (without the D-bags in the Marina).  Smooth, silky, a little salty and a lot delicious (the burrata, not the D-bags).  I had the lamb ragu over house-made, hand-cut pasta.  WHOA!  Superb flavor and a perfectly hearty portion.  My carb-filled tummy was happy.  Burp!

Service = 4.5 - The place was pretty busy for a Sunday evening but the two waiters and the one food runner were keeping everyone happy.  Our server was especially polite and came back to check on us without giving off that creepy hovering feeling.  

Atmosphere = 4.5 - This restaurant is not much from the outside but don't judge a book by its cover (CHEEEZE!)  The interior is very cozy and warm.  La Briociola is perfect for a special little dinner.
author: Eddie L.

description: What an unexpected delight! The neighborhood is noisy and sort of industrial and then suddenly you find yourself in front of this small gem. The ambiance is charming, the restaurant is clean and quiet. The menus, both wine and food, are extensive.  Six of us enjoyed every bite of what we ordered from the warm, fresh bread and antipasti plate to the zuppa, insalati, secondi, and finally the delicious and perfectly sized desserts and excellent cappuccinos. The wait staff were very friendly and attentive. We LOVE that they all spoke Italian. What a delightful experience! We'll be back for sure.
author: Helen B.

description: This place is a gem. If you can't get a rez in North Beach, or if you like something a little cozier and quieter, this place is a god send. The food is delicious and authentic; same with the wine. If you're looking for an Italian restaurant in soma, or anywhere in SF, La briciola doesn't disappoint.
author: Daniel O.

description:
This is a nice, neighborhood restaurant with decent Italian food.

I wish I could give this place 3.5 stars as a balance for the fantastic décor and ambiance (5 stars) and okay food (3 stars).  The setting is really nice - cool, modern fixtures and accents, but welcoming with warm earth tones.  The service was good and the staff was friendly.  We first started off with some fried calamari with marinara sauce on the side - this was nice - the calamari wasn't overcooked and the batter added just the right amount of flavor to it - it was perfect for a light appetizer.  My entrée was a saffron risotto with sausage, which was alright...I was expecting just a bit more flavor, but it was still enjoyable.  We ended the meal with a flan (crème caramel), which wasn't really that great.

Overall I'd say the setting is great for a small group or a romantic date (it's fairly quiet) and one can feel very comfortable there.  The food isn't fantastic, but it's good.
author: Ken G.

description:
Had the Tagliolini di mare - the tomato based fish sauce was wonderful.  the sauce had a good fish taste , not like restaurants that simply put a marinara sauce over fish and pasta.

The portion was generous.

Im definitely going back to taste other selections
author: Bob R.

description:
For only 1yr old..what a great find! phenomenal Italian meal. The halibut was light, moist and flavorful! Service warm and gracious and chef, management and servers 
genuine Italians from Italy! affagatto-my favorite dessert! Will be a regular. Live 1 block away. Joined Yelp because I wanted to share this amazing little find!
author: MeeSun B.

description:
Rustic elegance defines La Briciola well.  

Loved the ravioli, lamb ragu, Caesar Salad & puff pastry.  The risotto should have more moisture.  Great staff and the price points were oh so affordable.
author: Cynthia C.

description: This is a quiet little spot just south of the freeway. We were there on a Sunday evening and there was ample parking on the street. The atmosphere inside was very quiet and very much reminded us of Italy. The food was superb. Several said the calamari was the best they ever had. They were very accommodating, as our party of 9 became a party of 11, and they gladly added two chairs and said not a word as the last couple arrived very late. Wine list was excellent and the wait staff was extremely courteous and friendly. It's not a big place, capable of seating no more than about 50, but cozy and authentic.
author: Bill W.

description: I looked at their health inspection history and consistent violations each and every inspection.  I was thinking of going there for dinner but not now!  Yelpers, check out the inspection reports before going to a restaurant...(even if you see a 100 for the latest inspection, you can see the prior reports too)
author: Matt B.

description:
Love this place. Definitely want to keep this place my little secret...but here it is: 

One of the few Italian restaurants I know that offers a whole page dedicated to seafood pasta/ Italian cuisine. Start with the caesar salad! My all time favorites are the crab pot pie and sea bass ravioli in lobster reduction sauce. Salmon farfalle is rich and decadent as well. Definitely hits the spot if you're looking for a hearty and comforting meal on a chilly night.
author: Stine H.

description: I was extremely happy with the service and food serves at La briciola. My gnocchi was perfect and the staff was extremely accommodating to my friend who needed gluten-free options. They were also very knowledgable about their wine list which was a huge plus. Would definitely go back.
author: Vinitha R.

description:
(See pics)

Came here on a Monday to have some happy reunion.

Food wise we had the Calamari grigliati (grilled squids with arugula with chick pea puree) which was good. It's a good palate cleanser with its light taste. And it's beautiful.

We also had Tagliolini di mare that had mussels, clams, calamari, shrimp and proper sweet cherry tomatoes. All were delicious and not with too complex taste. A very hearty dish. We also had Linguine alle vongole that included fresh clams in white wine reduction. It was elegant taste and was also very pleasant.

They only serve full bottles and glasses and no half-bottle, which is quite common in many places. We opted for a couple glasses of white but I don't remember the name other than it was a good pairing.

Service was very good, nice and very friendly.

I like how the small gates open up before going inside to the restaurant. It's a small touch but nice even I do not know if the restaurant owner put them there or just came with it. It's a nice spacious restaurant on an otherwise almost deserted street.
author: T L.

description:
Food is kind of OK, but a bit underwhelming. Solid 3-star
Clean, good service but lacks vibe
author: Sergei B.

description:
Was at La Briciola last night, it should be 6 stars! 
The area is a little funky, but its well worth risking your like!
author: Frank J.

description:
Fantastic food, everything we had was amazing. Lamb chops, lamb ragu with stracietti, roasted baby octopi, chicken pate; all were amazing. This is definitely a top 3 Italian place in San Francisco; would say it belongs up there with Delfina and Cotogna.  

It's a nice place, but the atmosphere is not what makes this place remarkable. If factored in, would say it's more of a 4.5 stars rather than a 5.
author: Ray N.

description: Terrible.. I can't believe people actually think the food is good.. It's mostly young clientele who obviously hadn't had really good Italian food! Very poor service too.
author: Julie B.

description:
the place was great for a nice weekday dinner for two. 
They have some great wine and really good food! A little on the expensive side, but then the food, service and ambiance was worth it.
author: Mrudul B.

description: Came here for lunch and had a fabulous meal! The bread they serve is so tasty (then again, caaaarbs are always tasty). it's soft and warm on the inside and then has a great crunch on the outside. I got the squid ink spaghetti--definitely a must try! So. Gooood!
author: Hwan L.

description:
What a terrific find.  Thank you, yelpers for leading me here.  I'm very particular when it comes to Italian places.  This one exceeded all expectations.  The food, the ambiance, and wait staff were all exceptional!  I had the lamb ragout and my partner had the sea bass ravioli.  Fantastic flavors.  Also enjoyed the spinach salad and the wine selection.  

Such an unexpected experience in SOMA.  I truly felt transported to Italy once inside. 

Complimenti, Giovanni and Alessandro!
author: Kim E.

description: This restaurant was really awesome! Friendly service, warm environment, great timing, lovely space, & PHENOMENAL food! Our server did not hover, which I always appreciate. I felt like I was being welcomed into somebody's home and it truly tasted like it. For the first time I tasted REAL Italian food. In fact, the freshest food I've had in a really long time. This place converted me into a spinach salad person! I HATE SPINACH. I highly recommend this restaurant! GO
author: Elizabeth P.

description: We went here for a birthday dinner last week and had another awesome experience!  I can't say enough good things about the way the staff treats us every time we go here.  At the end of our meal they brought out a delicious combination made up of all their desserts in one plate.  Spectabulastic!  In particular, Giovanni is awesome!  Be sure to request him if you go and you'll have a blast!
author: Luke L.

description: It's a nice quiet spot. Great wine selections and there is never a wait. It's ideal for an italian date night
author: Dane H.

description:
Ginger Broty just moved to town, which meant two things: 1. we were using Momma D.'s credit card for dinner (sweet) and 2. I needed to put him in a relaxed, semi formal environment to make sure Ginger Broty and I kept our convo PC. 

I loved this place from the last time I came, and knew Ginger Broty would love it too. 

I figured out which dish would be most likely to be vegan, and ordered it. And IT WAS. The tagliatelle with porcine mushrooms, truffle oil, and black truffles appears to be (and tastes) vegan! YAY! Fresh house made pasta in the perfect portion and delicious truffle oil makes me a happy vegan. 

Ginger Broty order the gnocchi with spinach and cheese and scraped the bowl with bread to get all the sauce. 

Seriously a high quality nice dinner in a relaxed environment. Love it.
author: Emily D.

description:
Not a good overall experience. Very quiet restaurant - there were only 2 other diners. Ceaser salad came from a jar; croutons were cold and stale. Bread basket unimpressive. Ravioli was fine, but after delivered we never saw the server again until we were done and it was time to go. 

Thera are so many good Italian restaurants in SF, no need to go here.
author: Brian H.

description: Oh the bread w olive oil and tapenade was wow. ESP whence warm. The Caesar salad and calamari were perfectly executed. The filet and seafood lasagna were both very solid. Love the inclusion of truffle and fontina. A keeper!
author: Andrew K.

description:
My friend and I were craving Italian and looking for a place that was just a walk away in SOMA. We luckily found La Briciola by doing a quick Yelp search and I'm glad we decided to do bar seating instead of simply leaving. 

We ordered calamari, clam linguine, and seafood lasagna and were not disappointed! Our seafood was so fresh and everything tasted great. The portions were also quite large. 

The waiters were also super nice and friendly. I felt like I was in a really authentic Italian restaurant especially since all the waiters could speak Italian. 

Definitely putting this on the list of restaurants to come back to. Quaint, quiet, friendly, and cheap (for the city)!
author: Shannon W.

description: This is a great restaurant.  The food is very good and fresh.  Be sure to check out the specials.  It's quiet and intimate but also holds large groups easily.
author: J. D.

description:
3.5 stars for this place.

We found plenty of parking around this Italian restaurant. 

The setting was intimate but the service was a bit slow and could be easily improved.

The food was OK but nothing outstanding or that would make you happy enough to come back.
author: John D.

description: Really great service and lovely ambiance. Only reason why I'm giving this 4 stars instead of 5 is because the handcut pasta with lamb ragu was a bit too dense for my taste, although very tasty! I'd like to come back and try the squid ink spaghetti or sea bass ravioli.
author: Catherine U.

description:
Such a sweet little Italian restaurant! 

I was just in Italy about a month ago for my honeymoon and boy did the food and service bring me back to Italia! 

I came here last Saturday for a birthday dinner that I planned for my besties and the staff at La Briciola were extremely accomodating from the start. Basically, I was able to reserve seating for 25 people without leaving my credit card information or having to spend a food/drink minimum!  

I had the lamb ragu w/ hand made pasta and I did enjoy it very much, perfect portion size too. I've noticed the ragu is commonly used in Italy as they use a ragu base for their lasanga as well. Oh and I can't forget about their cheese...they freshly grade it over your pasta...YUM!
author: TuUyen L.

description:
Awesome... as good as it gets!

I love some good Italian food, and in SF there are plenty of places.  I think I have reviewed 2 so far, 1 really good (Perbacco) and 1 really horrible (Poesia).  La Briciola knocked my socks off.

I have walked passed this restaurant several times, but it is in the opposite direction from where I live if we are going out into the city, so it seems silly to go here before we go out, because that would be backtracking.  They have Burrata on the menu (which I recently discovered in SF) and knew that it would be a good restaurant.  Other Yelp reviews have been pretty positive as well.

Getting home late one night from work, we were not going out to the city so we decided to go out.  Downstairs from us is Pazzia (another Italian restaurant) and we had decided on there.  As we approached, they were clearly in the weeds, so we abandoned ship, and turned to trusty Open table.  They had room available at La Briciola 6 minutes from now, and that would be the amount of time to walk down 3rd.

As we walked in, there were a couple of large tables sat, some small parties too, but plenty of seating.  It was not overly crowded and it didn't look like getting our food would be a problem.

Upon sitting we were quickly greeted, and delivered the most amazing crusty and soft at the same time, still warm, Italian bread, served with a side of olive oil that had a kalamata tapenade in the bottom.  Omg delicious.  My husband and I devoured it. They cleared the basket and brought out a second round, which was really nice and un-expected.

We started with a Caesar salad to split and the Burrata.  We were quickly informed the Burrata was out for the night, so we went with the Salumi platter (am I destined to not have Burrata? see my Poesia review).  The Caesar arrived and they had already split it for us, which was really nice.  Nice crunchy Romaine, a lemony garlicky dressing, nice cheese on top and delicious crunchy croutons, Everything a good Caesar should be.

The Salumi platter (small) was fantastic.  Every type of cured salty meat I love.  Bresola, Speck, Prosciutto, and Salami. All top notch.  It was served with a small side of marinated veggies and olives.  Also came with delicious thin bread sticks.  We cleaned the plate and the side of veggies and olives was perfect for us, I love olives, and my husband love roasted bell peppers.

For my entree I went with the Lamb ragu and pasta.  WOW.  I thought the short rib ragu at Perbacco was great, this however was fantastic.  The portion was huge, enough for an entree or if you were doing a typical 4 course Italian dinner, split this. The pasta was so fresh, totally house made, cooked perfect, came out steaming with the most delicate and complex lamb ragu on  top.  The fresh shaved Romano cheese was the perfect topping and my glass of Barbera wine was the perfect compliment.   I ate every bite!

My husband got the linguini and clams (the entree he was craving on Christmas night that never happened). The portion was more than generous, it was HUGE.  Tons of pasta, a dozen super fresh and well cooked clams, and the best white wine-garlic-butter sauce.  He couldn't finish it all.  If you get this, make sure you have some of the bread left over to mop up some of the sauce.

We went with dessert, even though we were pretty full.  Every dessert on the menu I would have done, but I wanted something a little lighter, so we went with the Affogato.  Two scoops of the creamiest vanilla gelato, and a side of hot espresso to pour over the top.  Two small Pirouette cookies were served with it.

The price was spot on, not too expensive, but by no means cheap.  But for 2 entrees, 2 appetizers, a dessert, 3 glasses of wine, a diet coke (fountain by the way, and I assume free refills, but never had to get it) and an espresso, we made it out for pretty reasonable. 

Our server was fantastic too.  Not too obtrusive, there where we needed him, and the pace of dinner was perfect.  He also was great with the recommendations for entrees and wine.  I could tell he had passion for the food and wine and was excited with our choices.   

The atmosphere is perfect, really quaint inside, you could have a nice dinner for two, a romantic night out, a get together with friends or a business meal here.  Cannot wait to go back and try more!
author: David P.

description:
Went here on a night when there was a conference in town, and it was packed for a Thursday night. The service was good and the pastas were handmade. Because they were handmade, they weren't quite al dente, but fresh pasta does cook fast.

Everything tasted like pure Italian. There was nothing new and no strange flavors, but everything tasted good and like what you'd have in Italy.  Is it an exciting place where it'll change your life?  No, it's a good solid Italian restaurant where you could be a regular visitor and count on good solid Italian comfort food.
author: Paula N.

description:
The food? -- Excellent!
The service? -- Wonderful!
The overall experience? -- Sublime!

I've been here three times. First, solo. Walk-in single diners are not often treated as well as I was. The service was far beyond my expectations.

I was treated royally. A mistake I had made in ordering was instantly removed, and no charges appeared on the bill for my mis-ordering.

Not a trace of condescension, a wonderful meal.

Then I visited with a friend. It was perfect, as before.

Then with another couple. Again, superlative.

3 perfects for 3 visits = 5 stars
author: Stephen D.

description:
Made reservations for a group of 14 on NYE, and I was really nervous if my friends would like the food and if the service would be good. And I have to say from our dinning experience, I am really impressed with this restaurant! 

1. The food was delicious! Everyone gobbled up their food
2. Affordable!! 
3. Diverse range of dishes to please everyone
4. Great service! Server was very friendly, polite and accommodating, water cups were never empty, and the bread basket was always full.
5. Classy atmosphere, also very homey feeling
author: Pearl L.

description:
I had the seabass filled ravioli in the lobster reduction sauce. Wasn't too thrilled on it.  The sauce was watery. The ravioli was a bit bland. It was ok but nothing stood out. I'll probably give it another shot but definitely not on the ravioli.

They brought out bruschetta as the free appetizer for mentioning yelp. That was good!
author: Helen V.

description:
As much as I have a hard time giving the highest marks possible on any survey, I can't see fit to give anything less than that with at least the dish I enjoyed at La Briciola.  

The appetizers set a great tone the meal and while I enjoyed them I found myself fixated on the lemonade.  I normally order lemonade as I don't drink alcohol and their rendition is amazing.  I asked the waiter to make a recommendation with seafood and he suggested the lasagna which was layered with lobster, scallop, and sea bass with an amazing bechamel and great pasta.  I had never eaten seafood lasagna and frankly didn't believe that it would be any good, although I took the leap.  Good doesn't do the dish justice, It was so enjoyable that I doubt I'll  be able to force myself to order something different the next time I visit.  

The space is cozy, the service is on the money, and the bathrooms are clean.
author: Freddie C.

description: Charming dining room - small and intimate setting.  The food is well made and the staff is quite friendly.  I tried the bolognese - I've had better but it was definitely worth ordering.  I came up from San Jose to have dinner when I dined at La Briciola - it's great to have a good Italian option in SoMa when I generally don't care to make my way up to a place like North Beach where the historically good Italian options can be found.
author: Joseph F.

description:
After reading rave reviews from other yelpers, I was super excited to try this place out. There are few things in the world I love more that great Italian food. 

When I got there, I was seated immediately and I chose a nice table tucked in a nook by the door. 

The server was attentive at the start but it seemed the second we said, "just water", I wondered if the attentiveness faded just a tad. 

We ordered a salad (insalata del campo) and the salmon starter. Those came promptly. The salad was ample and I would recommend ordering to share as it was a LOT of arugula. It was fresh and tasty. My friend inhaled her salmon and we waited for our server. At this point, granted I still had a mountain of arugula still on my plate, our server was nowhere to be found. No one came by to check in to see how we were doing, and finally I had to flag the busboy down to get my salad to go. 

From the arrival of our salads, we must have waited an additional 30-45 minutes before we even asked after our pasta. The restaurant wasn't busy and I didn't think it took that long to prepare the lamb ragu since it usually involves ladling the already stewing sauce onto fresh pasta that took 7-9 minutes tops to cook. 

The lamb ragu was as mentioned on this page, delicious and since they knew we were sharing 2 pastas, they split the portions for us, which was sweet. 

The linguine with clams was also delicious with just the right amount of sauce. 

As we were both in a rush we skipped dessert. 

The food is excellent but the service truly could be better.
author: Karen K.

description: Came here for dinner last night with the wife.  The sea bass ravioli was ok, slightly underwhelmed.  But had one of the very best spaghetti (or was it linguine) with clams that I've tried outside of Italy.  Will definitely be going back and getting this every time.
author: Andy W.

description:
Small italian restaurant located somewhere you can just drive by and miss.
I felt under dressed when i showed up in jeans and hiking boots with a leather jacket. I thought my service will be all bad, but guess what. I was wrong. service was good. no one that i noticed looked my way. the food was pretty good. only remember the rack of lamb. since it was pretty good. and a cup of syrah. 
Think it might be nice place for a date where you want to actually hear one another.
author: Albert W.

description:
Definitely had a wonderful time here at La Briciola. And it all started with warm delicious bread! Its got to be warm and you know you're in for a good meal.
Our server, Johnny, was fabulous handling a rowdy table of 12 adults (with 6 bottles of wine guzzled down). We shared a whole bunch of appetizers - all of which were delicious - the grilled squid was probably one of the best dishes I've ever had at a restaurant. The octopus and warm seafood salad was amazing too.
I also ordered the seafood cioppino which was pretty good - but for $26 bucks I was expecting a lil more bang. 
All in all great experience, it is expensive but it is a nice, well-managed, well ran restaurant in downtown SF. Can't really dock them too much for that. And they have my favorite kind of Moscato d'Asti! 
Come here, you'll be happy you did.
author: S. M.

description:
fancier $$. (there needs to be a middle category between $$ and $$$). Very courteous servers (they moved us from near the door on a blustery sf evening to further into the restaurant)
Food is great. Sorry we po' and couldn't get appetizers, drinks or dessert.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I would probably give this place more like 4.5 stars if I could. First off, the staff is very nice and attentive. They always give good recommendations. We've eaten there a few times. It's a total hole in the wall and right by our place, so I love the convenience. 

Rabbit stew- Excellent and I'm not a huge rabbit fan. My husband loved this.
Warm Octopus- Very good, great flavor with the beans and barley
Lobster ravioli- just ok, I probably wouldn't get this again
Pan- seared tuna- great flavor but a little dry
Good wine selection

I can always count on being full and happy when I leave here, we'll be back.
author: Tami W.

description:
At first, I thought I was walking into a $$$$ restaurant due to the look and feel of the tables and the friendly greetings the staff give when first entering.  After checking my Yelp app on my iPhone did I realize this is only a $$.  Hmmm, wouldn't that be a great way to impress your date by taking him/her to a fancy looking Italian restaurant with great food and at the same time, doesn't burn a hole in your wallet.

La Briciola has a good selection of salads, appetizers, and main entrees.  Today, I opted for their complimentary bread with olive oil and real olive chunks and their "Straccietti al ragú di agnello".  The "Straccietti al ragú di agnello" is hand cut noodles which looks like moebius strips (basically long rectangular shaped noodles), with lamb ragu.  What is lamb ragu?  I'm not sure but it looked grounded up and it was with this brown sauce that covered all of the noodles.  Only one word describes the taste: FANTASTIC.  If you're afraid of eating lamb because of it's gamey taste, you won't have to worry since the sauce masks that gameyness.
author: Ronald L.

description: I was traveling on business so sat at the bar. The service was great and my appetizer (burrata salad) came up quickly. I ordered a pasta special and this took a little longer to come out which I was happy about because I didn't want to rush right into the main course. The pasta was homemade and very fresh. I would definitely go back.
author: Cherylene M.

description: I came here once in a group of 5, it was easy to reserve, the ambiance allowed enough privacy for a conversation, the tables were separated enough and it was quiet. The food was excellent, especially the lasagna daly special.
author: Marina R.

description:
La Briciola. Absolutely a must.  Owned by Italians, they know how to cook!
The service was attentive and the server offered great suggestions.
We had the Polpo con tagiolini, which were flavorful and tender.
The Lasagna di Mare which our waiter recommended was the best ever, creamy, tender and full of fish.  The Straccietti al ragu di agnello was exquisite.
The whole experience was fantastic.  Great food at a fair price in San Francisco.
We will be returning.  Oh and by the way, the profiteroles were delicious too!
author: Lorraine B.

description:
Went here last weekend for dinner. The service was great. Our waiter was very friendly and patient with our group. The ambiance was pleasant. The restaurant is not too big, which I was fan of. The food overall was pretty good as well. My bf had the Rabbit and he thought it was great. I had the seafood pasta with tomatoes. I enjoyed my dish as well, but it could have used a little more flavor. The appetizers were yummy as well. The grilled octopus was DELISH and a must try. We also enjoyed the platter w/ the Prosciutto. Good portion size and good cuts of a select variety of meats. My dad had the lamp shank which he seemed to enjoy and top notch as well. The desserts were typical Italian type desserts. I wasn't too blown away, but they were good as well. 

Overall I would recommend La Briciola. The price was not bad, and you get a lot of food. The atmosphere was cozy, good for couples, families or groups. Lots of street parking available as well.
author: Jen L.

description:
I'm always a bit nervous when meeting OOT friends at a restaurant. Will it live up to the (my) hype? Have my taste buds changed after four years in the Bay Area? Will my friends recognize the level of effort put into the menu and each dish? Basically, I feel like my move to SF is up for review during these dinners. And with this dinner, I took a big risk. 

My friend is second-generation Italian and almost never eats Italian food outside the home because it rarely meets the expectations of himself and his wife. They're really nice but have very high standards, especially for Italian food. He also lived in SF for several years and brought his family for a vacation.  Their hotel near Moscone was only about 5 blocks away and the prices at La Briciola are reasonable, especially for quality food. 

The main reason I felt good (pretty...pretty...pretty good) about the recommendation was that the executive chef is Italian, and the servers on both of my visits have been Italian. My friend and his wife really enjoyed the restaurant - what a relief! Everyone loved their meals and our waiter allowed us to catch up over a couple hours. 

La Briciola's pace of service could feel too leisurely if your brain isn't reset to European dining time. You won't feel rushed, especially with the bill. Hopefully this info will allow you to enjoy your next visit a bit more. 

The food here is great; the menu is pretty big for a not-very-big place. I ate the minestrone and stewed rabbit, both of which very good. The minestrone even smelled amazing, and my friend wished he'd ordered it. I couldn't believe how good the rabbit tasted. 

We all shared the fried calamari: light breading, and the squid was cooked just right. My friends ate salads, which they said were very fresh, as well as the lamb ragu and halibut. They were incredibly kind to pick up the whole tab and I felt even better that I'd chosen a restaurant with more reasonable prices for high-quality food.
author: Mike H.

description:
Well. I *want* to like this restaurant.  A pleasant experience, great food, reasonably priced...

... and then I went and left my hat behind.

I realized I had it under my seat and forgot it as I left. I called about 30 minutes later and they assured me it would be put aside. Now, on my hat was a one-of-a-kind pin that had no real value other than personally to me. When I went back the next day to get it, I found to my dismay that while my hat was intact, the pin was nowhere to be found.

There is no way it could have fallen off and I am positive someone saw the pin and helped themselves to it.

I have been back twice and have been met with a couple of shrugs, despite my explanation of its value to me.

So. Come for the food... just make sure you bring your stuff with you when you leave.
author: Jordan W.

description:
Good food and good service.

Meat dishes cooked properly, which many dont for whatever reason.

pasta was good and fresh.
author: Dan B.

description: Food, service and ambiance are nothing but perfect! From the welcome to the complimentary cookies with the delicious espresso. Definitely coming back!!!
author: M D.

description:
Let me preface this review by saying that this was my first real meal after a week of being on a liquid diet due to a very painful tooth extraction. You have to understand...if all you've been putting into your body is smoothies and Vicodin for 7 straight days, ANY form of solid food should be freaking amazing to you.

I decided to give La Briciola the honors of bringing me back to culinary nirvana after my uncalled-for hiatus in consuming food (because HUNDREDS OF YELPERS SAID IT WAS GOOD). And all I can say after the meal is, "Shit, I should have had Jamba Juice."

Anyhoo, opted for the seabass ravioli and lamb ragu...because like I said, HUNDREDS OF YELPERS SAID IT WAS GOOD. Bastards...ya'll were wrong. Halfway through my meal, I was telling myself that a meal at the Olive Garden would have been much more enjoyable. The dish was bland and really wasn't all that special.

Uh, to end this on a high note...the bread was warm and good...
author: Blenda L.

description:
What a charming little place in SOMA.  I have struggled to find really good neighborhood places in SOMA, but this place was a solid italian place with a great menu.  

There are ample options for both seafood and food from the land.  I tried a little of both with the warm octopus salad and the straccietti with the lamb ragu.  The octopus was very fresh but a bit underseasoned.  Nothing that a little S&P cant solve.  The lamb ragu had very good flavor--rich with lamb taste finishing with a refeshing tartness of the tomato sauce.  The shaved cheese on the top added a fantastic savory kick as well.  My only beef with the dish was that the pasta was a bit overcooked.
