Dessert was creame caramel.  It was a well executed flan.  Nothing extraordinary but solid.  The coffee was very very good as well.  

I would really really love to give this place four stars since I am totally going back and had a great experience with the food, service and the atmosphere.  Because of the slight misses with basic things like seasoning of the octopus and not cooking the pasta al dente, I can only give it 3 stars for now.  My friend also had a slight miss on her pasta (seabass ravioli) and the appetizer (buffalo mozzerella).  

The prices are very reasonable for any neighborhood, so it is totally worth checking out for yourself.
author: Scott C.

description: A nice, leisurely lunch near the Moscone Center. I had a plate of tortellini al gorgonzola - the gorgonzola sauce was very, very good but the tortellini was only ok. Their bread was also quite good. Reasonably priced, too. Definitely a good alternative to some of the crappy restaurants right around the convention center.
author: Deb G.

description: Dim light, great for date:)
author: Chuhan Z.

description:
Love this place. 5 stars all the way.  

We skipped the antipasto -- my husband had the spinach salad with goat cheese and candied nuts, followed by a huge seafood stew a lot like a cioppino.  I had an amazing (homemade?) linguine with mushrooms, followed by the grilled seafood second course.  I ordered this much food because yelpers had complained about portion sizes.  I am here to tell you that those yelpers are wrong.  I took home most of my "seconde" and my husband and i split it for dinner the next day.  That's how much food there was.  

We asked our incredibly charming waiter for a recommendation on a white wine, and he recommended an Italian varietal that I had never had before.  It was really excellent, just amazing flavors.  Big fan.  Wish I could remember the name. 

For dessert we split the tiramisu and a glass of porto.  We were in sugar, cream, and espresso heaven.  

Definitely in love with La Briciola.  Also -- such a charming space!  I had no idea it went so far back, and the small bar (with 4 barstools) is also very cute.
author: Tasha D.

description: I really like Italian food and I randomly found this small place in soma. I came here with a bunch of friends and we tried all different types of pastas. Everyone really liked their food =)
author: Annie Z.

description: Great service -the kind you get when everyone is a part of the family and  really cares about their product. Nice wines, lovely house made pastas, GREAT burrata. An easy walk from Moscone Center and out of the crush --one block gets a little grimy on the way but lots of people around.
author: Michele M.

description:
3.5 starts, which I nicely rounded up to 4. I went here this past Saturday to celebrate my sisters birthday. I made reservations via opentable and got the 30% off deal through them, so was excited for that! When I got there I gave my name, and explained I made reservations through opentable. I also added a note explaining it was my sisters birthday and to please bring out a dessert with a candle. 
 Dinner was excellent, service was great as well as the food, BUT when it came time for dessert, they dropped off dessert menu's....no dessert with a candle like I had asked for. At that point I had to ask my sister if she wanted dessert, instead of surprising her like I had originally planned.
When the bill came out, the 30% discount was not applied to it either. I had to go back and get it changed, which at that point, it was obvious they had not checked my reservation. If they had they would've noticed it was 30% off and it was in celebration of my sister's birthday. I would still go back since the place is cute, and the food is great as well, but hopefully next time they take the time to check reservations and notes added, would've made it a flawless night!
author: Erica O.

description:
Came here for a girlfriends birthday and not only was the food super good but the service was also amazing. 

We called for reservations at 5:15 but needed to come a little later and with no problem they changed it to 5:30 for us. We sat down and they gave us bread with an olive oil with chunks of olives on the bottom for sauce. Both were amazing and they kept refilling our bread without us asking whenever we finished a basket! Super good service. 

-I got the Tagliatelle ai porcini e tartufo which was pasta with wild porcini, black truffles, and white truffle oil. The noodles were thick and chewy which went along superb with the mushroom sauce. I had never tasted a sauce like this before. If you really love mushrooms you have to try this dish. 
-My boyfriend got the Linguine alle vongole which had fresh clams with a white wine reduction. This dish was amazing. The sauce was so tasty and when the bread was dipped inside it was oh so good. 
-My friend got the Grigliata mista di pesce with grilled calamari, shrimp, salmon, and swordfish. I had never tasted seafood so good before. This dish was literally amazing. 

They gave the birthday girl a tiramisu cake also. A big piece and it was amazing tiramisu. The atmosphere is nice with candles at each table with super friendly Italian service. Come and try it out and you won't regret it!
author: Audrey C.

description: My husband and I went for our Thanks Giving dinner and made our reservation through Open Table. The place was pretty full, glad we made reservations. We were immediately taken to a cozy table inside. We ordered the Burrata mozzarella for Antipasti. It was excellent! It was an assortment of butter cheese, Parma prosciutto, cherry tomatoes and arugala. The restaurant gave us house bread which went very well with the cheese, just melted in our mouth. My husband ordered the Agnello al Brunello (rack of lamb), which was alright. I ordered the Rombo all'isolana (baked halibut, fresh tomato sauce, olives, sliced potatoes). The halibut was so so good! I have rarely had fish made so well. The house bread again with the tomato sauce was excellent. The sauce was more like a light broth which was pipping hot. The waiter and the bus waiter were very polite and nice. For the second helping of bread when I said no, they suggested keeping it on my table so that I could have it with my fish and I am glad they did, because I polished it! Since we ate so much bread and carbs, we passed on the desert.  It was a perfect Thanks Giving meal! A bit on the higher end but totally worth it.
author: Pakhi P.

description:
Outstanding!
Authentic Italian food in a romantic setting.
Natural friendly staff, good menu selection  elegantly prepared great tasting food.
Really fantastic.
Halibut was so great I want to come back for breakfast :)
Salmon + pasta was a little intense at first but still wonderful.
Grilled calamari just about sent us on a mental trip back to Italy :)
author: Mike V.

description:
I was really impressed with this restaurant.  It's along a very unassuming block, but when you walk in, it is tastefully decorated with high ceilings and beautiful lighting.  We were fortunate to find street parking close by, but there is also paid parking right at the nearest cross street.

Some family friends had made a reservation for 5pm with an employee on Saturday and apparently walked away before someone could correct them that the kitchen didn't really open until 5:30pm.  We arrived today at 5pm, knocked on the door, explained the situation, and the waiter ran back to inform the chef and let us in early to accomodate our early reservation.

The food here is fantastic!  There are multiple vegetarian options which is great, and the kitchen is more than willing to work with you to make a dish how you would like it.  They will substitute, etc, to customize it for you.  I had the spinach salad and the spinach and cheese gnocchi which were both divine.  My husband had the other gnocchi dish, which I tasted and also adored.  The appetizer bread is served with an olive spread which is also delicious.  The tiramisu was mouthwatering too.

The wait staff was very attentive to our needs and never let a glass fall below 1/3 full.

I would definitely come back here.  It is worth the trip!
author: Danielle P.

description:
Always love going here. They are always able to accommodate us last minute and we are usually a group of 10 or more. The food is great and they have a decent wine selection. The service is great.

This is our new favorite place for lunch.
author: Kish K.

description: Their Squid Ink Risotto is unforgettably delicious.  Also, it turns your teeth black so make sure you smile your beautiful smile at the end of your date.  Then you'll be unforgettable.  ;)
author: Alice L.

description: Authentic Italian food :). Great service + homely dishes.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Great ambience, friendly service, delicious Italian food. Is there anything else that needs to be said?

OK, a bit more detail. Their menu is split into two sections "From the Earth" (vegetables, meat, mushrooms, etc) and "From the Ocean" (seafood), so it's easy to glance through and figure out what you want.  I ordered the Tagliolini di mare. The cherry-tomato sauce was flavorful but light and not overwhelming.   Definitely a place I would return to.
author: Ti Z.

description: This place is not actually good. i made a reservation for 2 after valentines day and as soon as we get there they were able to sit us. The waiter took forever to come and as ask what drink do i want and come back after 30mins. After 30 mins we got our water and ask for our order and waited for almost an hour for our food. To wrap it up its like 2 hours to eat here with their food which are verey pricy!
author: Patrick D.

description: This is a genuine Italian place. The food is really good and there is a lot to choose from, which is important to me. The Guys who served us were really nice and the owner even gave us an extra glass of wine. If you're looking for a place to have date night or just a yummy place to go with your girls, this place is perfect.
author: Maria W.

description:
4 stars for great value for money.  For this price, this is a great deal for good quality Italian food in BIG portions!  

The menu is nicely divided into "Earth" and "Ocean".  I personally like their seafood dishes slightly better than the meat dishes. 
I like the Warm Octopus and the Grilled Squid starters.
For main course, the Seabass Ravioli is really awesome... comes with a lobster reduction that you want to lick every last drop of.  (The more civilized way would be to ask for more bread.)

On the "Earth" side of things, both the Lamb Ragu and the Tagliatelle with porcini and truffle oil are great.  But I would still go back for the Seabass Ravioli.

Desserts - congratulations if you can get through a starter and main course and still have room for dessert.  You should think about entering into competitive eating.  But anyway, desserts are fairly classic.  I've had the tiramisu and profiteroles.  Both are very well-executed.

All in, I like La Briciola as a great neighborhood Italian.  You won't find very fancy creative dishes here, but the food is good, the atmosphere is casual, and the food and wine are priced reasonably.  Sure, I think Flour + Water has better and more inventive dishes, but they are half the size and cost just as much, not to mention the impossibility of getting a reservation.
author: Thomas L.

description: My favorite Italian Restaurant in the city. Amazing service, ALWAYS. I went for the first time for my birthday dinner and every dish ordered by all 5 of us was delicious! We were blown away at how much we each really enjoyed everything. The atmosphere is what really sets it apart. Dim lighting with an intimate feel. I love this place.
author: Trang N.

description:
I really wanted to love this place but I was let down (a little bit).

Pros:
-Very cute/cozy restaurant with a very friendly husband/wife serving team.
-Large menu variety (lots of options for the pescetarian bf, lots of pastas yay!)

Cons:
-None of the dishes wowed me (everything was tasty but nothing was OMG; caesar salad, arugula salad, porcini/truffle pasta, gnocchi, and baked halibut)
author: Priscilla T.

description: Despite a reservation a month in advance, they put us by the door and kitchen, we could not hear anything, my noodles were gooey and the lead guy was not very friendly. The waiter was good, dessert delicious, but I expected to be treated with respect.
author: Leigh B.

description:
Parking is easy, and the servers are very friendly. The menu is appealing too. Overall, the interior is pleasant, though a little cool.

We found the fresh pasta a little thick and tough overall. The mushroom pasta was not as flavorful as we expected. The ravioli with lobster reduction was very tasty and filled with delicious fish, but the pasta was a little tough. The beef lasagna was light and flavorful, however. The grilled and fried calamari were both very good. 

Overall, we enjoyed the experience but felt the food was not as good as we hoped.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
It's a lot further from market and 3rd, seeing Bryant I should have known better but oh well..a bit of a work out before eating! 

Maybe that's why the girl ignored me when I first walked in cos it was windy and I was in a hurry to get there by my 7 o'clock reservation--either way a few moments later the guy approaches me and brings me to my table where my friend was already seated. Score.

Restaurant wasn't super busy so that guy, our waiter, was attentive and helpful, ordered two appetizers and two pastas and it wasn't mouth watering omg good but it was good enough to warrant the price..after the 30% discount from savored.

a) they never brought the bill until we asked meaning they didn't make us feel like hurry your arse up and b) they did come back to check on us periodically and c) allowed me and my friend to chat extensively before and of course during as well as after our meal 

Was worth giving an extra twenty

Will I be back? Probably not. The food wasn't amazingly awesome omg I would trek back all the way out here good--maybe if the area picks up more
author: Whitne Y.

description:
My family decided at 11am that they needed dinner reservations in the city for my dad and brother's birthday. THAT NIGHT. THE WEEKEND BEFORE CHRISTMAS. FOR SEVEN PEOPLE. WITHIN WALKING DISTANCE OF UNION SQUARE.  I tried many many places, but thankfully La Briciola came through! 

We arrived at 8 for our 815 reservation and waited at the bar area for about 30 minutes before we were seated at 830.

The bread they brought out before the meal was warm, fresh, and delicious!  We also ordered a great bottle of Italian Chianti before our meal.

My dad had the salmon, and couldn't stop talking about how great it was.  My mother had the spinach and ricotta ravioli.  My brother had a plate with salmon, swordfish, shrimp, and calamari which was probably the best dish of the night.  Our friends had the stewed rabbit (loved it), the spinach salad, bruschetta, and a few other appetizers as entrees.  I chose the orechiette with sausage-- was delicious! but didn't agree with me the next day (not the fault of the restaurant-- i have a sensitive stomach).  

For dessert, they brought my dad a dessert with a candle (gelato with strawberries) and my brother a tiramisu with a candle and a happy birthday song for each :)  The waiter also brought us a round of sweet dessert wine on the house.  

Overall, everyone loved La Briciola!  The service was warm and personal, and the food was on point.  The menu was a little price-y, but not overly so.  Our friends were excited to bring their daughter (currently living in Italy) to La Briciola ASAP.  My parents even went back the next night to pick up a few gift certificates!
author: Melissa H.

description:
Our work came here for lunch mid week and were the only customers, so of course, our service was fantastic. The location is a bit off-putting, since there are two other sketchy Asian food restaurants with bawdy tarps and signs right next door, but once inside you feel as if you're in Noe Valley settling in for a nice lunch. 

Olive puree with olive oil for a spread on their bread is killer. We had to ask for more. Had a proscuitto and mozzarella panini with a salad and fries from their lunch menu, which was filling and done well, but I can safely say go for the chicken! My two co-workers had to fight off my darting fork to snatch pieces, which was char grilled and unbelievably tasty!
author: Alita M.

description:
This is the perfect little italian restaurant.  Great food, fresh made pasta, good prices, great wait-staff.  The menu is simple and they do everything on this well rounded menu very well.

I highly recommend bricciola.
author: Zack M.

description:
La Bricola is a cute Italian place in SOMA. It's one of the few decent dinner locations in the local area. However, I would not drive all the way out there for a meal (north beach has much better places). 

Great service and ambiance for a quiet evening with a special someone. They have two tables up front for two that allow you to look out. They accommodate groups quite well as well, having a decent amount of space to piece together tables. The service is timely and the staff is friendly and attentive. 

The dishes are of top-notch quality as well, though the portion is quite small. Their carpaccio and tagliere are worth a try. For the primi, I am a fan of the any Gnocchi and squid ink risotto. The gnocchis are really soft and well flavored. The squid ink risotto is delicious. They also have a lasagna de mare that's worth trying. Then for secondi, the swordfish, Caciucco di viareggio, and the T-bond steak are my tops. Finally, for dessert, they have the normal range of Italian sweets: Souffle, tiramisu, and panna cotta are my go-tos for any Italian place they they do not disappoint. 

GIven their small portions, you are actually okay ordering 4 courses. However, the bill does rack up very quickly, particularly if wine is involved. (I'm a fan of their Chianti's). Great place for an intimate celebration or a group dinner when money's not the top concern and folks are willing to dish out a bit more for great service, ambiance, and Italian food outside of north beach!
author: Yue Z.

description:
Excellent place for people who have money to take their dates. I've been here three times with my guardians and I just enjoy the atmosphere and the food. It's comfortable and the portions are just perfect.

The bread they serve is the best bread I have ever had in my life; really delightful. The waiter recommended me a nice Italian lemonade or something to that extent but whatever he recommended was really good. I will be coming back here for more pasta and Italian food.
author: Bryan S.

description:
Randomly situated in a dark and semi-ghetto area, but once you're inside, you're golden(it is on a main street intersection however). So the place was pretty legit, service and accents and all. It took a little while to get our food, but if you're with good company, it is not so much of an issue.

I had the Risotto al nero di seppia, which looked quite interesting both on the menu, and when it came out. The taste was quite good, but after a while, it got boring. The actual ratio of rice:calamari:scallop was actually like 100:10:1. Bascially, a cooked scallop tops the dish, and you hope that you find some calamari pieces while u consume like 1200 calories of rice X_X. Not a worthy carbaload, -_-.

My fwend got  the Tagliatelle ai porcini e tartufo, which was very tasty. All sorts of mushrooms and truffle oil. I may try that again if i get hungry and am in the area. 

All in all it is a pretty solid meal, albeit the dish I had was not particularly interesting or tasty. Perhaps I shall try something else another time~~

My name is Boris Yelpsin, and I approve this message.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Oh that was good! 

Going for lunch on a very very rainy day (ok, that was today) and finding myself in a very nice and cosy restaurant, eating great sea food risotto and antipasti, that was definitely a great experience!

To tell you the truth, I picked the risotto because I think risotto is such a tricky dish that it would tell directly if this restaurant could be trusted or not. And it was delicious! My plate was full with very good rice, tomato and sea food, just as I like it. The rice wasn't too sticky, but I thought it was great this way. And everything else on the menu looked really good too and the pasta especially seemed absolutely delicious. 

Unfortunately we didn't have time to try out the desserts, but if I trust other reviews, they're really a must-try too!
author: Camille L.

description:
This place is awesome!!  Every time my husband and I have gone, we have the most amazing dinners!  Super friendly staff, free appetizers, and deliciously scrumptious meals make for a wonderful evening.  The baked halibut and filet mignon are some of the best dishes I've ever had! 

 Most of the people in there speak Italian, which is a great sign for an Italian restaurant.  Hope I get to go visit again soon!
author: Maya G.

description:
The food was awesome. I had the seafood salad and scallop risotto. My wife had the gnocchi (which I tired) and both were delirious.

The service was great, fast and attentive (water glass always filled, checking up on us).

The waiter was nice and his wine recommendation was spot on.

The inside of the restaurant is very nice and quaint.

It was also less than a 10 minute walk to AT&T Stadium (we're going to see Cirque du Solie Totem). Took MUNI to New Montgomery and just walked the 12 minutes to get there, so very convenient location.

We'll be back for sure.
author: Alan P.

description:
If you don't mind the random location underneath the freeway, La Briciola is a super cute romantic little neighborhood restaurant.

Only great things to say:
- Top notch service
- Authentic waiters (he spoke with an Italian accent!)
- Warm bread basket - seriously, easy thing to do but so many places fail here.
- Delicious house made pasta. I had the Lasagna di mare ($19), creamy from the decadent bechamel sauce, and filled with shrimp, salmon, and swordfish. Ahh so good. I loved the creative way of making a seafood creation rather than the typical red meat sauce. Mmmm.
- Dessert - I preferred the Tiramisu ($8) over the Profiterolles ($8). Tiramisu had a lot of great flavor, and a nice big chunk of it. The profiterolles fell a little flat for me because I was expecting ice cream in the middle and this was filled with cream.

Overall, nice wines by the glass, friendly service, decent pricing, and no wait. But watch out for random vagrants who may press their faces against the window for fun. No fault of the restaurant, just an outcome of the location.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Great food and atmosphere.  Exactly what is advertised.  Good for a romantic date.  We found free parking on the street at 6pm on a Saturday and there are also a few $10 garages close by (Note: I actually walked to meet my wife from BART.  Around 10 blocks and not at all bad.)
My wife's family is from Lammari, outside Lucca in Tuscany  so I know good Tuscan food, and this is it.  This won't replace going there in person, but it does get you some of the way.
The staff was very good and as others mentioned many are from Italy.
author: David S.

description:
My roommates are Italian, from Italy. They give their stamp of approval on this restaurant.

Personally I prefer their seafood dishes over their meat dishes, but that's a personal opinion. Their rack of lamb is also delicious.

Due to my diet I haven't had much of their pasta, but I've been told it's delicious. :)

Recommended:

- warm octopus salad with cannelini beans
- baked halibut
author: Mary M.

description: Awful! Came here for dinner on 10/27 and ordered filet mignon ($35) which was inedible. We had to bat off the nats buzzing around our plates. They were out of the wine we ordered and offered a sub-par replacement (we ordered Claret; they substituted with cheap Cab). Very noisy. Waiter was nice. I will not be back and will not be recommending this place!
author: Trish M.

description:
This place is a hidden gem close to a random place under an overpass in SOMA.  It is pretty tiny but very cozy with romantic lighting.  I came on a Sunday night and it was pretty low key and quite; the staff is very friendly.  They have a pretty wide variety that is separated between ocean (seafood) and the land (meat) that will please any group of people.  In particular, I got their seabass ravioli, which they did not skimp on the fish meat.  It was really plumped with a delicious sauce.

The only thing I would add is I feel like their portions are a little small for me.  Their table bread is good and it comes with a delicious almond dip.  As for dessert, I got to try three of them- yum, you can't really go wrong with any of them.
author: Krystal C.

description: The bread that is served to your table before the meal is so good that I would go back here just for that. I went with three colleagues and we couldn't stop raving about the bread! Aside from that, I ordered the seabass ravioli with lobster reduction which was very good and filling too.
author: Emma N.

description: The place was a bit of let down specially for SF.  we started with Bruschette assortite zucchini, which was a Ok, they burned the bread a bit. My friend got the Petto di pollo ai porcini which had a great sauce and chicken was ok a bit chewy and I got the Ravioli di cernia that was good. For desert we got the Crème Caramel and Tiramisu both of which were below average. Specially Tiramisu that the cream was hard instead of soft... the service was good, I can't decide if the ambiance was good or just Ok. over all I give it 3 stars and won't go back with all the other great options in the city.
author: Arash H.

description:
Incredibly sad that my experience at Briciola wasn't as amazing as the other Yelp reviews. This place was supposed to be my gem of an Italian restaurant which is minutes away from my front door. Unfortunately, the food was mediocre and lacked excitement. Our party of 3 ordered the spinach with goat cheese and Caesar salad. Both were large portions and tasty; they even out-shined the entrees. As for our entrees, we went with the squid ink pasta, ravioli and grilled seafood plate. Everything was all right but again not all too unique or overly delicious. 

We also received complimentary glasses of Procecco to end the evening, but it wasn't enough as I was still disappointed with the food. Since this is incredibly close to my house and I really want to love it like everyone else...I will be going back to give another try.
author: Lisa R.

description:
Food = 4
Service = 5
Ambiance = 5
Price = $$$

Overall, my wife and I had a really great weeknight evening experience.  I had the rabbit stew.  I never had rabbit before, but it was a very tasty stew with everything cooked nicely, and good flavors.  My wife had a spinach and cheese gnocci, which was good, but not necessarily the best gnocci we've had.

The service was attentive and very helpful in helping us select our orders.  The ambiance was quiet on a weekday, but the place did get about half-full.  It was perfect for a weeknight date with my wife.

Would definitely consider going again.
author: Ed S.

description:
Just went last night and had a very positive experience. We went at about 8:30 in the evening, and the atmosphere was just great. The lights were dimmed and each table had it's own candle, giving the whole place a really nice, intimate feel.

We ordered the fried calamari for an appetizer, the lamb ragu and sea bass ravioli for entrees, and the tiramisu for dessert -- all of it was phenomenal. We were really comfortable the entire time and ended up chatting for the duration of our stay, about 90 minutes.

I also had two mochas and they were great, smooth and creamy with enough of a kick to keep me awake for the BART ride home. 

All in all, a great experience and I'd definitely go again.
author: Alex C.

description: Great food and an awesome staff. This place is what an Italian restaurant should feel like: inviting, comfortable, and delicious.
author: Brian A.

description: Excellent pasta and meat dishes. This is one of my two favorite Italian places in the city, and never disappoints. The olive tapanade they serve with the bread is soooo good!
author: Rajesh S.

description: The place was quite the hike from Union Square.  It's really expensive and the food didn't seem worth it.  Little to no vegetarian or vegan options.  I ordered a dish with homemade pasta and it was pretty bad...nothing like homemade pasta.  The restaurant looks nice, though, and the staff was staff was kind.  Watch our for the cloth covered window in the women's bathrooms...strange.
author: Shea H.

description:
Had a great dinner experience here for a friends birthday.  The restaurant did everything right: food was heavy but excellent (had mushroom crepes, tuna and profiteroles), service was on the dime, and the atmosphere was relaxed.  We brought our own wine and they even comped us the corkage.  All that for under $50 a person including tip.  Wild.

In short, one of the best values I've found in San Francisco.  I'll be back.
author: David A.

description:
Great Italian Food in SF!
While here traveling with my teen daughter we found reviews for La Briciola and thought we'd go for her birthday. The food was wonderful (fresh clams and mussels appetizer for her and carpaccio for me). We both had fresh pasta entrees and delicious dessert to follow. The place was small but had a warm and pleasant ambience and wait staff was attentive and friendly. Would definitely recommend this restaurant and will be back again.
author: Ida V.

description: Horribly disappointing, especially given the reviews. Ordered several pastas, all of which fell flat: pasta was chewy and tough (not al dente), flavour was monotone and failed to penetrate the noodles, sea bass ravioli came with shell bits in the sauce. Give me my money back.
author: Adele T.

description:
We ate here before seeing Tantrum last November based on yelp reviews.

This now my favorite Italian restaurant.   Many of the reviews on yelp cover some of our main courses.  However one main course I have not seen reviewed is the Coniglio in umido con polenta: "stewed rabbit~tomatoes~olives~rosemary~polenta".  My mom got this and we all tried some of it.  Wow, what a great dish!  Great portion size and lots of flavor.  You didn't even know you were eating rabbit.  I can't wait to go back for this dish alone.

Service was impeccable.
author: Stewart B.

description: Friendly service, but I found the food unimpressive. The lobster ravioli was OK (actually tasted better the 2nd day after reheating), but I can't even remember the other food we had.
author: Liz L.

description:
With a huge menu and a range of dishes from vegetarian to rabbit there is something for everyone here but most of the dishes aren't that special.

Without a doubt this is a good restaurant with good solid food and occasionally some quite good food.

We were a party of four on Tuesday night. We had made reservations that weren't needed as there was about a dozen tables filled at 8pm. The decor looks like they stopped half way through the decoration process but there is nothing horrible about it.

The service was excellent and helpful without being intrusive. The were able to seat us even though we came early and our party was not complete.

I was dining with two vegetarians, one pescatarians and myself, an omnivore.

The dishes we had:
Carpaccio di manzo-a straightford dish of raw beef, arugula, cheese and olive oil. it's was simple and just the way it should be. 

Fagottino ripieno- veggie crepes with a wild porcini mushrooms and truffle oil. this was probably the best vegetarian dish with a rich creamy sauce and savory filling.

Insalata del campo, a very basic and boring salad, nothing more and nothing less.

Our Entrees were:

Two orders of Gnocchi con taleggio: this was another average dish and while the gnocchi were light and fluffy, the spinach was non-existant and it seemed unfinished.

ravioli con pomodoro-again it was decent but uninspiring spinach and ricotta ravioli with a tomato sauce.

the three veggie dishes were all under the primi courses but they were entree sized and entree priced.

The best entree by far was the 
Coniglio in umido con polenta where the rabbit was amazing as was the polenta. first off it was huge plate of rabbit and then served with some of the best polenta I have had in San Francisco. The rabbit was cooked beautifully and then was in a rich italian hunter style sauces, all the was tender and moist and tasted like rabbit without any gaminess. the polenta was super crisp on the outside and super creamy on the inside.

We finished our meal with four desserts, all of which were good.
We had:
Tiramisu-very moist and good and pretty standard
Creme Carmel which was good but tasted a bit over flavored and burnt
Panna cotta with berry sauce-it was the special and the best dessert, super creamy and rich and the berries was wonderful and burst in your mouth
Profitterolles filled with creme served warm and covered in chocolate sauce, really large portion of four of them but they weren't as good as at Delfina.

The bill can add up if you are doing multiple course with antipasta in the low teens, primi in the high teens and secondi  in the 20's. Our bill with three glasses of wine, 3 soft drinks, and three coffee beverages was well over 200.

All in all this an ideal place to come for a business dinner or a more formal meal with the parents or a date from the Marina. It's does good Italian food in a boring if professional setting.

I may come back with meat eaters or if it's a business expense.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: This is by far the best Italian food I've ever had...and I've been around a few years and have eaten out all over the world.  I had the Linguine with Clams, and my husband had the meat lasagna.  Both had a glass of their savignon blanc from Napa valley.  Everything was excellent.  We didn't have reservations, but just walked in since I read good reviews on Yelp.  Also had the espresso and a strawberry and Italian gelato dessert.  I couldn't find one fault with the restaurant food or service.  I would definitely chalk this up as one of my favorite restaurants.
author: norma n.

description: Pretty great Italian restaurant. We went pretty late on Monday night, so there were not many people. The food was good and the atmosphere was even better.
author: Yushan Z.

description: I was craving my Nona"s cooking, and I came across this little gem. I knew when the true Italian  Bread was served with olive oil that had chunks of olives in it that i was in the right place. The Calamari was cooked to perfection ( no rubber bands!) They are one of the few restaurants to get Gnocchi correct (light, fluffy - no sinkers here!!)  I was blown away at how they have mastered the Panna Cotta. What a great way to finish a fabulous meal. If that isn't enough, the service was 1st class. What a fabulous dining experience. Belissimo!
author: Carmen M.

description:
Drake's song about being fancy would not apply to this place. At least not to the exteriors. If you don't pay attention while walking, you might just miss it and not know! It's rather is a rather shady neighborhood. (At least it seemed so the night we went because there was not a soul on the road in SoMa!)

But, when you walk in and you get greeted by warmth (not just because the heater was on, but because the place looked warm and the people here flashed warm welcoming smiles!), you just stop dissing whoever you were dissing! Great ambiance. A very romantic setting for those of you who want a quiet little place. Very much a ristorante Italiano feel!

The moment you are seated, you order the wine and are presented with bread that goes with the usual combination of olive oil and balsamic vinegar. Their bread was hot from the oven and oh so soft. I think I stuffed myself with the bread even before I ordered my meal! Our table of 8 ordered 2 bottles of the Tollo San Giovese. Both the husband and I are not fond of red wines. But I totally loved this one. Smooth and not the kinds that gives you a headache. However, it is rather potent! Arun ordered the Italian beer to compliment his food and he was a happy person. I don't know whether it was the happiness courtesy Thanksgiving or they do it in general, but we were served a bruschetta sampler, on the house. That calls for one star atleast!

Their menu is rather eclectic. You can order stuff that comes from the earth (ergo, meat and veggies) and stuff that comes from the sea (ergo, seafood). My hubby and I ordered the Burrata and the Ravioli con Pomodoro and split it between us since we wanted to taste them both. They were both fantastic. I hadn't tried Ravioli before this and I think I am glad that this was the first time I tried it because I simply loved it. Their marinara was perfect. The prosciutto was yummy. I also managed to sample some of the Gnocchi con taleggio from a friend and the gnocchi just melted in my mouth!

An equally spaced out menu for the vegetarians, vegans and the ones that like meat. This place serves genuine Italian food. Not the bastardized American version :o)

Post-dinner, the husband ordered himself a Cappuccino and me and a couple of my pals decided to split the Creme Caramel, which essentially tasted like Flan, felt like flan and I think, was flan!
I managed to sip some of the cappuccino too and man, I was floored. I know this might sound bad about the coffee, but it tasted like coffee back in India and I was a happy birdie!! :-D

Price-wise, it is very reasonable. The average price for a dish is around $10-$12. Our total bill for 8 came up to $280 including tips. 

Arun and I would definitely go back to this place. Its just lovely with lovely people serving you.
author: Ranjani S.

description:
So for me, this was a rather different Italian resturant.  Location seems a little on the outskirts of downtown. Inside building is all hard surfaces (ceiling, floor, walls) so it can be very noisy, even for a relatively small resturant. 

Food wise, depends on what you like. Most sauces I saw or tried were seemingly beef based, little oily, lack of tomato or cheese based sauce (at least for everything at our table).  So for me, was not particularly  fond of it, wasn't bad, just not my taste for Italian

Service though was good, including being very flexible with the seating.
author: Joe S.

description: La Briciola is authentic Italian. The menu is creative and the food is quality. The tagliatelle with porcini mushrooms and the halibut was dynamite. Nice wine selection, good service, and nice calming atmosphere. No liquor outside of wine and beer though.
author: Joe B.

description:
Loved this restaurant! From the moment we walked in, we felt welcomed - even without reservations. Our favorite part of the experience was the owner - very sweet Italian guy (Allessandro). My friend and I weren't very hungry so we declined appetizers. However, Allessandro brought us a sampling plate of a few different appetizers on the house and we loved every single one. We then shared the seabass ravioli, which was exceptional. The food was very fresh everything was extremely flavorful. We also had very generous pours of wine, which Allessandro was happy to re-fill for us.

The ambiance is cozy, romantic and warm - perfect for a date or dinner with a friend. I am eager to go back and try more on the menu!
author: Jenna Q.

description:
Service was excellent, fun,smiling, educational and attentive. Love to hear Italian and try it out. I love learning languages - know a smattering of 5 meself! 

I had the special - Halibut - it was like custard - delectable. thin thin slices of potato some tomato sauce and olives - did not think it would fill me but it did. BF had smoked salmon pasta and he liked it better than mine but I thought it was a little salty. Another had the truffle oil mushroom thingee picola?  and loved it too but I am not that much into truffles - I like mine best.  Pumpkin gnocci - others had was liked but they did not ooh and ahh like the rest of us. It definitely tasted like pumpkin and was filling.  I had the etoh alternative as designated driver which was peach fizz. Nice.   Oh and the lentil soup though having a oil floating on the top was delish!  

Left very satisfied.

review 154
author: Ms W.

description: Ate there with a big group last night and had a poor experience.  Ambiance was nice.  But the waiters were impatient, rude and slow.  The food was decent but overpriced.  Most of the group I was with gave so-so reviews to the food.  The worst part was that after we spent close to $1000 and were tipping close to $200 they refused to take more than 1 card because it was "too much work."  Instead we had to play a complicated game of figuring out who had cash, Chase Quickpay, Paypal, etc.  one poor friend had to put it on their card and then retrieve money from all over the internet.  For $200 I would have gladly run the cards myself.  Their loss though.  The extra 10 minutes of work they would have done cost them the future business of most of our group.
author: Chris H.

description: Came here for a date with the boy last night.  Been before, pretty solid Italian food.  We shared the Fagottino ripieno which are the vegetable filled crepe~wild porcini sauce~white truffle oil. Yum!  Very good.  For our meal we shared the Gnocchi Sorrentina, which I was a little disappointed in.  The dumplings were a little tough (not as light as I have had before), and the mottza got very tough once the dish was brought to the table.  The sauce was very good, lightly seasoned not over spiced balanced, and you can still taste the seeds (which I like).   The service was ok (not stellar, but not awful). Next time would prob just have the app as my dinner.  Be warned, it is pretty pricey.
author: Sheetal P.

description: Great service.  Nice ambiance.  The food was good, but I think there is still room for improvement when it comes to bringing out more flavors.  The wine selection was great, and the servers were very good at assisting in every way possible.
author: Julian C.

description:
This place is bomb!

I came here at 7:30 without reservations on a Friday. I had no idea what I was thinking. I walked in, and the place was absolutely packed. I had no idea where my party of three was going to sit. The sweet blonde-haired hostess told me that we'd probably have to wait until 8:45 to get a table, but that she could probably work something out.

I was preparing myself for utter disappointment and I really didn't want to leave. I was browsing their menu and practically salivating. A few minutes later, she came back and told us that we had a table! I was so ecstatic. 

We sat in a cozy table and ordered the 2007 Avignonesi di Montelpulciano Toscana. This was absolutely perfect for me and my man even though we ordered seafood dishes. My good friend was a bartender in NY for the longest time and he definitely knew his wine. 

We started off with the Tagliere di Salumi coppa~spek~prosciutto~salame~olives~marinated vegetables. This was a fantastic dish to share. I love coppa so this was the perfect starter. 

My friend had the Straccietti al ragú di agnello hand cut pasta~lamb ragú. He seemed to really enjoy it. 

My guy had the Ravioli di cernia seabass filled ravioli~lobster reduction. Like some Yelpers, I thought the reduction completely overshadowed the seabass - which I could not taste at all. The sauce was delicious and perfect for bread dipping.

I had the Risotto al nero di seppia calamari~ink sauce~scallops. I failed to pay attention to the "ink sauce" part of the dish. When my dish came, I dug into the big (but few) pieces of calamari and one scallop (just one?!) and of course, ate the risotto by spoonfuls.  At least it was delicious. The black risotto was absolutely creamy and flavorful. I love squid. It was cooked very nicely here. 

However - What my lack of attention regarding squid INK resulted in was my teeth covered in pure black - squid - ink. So, here I was talking politics to my two dinner companions, and they were laughing at me and my black teeth. 

Our server and the hostess were both polite and efficient. I really love good Italian and glad that there is a cute charming restaurant here in SOMA. We will definitely be back -- but we will make reservations for sure.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
Went with a group of 10 and the service was great... Warm friendly and quick. 
Some of the best meals were grilled fish
But the pastas were great as well
author: Brian K.

description:
New favorite restaurant!  Great food & great service.  
Bread and olive oil = SO GOOD!  Olive flavored olive oil, with chunks of olives at the bottom
Risotto with squid ink sauce = YUM.  I was already craving it again on my drive home.  
For dessert tried the tiramisu and panna cotta (special), loved both! Service was great as well, we had just come from a afternoon tea bridal shower so we weren't very hungry. They were totally ok with us sharing meals (no dirty looks, no sign of annoyance), and even split the food for us.  Lastly, I always order water with no ice (I get cold) and when they remember that when refilling my glass, that's definitely plus points!
author: Maggie L.

description:
Delicious! Everything we ordered was great! 
 --Crostini misti di polenta: great flavor, and nice little assortment.
 -- Bruschetta assortite zucchini:  6 pieces (2 of each) - all were good, fav: peppers
 
I ordered the Conchiglie con salsiccia  - yums.  Simple, but worth it.  My coworker ordered the Penne pasticciate al ragú, which smelled & tasted amazing!

And the tiramisu... reason why we went here - definitely worth it!! 

Service was okay.  Waiter was really nice, but was a bit slow - we had to constantly try to get his attention.
author: Heather M.

description: food poisoning!  Don't order any thing with meat here because I fear that they do not store things at the correct temperature.  Its a shame because the food was so tasty, I will spare you the details.
author: Cloudy S.

description: Decent Italian restaurant in SOMA that is very traditional but food was slightly disappointing. The puff pastry seafood appetizer lacked substance in filling although the sauce was good. The cioppino was cooked in a hot baking dish which gave it a rustic feel but tasted a little too fishy with overcooked seafood. The ravioli with lobster sauce was nice but pretty ordinary and small portioned. Overall not a bad spot but it is semi-pricey for food that is not spectacular.
author: Ed L.

description:
Cute little Italian restaurant in SOMA. The menu isn't incredibly extensive, but just enough variety for you to choose from. The space feels intimate; dimly lit with candles and soft overhead lighting. I especially like the brick and arches that make up the space. They also have photos and paintings on the walls that can be purchased from local artists. The service here is also top notch. Expect the waiters to be extremely friendly and doting.

Now, onto the food. I always like to start with the burratta which they serve with prosciutto, arugula, and this balsamic sauce. My favorite dishes are the lamb ragu, the frutti de mare, and their lobster ravioli. Their saffron risotto leaves something to be desired. Entrees are approximately $17 each. Dinner for four will probably run you $30 a person including wine and appetizer to share.
author: Angela L.

description:
Strengths:  Casual atmosphere, warm service.  Good value wine list.  Lamb Ragu was awesome.

Weaknesses:  Most of the food was not as good it looked.  First time chicken liver pate did not taste good to me...in my life.  Texture felt like ground beef.

Opportunities:  Refine the food.  Presentation is outstanding but taste and texture are a bit off.  Puff pastry a little dry and the rolled veal was very salty.

Threats:  Pazzia, closeby with better food but not as good atmosphere.

Total:  $140 for 2 ppl.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Prices expensive.
Ambience quite nice, the only part that earns a definite positive grade besides parking availability.
Food mediocre to OK.
Wine selection pretty good, though overpriced.
Service terrible, even though most tables were empty.
Parking very easy to find - it should have been a tip-off.

Overall - There are enough good restaurants in SF, with much better food, service and value than this.
author: SAROSH K.

description: I noticed that the host was also the server. The busboy was very attentive. He refilled my cup of water every time that it was low. The food was delicious. One of the best tasting calamari appetizer I've eating at an Italian restaurant. Overall, it was a good experience.
author: Murphy D.

description:
Awesome place! Husband/wife team are great and make this place a delight to visit and eat!  

Luciano was very helpful with the wine selection and the food was awesome.  I had halibut - which was delicious - just be careful its served ve hot! The raviolli and gnocchi were also big hit.  

Agree with other comments - like warm bread and (interesting) olive oil very interesting.  The burschetta combo with eggplant and traditional tomato topping is a must try.  

We checked-in on Yelp and got 2 free desserts.  

Price wise came out around ~$35-50/pp (depending on drinking) - and its a great value for $ and time!  This is a great place and definitely one of the best Italian restaurants in the city.  

Advice to SF Yelpers - must try Italian!
author: Bhavin M.

description: I made reservations for 14 of us a few weeks in advance and was so happy they can accommodate us on such a short notice for the post Thanksgiving Sat night in the city. The service was excellent!  Our table was ready, our waiter was spot on, knew the specials by heart and answered all our questions courteously. The best part was the food!  Of note: the ink risotto was delicious (though it could've used more seafood but I'm a seafood freak, lol), the lamb chops were perfectly done, their pastas were freshly made and tasteful.  Everyone in our party (grandparents to a 3yrs old) had a great experience.  The ambiance was perfect for families. Would definitely revisit and highly recommend.
author: sheyam i.

description: Wow! What an absolutely fantastic meal! I can't wait to get back there again. Service was impeccable, unbelievably friendly, and the staff were so charming! Also, our waiter must have overhead us wish my dad a happy birthday, and after the meal brought us dessert on the house. What a wonderful touch. I'm so glad we found this little hidden gem. Definitely worth going back to!
author: Nina W.

description:
Best gnocchi I've ever had!!

Looking for a late night/ quick bite at 930p on a Wednesday and La Briccola was the perfect spot. Cozy and warm with excellent food. Service was great and just very classy!

Highly recommend it and I will be back
author: Peter T.

description: Tested La Bricola out for a special New Years Eve dinner and it was delicious.  Calamari was some of the best I've had and the cioppino was excellent.
author: Joshua K.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to try this place cause I was hell-bent on finding another risotto hot spot we could venture to. When I checked out the menu online I narrowed my search down to their risotto allo scoglio (seafood risotto with prawns, calamari, and clams). Unfortunately, they only served it as a lunch special. Boyfriend calls up the restaurant to see if the chef could still make it for dinner, guy says "yes." Score! 

We show up at the restaurant which was empty since we got there fairly early, but the minute we walked in I was already in awe at how intimate it looked. There was a wine rack that lined the far back wall and the walls are painted a nice, simple cream color which gives it a soothing ambiance. While the large arch ways separating the bar with the dining room table gives it a more lively and spacious feel to it.

We were seated in the back where I could see they had a large selection of wine. I was already ready to order my risotto but then the guy said that it's only offered during lunch. Kinda disappointed by his lack of effort with not asking the chef the possibility in comparison to the guy we spoke to over the phone, so I had to dock a star. Simple gesture that takes less than 2 minutes. Didn't feel like bothering with that, so I just ended up going with the Ravioli di cernia (seabass filled ravioli with lobster reduction). The seabass gave the ravioli a nice light flavor to it so that it didn't feel so heavy with the lobster reduction. Not disappointed at all because it was just the right amount so I could fit some dessert in with my meal. My boyfriend got the Risotto alla monferrina (saffron risotto with sausage) and he was a bit disappointed since the risotto was a little on the under cooked side and the flavor just wasn't there for him plus the portion was way too big. I ended my dinner on a high note with the Soufflé al cioccolato (warm chocolate cake~chocolate sauce). It was delicious...I could hardly share with my boyfriend. 

I think I'd have to come back to try the other dishes and the waiting staff wasn't all that bad. But I did find it odd that one of the guys who were the hosts, was not dressed in uniform at all, so I was a bit confused when he was leading us to our table. Can't really say if he was the manager or not so we just decided to go with the flow.
author: Alexis A.

description: Wandered in Friday after work with my husband.  Cozy ambiance, friendly servers.  Wine was good and service excellent.  I ate all my gnocchi and then a cannoli afterward.  The only downer was the bread - please serve hot, a little bit bigger slices, and no olives in the olive oil.  Otherwise a terrific meal.  Highly recommend!
author: Carolyn J.

description:
Terrine of veggies!  Lovely tastes and textures.
Linguine alla Cinqueterra....I can't believe I ate the whole thing.  Nice vibes, nice staff.
author: Victor M.

description: A delightful Italian restaurant, small enough to feel cozy, but large enough to accommodate large groups.  Service was great, our waitstaff appeared to be bilingual in Italian and English, and the prices are reasonable.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
The service here is very friendly and very Italian. Other reviewers are correct in saying that they throw Italian words into all their sentences; "bella" was thrown around a few times. Other yelpers are INCORRECT in that the portions here are not small at all. I thought they were perfect, especially since for a meal that is designed to have 3 courses.

The bread basket was to die for. I ate nearly the whole thing all by my lonesome. The dipping sauce was also amazing. I did not discover until halfway through the basket that you have to "dip deep" to get the good chunks at the bottom of the bowl.

For an antipasto, I attempted to order the Burrata, but they were out, it was very sad. Instead I ordered Sfogliatine con gamberi e asparagi. This was kind of a let down. I love puff pastry, but the pastry was lacking in the puff department, and lacking flakiness. My date ordered the carpaccio, which was pretty tasty. I feel I can not properly judge though, because I had never had carpaccio before.

For our primi, we shared the gnocchi sorrentina. I was very unsure about this gnocchi. On the one hand, it was much much softer/mushier than gnocchi I have had before, but it was also kind of nice that it wasn't heavy at all. This must be the dish that people refer to as "Chef Boyardee." My date said it smelled like spaghetti-o's. Fortunately, it tasted better than spaghetti-o's.

For secondi, I had the halibut and my date had the filet mignon. The halibut was good, but maybe a little too salty. I couldn't quite put my finger on what it was that made me not finish it. I hate beef, but the filet mignon was not bad; my date certainly liked it.

For dessert, we shared the profiteroles. They were yummy. The filling was perfect and the chocolate sauce was absolutely to die for. I am quite judgmental of profiteroles because I have made them many many times. It was a very good finish to a sort of medium meal.

My experience here was not negative, but I think I would try other Italian places before returning.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
Really good gourmet Italian pasta. 
Delicious seafood ..
They make the pasta dough there themselves. 

It's a little too pricy.. and it's a small restaurant.

Ideal for Romantic dates.
author: T I.

description:
Had a nice dinner here last Sunday.  

What we had:
-Bruschetta trio plate: 1. tomato, 2. mushroom, 3. roasted peppers. Yum on all three.  

We shared a lamb pappadelle pasta plate.  This was okay.  I felt the pasta was overcooked and the lamb lacked a lot of flavor. 

BUT... our entrees totally made up for the pasta dish.  I had the filet mignon with truffles on top cooked to perfection at medium rare.  I seriously did a happy dance after the first bite.. no joke.  It was uncontrollable.  I had to shake my booty in happiness.  

The friend had the lamb chop dish.. also cooked to perfection at medium rare.  Seriously, my friend took a bite of his lamb and had a mouth orgasm.  I tried it and totally concur.  

Food was good and service was attentive.  I'd come back here again to ensure a mouth-gasm and a happy dance.
author: Vicky T.

description: My pasta was cold, but flavors were good. The food was good, but not "great!"
author: Maria M.

description: Authentic Italian food - A MUST dine!  Thanks to everyone for making our night so enjoyable!
author: Ann H.

description: Wonderful Italian food at La Briciola.  I had the Crudo e mozzarella prosciutto, which is an excellent paninni, as well as the minestrone soup. Thoroughly enjoyed these well-prepared dishes.
author: Jack K.

description:
We came here with a large group for dinner on a Saturday night. Parking was really easy and the large wine list was a huge plus. I ordered the agliatelle ai porcini e tartufo (wild porcini, truffle pasta) and was disappointed by the portion size (everyone was still hungry after dinner) and the lack of tartufo in the pasta. 

I've definitely experienced better italian in SF. Paired with their slow service I don't think I'll be returning. The restaurant itself is cute and charming and most of the people there seem to be Italians. The food just didn't deliver.
author: H T.

description: This place is almost too good.  Came back here last week after many years away because I was in the mood for some seafood.  As always, the staff was very welcoming, and there was plenty of room on a Wednesday night.  We sat at the bar and ordered some wine, which I was very pleased with.  They promptly brought out their delicious bread... warm and crisp, and they kept it coming all night (bad for my low carb goals but good for the bread loving devil inside me).  Started with the steamed mussels and clams.  It was a very simple broth, but was likely the best steamed seafood I've had in a restaurant.  I was seriously spooning the broth straight into my mouth at one point.  It was that good.  We also got the grilled calamari and the pulpo.  The grilled calamari was perfect.  I likes that the dish only included the whole mantles that charred up nicely.  The pulpo was so incredibly tender that at first I thought they had given us something else.  I'm really looking forward to coming back for more of their seafood dishes.
author: Ash T.

description:
Another neighborhood gem (I like living in the SOMA).

"From the Earth" and "From the Ocean" is a nice twist.

Try the Spinacina, Filetto con fonduta al tartufo, and Frittura di calamari.
author: Francis M.

description:
Good food, small, good portions, and good service. Got free tiramisu for checking in. 
Filet mignon was cooked nice and was tender. Had ravioli and a pasta with clams and mussells. Honestly, I didn't really like the pasta sauce. Waiter recommended a wine we drank which was good too.
Our total came out to around $140 with tip.
author: Aeri K.

description:
This restaurant was on the way home from the Cal Train Station in SF, so my wife and I decided to drop by.  Overall, the food was solid, but unspectacular.  The service was good and friendly, but the restaurant was nearly when we arrived just prior to 6 p.m.  

We ordered the insalata del campo (arugala salad with cherry tomatoes and shaved parmagiano), sea bass ravioli, and filet mignon.  There was also a yelp coupon that offered one free dessert per table, but my wife negotiated to grab us two desserts, so we got to try to chocolate lava cake and panna cotta.  

The bread was quite excellent and the decor was nice.  The salad was okay - fresh, but not worth the $9 that was charged.  The entrees were tasty, as were the desserts.

With the yelp offer, I felt that we had a decent deal, but without the offer, it felt overpriced given the quality.
author: Bowdoin S.

description: 3.5 stars. Service was great, but the food was just ok. Hard to remember what we had, but I know one dish was black from the squid ink. Neither dish was very memorable.
author: Matt S.

description:
Yum. And wow.

When I walked in, I was impressed. 
When I ate the food I was impressed. 

Then, when the owner sat down with me and my friends to talk genuinely about the food, business, and life for two hours, I felt like I was in a dream. You can find great restaurants  but you can't always  great people behind them.

Here is what I remember the most:

The Farfalle pasta was sinfully delicious.

They freeze nearly nothing. Everything (homemade pasta, produce) arrives or is made the day you consume it.

The owner is from one part of Italy (Piedmont I think?). The head chef is from another. They combined the flavors and textures from both regions to make the menu.

The owner and his wife designed and built the inside of the restaurant from the floors to the bricks on the wall to the hanging artwork.

Essentially, I left La Briciola with a whole new outlook on what a restaurant could be. I never knew you could run a successful a place with so much love and dedication.
author: Loe L.

description: Not bad but didn't like my food (prosciutto panini). The service was great.
author: Maryam M.

description: My boyfriend and I came here to check it out. We found it a little pricey, I ordered a $20+ dish of a mid-sized chunk of salmon which was satisfactory but nothing spectacular. He got a pasta dish which was also okay. I don't have much to say, which means there was nothing spectacularly great or bad and this place is all in all a solid restaurant.
author: Amy L.

description: So legit. Great food, great staff, a go-to spot for me. Have never had anything I don't love. No nonsense Italiano spot. Hit it. Be happy.
author: Justin M.

description:
My husband and I love this place. Simple, delicious food, reasonably priced and fantastic, friendly service. Plus it is a BYOW. I haven't had one dish here I didn't love. My favorites are the mozzarella, calamari app and the seafood lasagna. 

We also had my husband's birthday dinner here back in January for 14 or so people. They were a pleasure to work with and made sure everything went smoothly. 

This place is my favorite "I'm craving carbs on a Tuesday night" restaurant. As another Yelper said it truly is a hidden gem!!
author: Courtney D.

description:
Good pasta, good service, good ambiance. Great dip for the bread. Satisfied for the price.

I don't plan on returning but won't mind if it happens. My buddy felt the same.
author: Todd I.

description: Random (and slightly seedy) location, but delicious food. The prices are pretty reasonable, and the food is high quality. Despite the location, the ambience is warm and welcoming. It's pretty easy to park around here, which is always a plus.
author: Diana G.

description:
A group of girlfriends and I came her for a birthday dinner a few couple nights ago.

The entrance to this restaurant is easy to miss; very cozy and intimate inside. Definitely a date/ anniversary/ special occasion spot. The employees were very attentive and were very easy-going as we waited for the rest of our party to arrive. 

The menu offers a pretty good variety of selection, but as described in most of the other reviews, the portions are pretty small and overpriced. Having read these reviews, I did my best to prepare by eating a bit beforehand. I ordered the Vitello alla valdostana (rolled veal), which I thought would be satisfying and somewhat filling, especially for being an entree dish. Unfortunately, I was disappointed by the portion size, BUT those were really (small but) delicious bites! Amongst my friends' dishes (including lamb, salmon and pastas), I heard opinions of it being delicious but not filling OR a bit bland. In the end, it definitely adds up if you're expecting to be full at the end of your meal.

Overall, decent food, small portions, and GREAT service. I don't plan on coming back because I definitely prefer other spots in the city.

** Also, be sure to check-in on your smart phone for a free dessert! :)
author: Julie T.

description:
3.5 stars

Came here for girls night out, 15 of us. One would think that this was a quiet romantic Italian resto. Not last night!

The servers were very accommodating, polite and patient. 
The food was ok. I shared the sea bass ravs  and halibut (both recommended by waiter). The halibut was in a tomato sauce and melts in your mouth! Not what I expected but pleasantly surprising. The fish was a tad on the salty side. Sauce was ok. I had high expectations for the ravs. Again that was ok. Very cheesy which was weird. My friends had the seafood pasta dish (like a cioppino). Said it lacked flavor. 
Desserts were decent. Tiramisu I thought was the best. Girlfriend liked the chocolate lava cake and cream puffs

Pros- lots of parking at 8pm. Extensive list of Italian wines, all reasonably priced. Can get a reservation last minute for large parties

They make their own pastas so I am hoping to return to try them. Hopefully it will be mind blowing haha
author: joyce l.

description:
Pros:
Perfect ambiance for a quiet evening tête-à-tête with the honey; Great service with a touch of Italian accent; Delicious food; Expansive selection of fish dishes; Fine selection of local and Italian wines.

Cons:
It's expensive for what you get on your plate; Profiterolles came with hot cream inside (as opposed to the correct manner to serve them with chilled cream or ice cream); Somewhat salty main dishes.
author: Gabriel A.

description: This place was okay, and not more or less. As part of a group of 4 we had the bruschetta & mozzarella/ Parma ham starters & 3 different mains. The food was all finished, but it didn't make any impression on me or my wife. Ambience was pleasant and the waiter was very attentive.
author: Barry O.

description:
Very satisfying food and great service. 

I had the Ravioli with Spinach and Ricotta and had the waiter cover it with Parmesan.. It was exactly what I was hoping it would be!!

Food wasn't mind-blowing, but it was very satisfying.
author: Nikki H.

description: La Briciola is one of my favorite SoMa neighborhood dinner spots.  I end up here frequently, particularly because it's open later than most places in the area and it is delicious.  It is a bit pricier than one would expect at the end of the meal - dishes aren't expensive, but they are very small, so it adds up quickly.  Definitely worth a visit to try it though!
author: Greg B.

description:
All I have to say is WOW. I don't really give out 5-stars that freely, but this place is awesome.

First of all, getting a reservation was a breeze. Despite its high ratings and popularity, it's not one of those restaurants where you go on Open Table and you can't find an opening within 2.5 hours of your specified time blah blah blah etc etc... I hate that. I actually had to shift my reservation later by half an hour (party of 6) about an hour before dinner, and the woman told me it was no problem. She was so nice and accommodating.

When I got there, the hostess was so nice, and was actually able to seat me early. The bread and olive oil dip are as good as everyone says; strong olive oil flavor with bits of olive at the bottom, and warm, crusty Italian bread. Delicious!

I had the sea bass ravioli with lobster reduction, which was great, not too heavy, with a nice seafood-y flavor. My sister had the clam linguine with white wine sauce, which was delicious. My dad got the lamb ragu, which looked yummy as well (I didn't get a chance to try it because he ate it all), so I definitely am coming back to try that. Al their pasta (I think) is house-made, and it's sooo delicious.

For dessert, I had the panna cotta, which was so light and fluffy, yet rich and creamy at the same time. I don't know how they do it! It wasn't on the menu tonight, so if you want this you might have to ask for it. 

Although I usually feel stuffed after an Italian dinner, I didn't tonight. All the proportions were just right, and I felt satisfied, but not uncomfortably stuffed. I was surprised, given the amount of bread I ate before dinner! The ambiance is wonderful.. cozy and warm, reminiscent of Italy...and the service is great. Our server was so polite and never took too short or too long to bring out dishes, etc. 

Overall, I loved this place and will definitely come back again and again!
author: Rhea K.

description: Why I have walked by this place so many times & not eaten here, is unbeknown to me. But finally we stopped, and my italian-food eating life has been changed forever. Fantastic. Thats all I need to say. The place is quaint & the staff are the real-deal. The charcuterie plate had some of the best prosciutto I have ever eaten, and the lamb ragu with  homemade pasta was unbelievable. Small places also get my vote, as they wine mark-ups are not as crazy as some of the self-infatuated michelan rated restaurants in this city. ( some as high as 400% !). Here, we ordered a beautiful 2007 Brunello, and it was only $25 more than what you could buy it retail. We will definately be back here. Don't be taken back by the strange location on 3rd in SOMA, its a real gem.
author: Jen S.

description: 3 courses. Mother's Day. Course 1 (octopus), a real test of an italian restaurant, this was bland, bland bland. Couse 2 (Orecchiette w Broccoli), pasta cooked well, as was broccoli - not over done but not well seasoned either. Course 3 (rabbit) this was excellent, cooked well, not overpowered by sauce, made running bread across plate a pleasure. Nice atmosphere, prices borderline (high), service was so / so, but plenty of ice water and generally pleasant when informed we would not be getting alcohol, wine or dessert (all avoidable options for us generally).
author: Christopher F.

description:
The Good:
+ Accommodated our huge group graciously.
+ Awesome dirty-martini-esque olive oil.  I love olives.  I could've eaten that stuff with the bread all day.  They were quite generous with the bread and oil, especially considering how long we had to wait.
+ Flavors, when they were spot on, were delicious.  The honey and I ordered the polenta appetizer to share, which was awesome.  We then went halvsies on the fish/lobster sauce ravioli and pasta with tomato and arugula.  The lobster sauce was AWESOME.

The Bad:
- The ravioli....where was the fish?  Seemed like mostly cheese.  The pasta with the tomato and arugula...sorry, but I make a much tastier version from a NYT recipe.  Blah.
- Small portions.  Not good value for the money.

The Ugly.
--  The restaurant really struggled with our huge group--collecting the orders, getting all the food out within a short span of time, and then giving us the check were all challenges for them.  Worse yet, it didn't seem to occur to the waiter to break up the check for a party of about 30 people, so you can imagine how long it took for us to figure out how to split the tab, especially with the mix of cash and credit cards and dishes and drinks.
author: Alicia C.

description:
Wow! Amazing place with fantastic italian food. A bunch of American - Italian women began a conversation with me when I was here, just to tell me how wonderful the food here is. Apparently, her relatives from Italy who visit do not leave SF without a meal here. 

We were a large group of 20 people and they were nice enough to accomodate us in the small space they had. We ordered a variety of things from the menu (too many to list) and no one had anything but fantastic things to say about the food. They even worked with some of our special dietary preferences. Wonderful place indeed!
author: Ash B.

description:
This is a charming Italian restaurant I stumbled across one night in the neighborhood. They serve absolutely wonderful food; everyone who has gone here simply loves it. I am a big gnocchi fan and they make a delicious one (their current iteration,  with a meat sauce instead of cheese and almonds, is wonderful, and a huge improvement). The ravioli is also first class, prompting rave reviews from all who have sampled it. 

But on to more important things...they have a wonderful coke mix. Just the right amount of carbonation gives it an extra "burning" kick, and they serve it in thin classes with aerated ice cubes. The drink stays cold and the ice remains un-melted even to the final sip.
author: Emily S.

description:
My friend offered to take me out to dinner, and she suggested we try out the new restaurant that took over the old place. 

I am not sure if they were short-staffed that night, but service was a bit uncomfortably slow. Other than that, everything was really amazing. When the waitstaff was there, they were very nice. They got our orders totally right, my water glass was constantly re-filled, the food was excellent. We had a kid with us, and they were very nice to her. There are no crayons or anything, but they didn't at all seem upset she was there. 

We are both NYers, one of us is Italian, and we both loved the food. I have already told another person about the place, and plan to go back.
author: Green Y.

description: Feels like a mama and papa owned restaurant. I'm not a huge fan of Italian food but this place is one I actually look forward to going.
author: Lian F.

description:
Food - Great
Decor - Good
Service - Great

MIdway into into dinner found out that my waiter (Luciano) and the bartender/host were the owners. Nicest people. 

I had gotten a free desert by checking with Yelp, and did not have the time to eat because was late for a plane back to NY. She insisted that I took it to go.

Food was really good here, staff super on the money bringing bread and all else.

Great place will go again when visiting San Fran.
author: Ronald D.

description:
What struck me first was how classy the atmosphere is.
Excellent food and great service at a reasonable price! What more could I ask for?
author: Brian C.

description: My husband and I were visiting from Alaska and wanted at the last minute to do dinner with friends, so we yelped, made reservations for 4 and when we arrived doubled our party to 8.  No problem in 5 min. they increased our table size to accomodate.  Now for the food, from appitizer to dessert the food rocked, so good.  Each person ordered something different and we all tasted each others food, each entree was wonderful.  Not a bad plate in the bunch, and the homemade pasta was to die for.  The prices resonable and service great.  What a hidden gem, we all vowed to return!
author: Cathy T.

description:
Came here for dinner to celebrate the first day of the new year.

Based on reviews, I knew this place will look nothing at all from the outside.  Tucked between a liquor store and a gas station, it's easy to miss.  But lucky me, we even got parking right in front of it.  

Place is small but has very nice setting, good relaxed ambiance, soft lighting, perfect for dates.  Maybe if they added music similar to what they are playing at their website, it will add more to the romantic vibe they seem to be going for. Nonetheless, the quiet atmosphere was okay and this place is great for groups and families.

We got a glass of wine each.  I was excited there for a minute because they had Opus One.   But only by the bottle so I got a cab instead.  

We started off with the Spinacina.  Although not a bad choice for a starter, there really was nothing exciting about this dish.  

I got the the stewed rabbit with polenta.  Wow!  As in, this won high marks with me.  Tender meat, great heavy sauce, good balance with the side of vegetables and the polenta.  My friend got the salmon fillet in saffron sauce and it was enjoyed plenty.

My dish was a really good portion, I was so full, but I refuse to not have dessert.  It's the best part of the meal after all.  So to finish off the meal I got the puff pastry topped with whipped cream and chocolate sauce.  I would have preferred this warmer but it still made me excited, just watch me take spoonfuls of it.  

5 stars for customer service.  From my phone call to make reservations to the entire dining experience.

The meal for two totaled $100 with tip.  I will definitely recommend this place.
author: Pam S.

description: What a great gem of a place.  We had a great server that walked us through the menu with ease.
author: Gordon W.

description: Booked a table for 25 for a family reunion well in advance.  Everything was perfect. The seafood dishes we chose were so delicious, we had to offer tastes to  each other. I recommend the sea bass ravioli in a lobster reduction. The 6 children were made to feel very welcome, and they loved their dishes, too, especially the warm octopus salad and smoked salmon. The staff was genuinely hospitable and kind.  Thanks to Alessandro and the rest of the staff for a wonderfully memorable evening!
author: Anne H.

description: I've eaten here twice and each time it was DELICIOUS!    Reasonably priced, very easy to get a reservation (I've gotten same-day reservations 2x here).  Great wine selection, delicious pasta entrees.  I haven't had a meat or fish dish here yet but I'm sure to as I will be back.
author: Jackie O.

description: Have been to this place twice now- once with a group of friends and once with my parents.  The food was consistently delicious both times.  Seafood items were particular standouts (right hand side of the menu - nothing we got from there disappointed).  Olive dip and bread could have filled me up before the pasta even came, and the wine selection has some of my favorite Italian wine (there's a spicy montepulciano that I don't think I could avoid if I tried).  Plus, everybody there has Italian accents - I love it.  Will be back again!
author: Danielle B.

description:
The lunch menu at La Briciola is an amazing value. Try the pasta dishes, especially the bucatini and Gorgonzola tortellini. I also am a fan of the veal scallopini. 

Really, in the area of SOMA you can't do much better for a pleasant work lunch out.
author: Laura S.

description:
2.5
The bad:  Restaurant was Stuffy and muggy on a hot evening.  Service was too slow for my taste.  I could have made the Caesar salad and pasta dish I ordered.

Good:  Our grilled calamari appetizer was good though I didn't like the pairing with hummus.  Linguine with clams was also not bad. 

If you want Italian, go down a block to Pazzia.
author: Yum Y.
