description:
Went to the restaurant tonight for the first time with 2 of my girlfriends and it was such a wonderful experience that I felt it necessary to Yelp about it right now :) 

This restaurant has everything that you would expect and more. Greeted and seated promptly. Waiter was perfect, very courteous and checked on us just the right amount of times. The menu was great with a good selection and prices ranging on average from $15-$25 for entrees. They made one mistake and brought out the wrong Gnocchi for my friend, but corrected it within 5 minutes. To make up for this mistake (which was totally no big deal) they refilled our wine glasses, which basically gave us 2 free glasses of wine. Anddd gave us a free dessert at the end of our meal! I was so very impressed with this place, that I just can't believe I didn't come here sooner!
author: Kate C.

description:
Had a delicous, well-rounded dinner here tonight accompanied by fantastic service.

We ordered:

burrata antipasti
lamb sugo
sea bass ravioli in lobster reduction
tiramisu

Everything we ordered was flavorful without being overpowering, and also perfectly portioned. I would have to say the ravioli was outstanding and I would highly recommend it more than anything else.  Randomly, the olive oil is also exceptional. Service is friendly without being annoying. On a Friday night it was not crowded, but don't be fooled - the food here is serious. Also had a nice glass of cabernet. Were able to find street parking and not pay a dime -- in SF that is a rarity, my friends.

Will definitely come again if I'm in this neighborhood.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Great elegant little place tucked away on 3rd street! My bf lives a couple blocks away and we're always searching for more restaurants in SOMA, and we were very happy with this find. 

We walked in on a Sunday night with no reservations, but they seated us promptly. We had the cutest bald waiter straight from Italy who answered all our questions in Italian. I loved it even though I couldn't understand him (just smile and nod). I'm not usually a huge fan of the white bread they serve you, but this one was super soft and went perfectly with the tapenade. I practically finished the whole thing by myself (bye bye Cancun diet). For wine, I ordered the Frascati from Italy (similar to a Pinot Grigio) and my bf got the Riesling. Both were great, although the riesling was a tad better since I'm partial to that. 

The zuppa was great too - I didn't order an appetizer since I was pretty stuffed from bread and wanted to save my reserves for the main course. My bf got the sausage, spinach and frommage pasta and I ordered the baked halibut with tomato sauce, olives, and thinly sliced potatoes. The fish itself wasn't the BEST fish I've ever had (tasted a little too... fishy, if you know what I mean). But I figured I'd have better luck with another dish next time - everything else was so good I could tell it was probably just unique to what I ordered. And I'm definitely not this forgiving normally. 

The best part though, was the dessert. The profiteroles were ginormous and overflowing with chocolatey goodness. The caramel custard was delish too. And on top of that - this is what really did it - remember our cute little Italian baldie? He gave us 2 free glasses of Moscato sparkling wine, which is our absolute FAVORITE meal topper. He definitely got a brownie points for that one. So we guzzled and licked the rest of our meal and came back stuffed and satisfied. 

Definitely coming back, especially since it's so good and there were so many other things I wanted to try, like the seabass stuffed ravioli and the warm octopus salad.
author: Natalie W.

description:
YU-UM.

After hearing great things from our good friend, we decided to give the place a chance one night (after much speculation from someone in our party) and we all left full of delish meals.
I had the agnello (lamb) sauce and a friend had the anatra (duck) and they were both great. Another one tried a seafood pasta that was awesome. The pasta is homemade and the antipasto was delish.

The atmosphere was great and perfect for a date....

Not to mention they got the caffe' down. We'll be back and with more people in tow!
author: Francesca F.

description:
What a standout little gem of a place. A friend and I wanted some handmade pasta and I thought I'd have to head over to the craziness of flour and water or drive all the way to La Ciccia. Who knew - 3rd and Harrison there's a great authentic italian place with great food, italian type slow and faithful service, and it's NOT a shit show!

Food: they have burrata on proscuitto. That is really all I need. The opening bread comes with a nice tapenade. My lamb ragu pasta was amazing. The salmon with saffron was good if you love saffron. The profiterole desert was not the best but still yummy.

Ambiance: small, quiet, intimate, perfect.

Service: this was typical italian service. No one breathing down your neck, but always osmeone available if you need.  All of the diners were there for a long leisurely time. There was no hustle bustle to these meals. It was great.

I'll be back here for sure.
author: Andrea S.

description:
What a hidden gem in SOMA! My bf and I were looking for a place to eat around his place and as novices to the area we looked on yelp and found this place. It's a small little nook by the freeway but has a really classy interior that I was not expecting. 5 stars for that.

The service was also amazing! The waiter (we are convinced he might also be some sort of owner or family member as well) was just wonderful giving us a free sample of his bellini champagne for free to enjoy with our dessert. 5 stars here as well.

The food was great. Their bread they give at the table is so fresh and fluffy and is given with a delicious kalamata olive spread. I love olives so I really enjoyed this. We also got the bruschetta sampler - it had roasted pepper, eggplant and zucchini, and pomodoro (or tomato) bruschetta. It was honestly so delicious. Then we got the spinach and cheese ravioli and this is the only part that wasn't mouth watering. It was still really good, but just not up to the delicious caliber of the rest of the items at the restaurant. Lastly, since it was my boyfriend's birthday, I insisted we get the tiramisu (even though we were stuffed) for dessert, and man, it was good. As I mentioned earlier, our waiter brought us the champagne to accompany and they were just divine together.

We will definitely be going back here often since its only a few blocks from his place.
author: Raina B.

description: I was please with the atmosphere when we walked into La Briciola. The restaurant has a nice cozy layout but the tables aren't right on top of each other which I hate! We started with the bruschetta which was nice although not exactly what I was expecting. There were three different types of bruschetta on the plate, a zucchini, pepperoni and the classic tomato. They were nice, but I would have preferred one piece of the traditional tomato, I don't like my apps to be too big.  We ordered a lovely Italian Pinot Grigio to go with our meal and the server was kind enough to make some menu recommendations to compliment the wine which I thought was a nice touch. I had the ravioli and my husband had the gnocchi. Both were delicious and paired with the wine nicely. We had a lovely dinner and I will be back!
author: WaltzingMatilda T.

description: Second time eating here- super easy access from freeway. Terrific food and service - Giovanni had great recommendations and knows his wines well. I had rack of lamb which was beautifully presented and absolutely melted in my mouth!  My husband had a delicious halibut entree, and our sons ate every bite of their pasta dishes: penne with crab and orecchiette with sausage. We will be back!!
author: Diane C.

description: I love this local dinner spot -- dark, romantic, good service and wine list. My only complaint is the lack of vegetarian options.
author: Kelly S.

description: the seafood is very nice. well cooked with tomato. the pasta is awesome. really a nice place to have dinner. the menu is in italian.
author: Guodong W.

description:
Great neighborhood restaurant!  Found it through yelp when shopping at Westfield mall. I was starving after shopping all day and craving Italian food but did not want to deal with the mediocre and overpriced tourist restaurants at North Beach.

Got to the address which looked quite shady outside, but once you walk in to the restaurant, you are transported to a different world from the gang type characters outside.  People are dressed for dinner.

We arrived around 7pm and were able to get a table without reservation.  Not even 15 minutes later the place was packed and people kept arriving even after 9:30pm.

We ordered wine by the glass and both my friend's Chardonnay and my Cabernet were very good.  

Then we shared Sfogliatine con gamberi e asparagi puff pastry~asparagus~shrimp~crab reduction.  It was delicious but @ $14 it sure needed more than two and I mean only two penny size pieces of shrimp.  The stuffing was purely vegetables.  The crab reduction as well as the puff pastry were delicious.  Next time just add MORE SHRIMP! and it will be perfect.

For my main course I had Straccietti al ragú di agnello hand cut pasta~lamb ragú which was very tasty but not out of this world. $17

My friend had the Rombo all'isolana baked halibut~fresh tomato sauce~olives~sliced potatoes which was absolutely delicious. @ $23 She loved it, I loved it and I plan to go back to get a whole dish to my self!  The portion was big and the fish was cooked perfectly.  Moist and flaky.  The tomato sauce was light and delicious and it did not overwhelmed the fish.  If anything it brought out the natural flavors of the halibut.  So, so good.

Service was perfect.  Friendly, attentive, knowledgeable.  I think he was the part owner people are referring to.  Very smiley and nice.  Threw in a few Italian words here and there so that was perfect too! :)

The dessert was good but nothing amazing. 

The reason I am giving 4 stars is because of the halibut, the service and the so, so , so comfortable ambiance.  I don't usually like sitting at a restaurant for more than an hour and a half without getting antsy, but we were there for 2 and a half hours just talking and enjoying the restaurant and wine.  Not once did they make us feel like we overstayed our welcome :-)

We will definitely be going back and next time I am bringing my honey.

Shared app, two main courses, 2 glasses of wine, two dessert wines, two desserts.  Bill total with tip $135.00
author: Mags P.

description:
I went here during a job interview at about 1:00 p.m. on a weekday.  It was surprisingly empty, which I appreciated.

I had the cheese ravioli with marinara sauce, which was a solid 4 stars.

My interviewer had the veal and seemed to think it was mediocre.

If you work in SOMA, this is a place that's worth checking out a few times.
author: Jason H.

description:
This restaurant was a delight from the start. Very understated decor, and a wait staff with great energy and friendliness. We were a party of 6 - we had great wine, food, and dessert. I had the squash gnocci and it was perfect in texture (not underdone, not too done), with a lovely sage sauce. Other meals I sampled were the lamb ragu, the seafood lasagne, and the tagliatelli porcini. All were very nice. 

For desert our table shared a piece of tiramisu. We had a birthday at the table so the waiter brought it with a candle and sang for us. 

After paying, the waiter also surprised us by bringing us all a small digestif of limoncello on the house! 

We would go back in an instant.
author: Phil L.

description:
Very nice traditional italian restaurant in SOMA.
The food is very good.  I went there with a group of friend. We were 6 and all of us were very happy with our choice. I had the carpaccio and the pasta with truffles. The pasta were just delicious, i strongly recommend.
The service was excellent, all the staff was super friendly.
Very easy street parking (except when there is a Giant game).
author: Delf M.

description:
La Briciola is a lovely place to grab a great Italian dinner in SOMA. A few friends and I visited La Briciola recently for dinner and were fortunate to find this place on short notice - great combination of Open Table (to find a reservation for 6 people with only 30 mins. advance notice on a Friday night), Yelp (to confirm that La Briciola would be a great place to dine), Google Maps to find my way there, and multitasking on my Palm Pre to make it using all of the above so seamless =). The restaurant has a fantastic milieu with lots of light, tall ceilings, and a very cozy feel. Based on my one visit here, La Briciola definitely seems like a hidden gem (i.e., should be packed on a Friday night but still had a couple of open tables). Anyways, onto the review!

First off, even before the food, I must point out that the host / head waiter were both tremendously friendly. In particular, the head waiter was particularly energetic, welcoming, and helpful. If you want to visit an establishment where you truly feel welcome, this is definitely a place to visit.

My meal consisted of delicious bread (with a great olive oil / minced olive dip) and bruschette, Ravioli con pomodoro (spinach and ricotta filled ravioli with basil & fresh tomato sauce), and a fantastic '07 vintage Irony Pinot Noir (we ordered a bottle for the table) that complemented the meal well. Service was reasonably speedy and definitely friendly. Per another reviewer's commentary, this is a traditional Italian restaurant with a menu comprised of first (primi) and second (secondi) courses, so the portions are consequently a little small (my only real reason for giving this place 4 stars instead of 5). 

Another great touch by the restaurant: during our meal, a person at a neighboring table dropped a glass of red wine that shattered, splattering red wine all over my friend's (thankfully black) wool coat. Not only did the staff quickly help dry off her jacket, but they brought our table a complimentary round of dessert wine (possibly Prosecco?) - overall, an extremely kind gesture by them, and one that did not go unnoticed.

All in all, if you're looking for a nice Italian meal (mid-priced), I recommend that you keep La Briciola in the mix.
author: Rishi N.

description: You can tell that every pasta here was made with the effort and the quality of the ingredients is incredible. However, I just can't give this place a five star rating, maybe it was because I'm used to heartier tasting pasta.. but all in all this is just a standard good italian restaurant... we had the recommended lamb ragyu? and the seafood lasagna.. both of which were just good.. their tiramisu is excellent and service push this restaurant to a four star restaurant
author: James H.

description:
My coworkers and I dined here just a few days ago after the ballpark.  One of them wanted to eat Italian, so of course, I yelped it, and what do you know?  This place is pretty close to the ballpark right on 3rd street!  

Now one of my main concerns is how this place looks so unassuming - people pass by this little golden nugget all the time!  Don't be fooled though, it's a wonderful place, but a tad small from how it looks on the outside.  You can easily miss it (we drove by 2x before finally seeing it!).  

After coming in, we were met by a wonderful hostess that accommodated even though we didn't have a reservation (you should put one in, you won't regret it!).  The day we came in was pretty busy because of prom.

The ambiance was pretty good - well lit, tasteful decorations, and a great waiter!  The hostess made sure we were comfortable and extremely friendly.  

The waiter spoke fluent Itallian, and treated us kindly despite the fact that they were going to have a 7:00PM reservation (we arrived a little before 6:00PM).  

We didn't feel rushed, and they even started us off with an appetizer and have I mentioned their toast is to die for?  The appetizer was a different mixture from the original Bruschette assortite instead of the normal zucchini, eggplant, and fresh tomatoes.  It was eggplant, bell peppers, and fresh tomatoes.  I'm not one for bell peppers, but I would make an exception to this one.  The bell peppers were nicely marinated that I could easily eat more of it if I could. 

My group ordered different entrees so we could share:

Ravioli con pomodoro spinach and ricotta filled ravioli~fresh tomato sauce~basil

Straccietti al ragú di agnello hand cut pasta~lamb ragú

Ravioli di cernia seabass filled ravioli~lobster reduction

Farfalle con salmone smoked salmon~peas~brandy reduction 

For dessert we had:
Profitterolles alla vanilla  pastry puff~vanilla ice cream~chocolate

And something that wasn't on the menu, but a special they had for that day:  a chocolate souffle that was similar to a lava cake.

All their food were absolutely divine.  

I highly recommend this place and I can't wait until the next time I stop over for a bite to eat.
author: Nina M.

description:
My husband and I had been meaning to try this place for quite some time as we live very close. Last night we finally went and we were both blown away! 

I would consider myself quite a 'picky' diner, so I do not take 5 stars lightly. The food was truly incredible here - we started with the veggie crepe appetizer (forgive me for not butchering the Italian names) and my husband had the filet minon and I had the lamb ragu for dinner. I totally stuffed myself because I couldn't stop eating - everything was flawless. The service was great - very warm and pleasant - not exactly the same level of service you would get at a pricier restaurant (didn't replace silverware between courses, etc.), but wonderfully charming. They even came and gave me and extra glass of wine toward the end of the night so my husband wouldn't have to 'drink alone'. 

I will definitely be back - YUM!
author: Hilary R.

description:
The place is not in the best of locations. Definitely drive there. 

Service was good. Food was very good but not as good as some of the reviews state. I had the signature homemade pasta with lamb ragu. It definitely needed salt. 

Overall I would go again but not until I tried other places nearby first.
author: Charles P.

description:
I rarely crave Italian food because I always think I can easily make pasta on my own and save some cash, however, everyday I walk past La Briciola and I've been wanting to try it for awhile.  So happy I finally got the chance!

The noodles are wide and cooked really well.  We got the pasta with duck ragu and lamb ragu, they were both good but tasted very similar.  The sauce base was exactly the same but one had duck and the other had lamb.  If you get one, you don't need to get the other.  They are both good though but if you're like me and my bf and you guys like to share plates, get something different.

Next time I'm getting the pasta with porcini mushrooms and truffle oil.

Tiramisu was good but not as good as Pazzia's.

Pastas are about $18-20 and more full meals are about $22-28.
author: Becca L.

description:
The service and bread/tapenade were the best part about the meal.  We had a great waiter who steered us to some delicious wine, but should have strongly discouraged us from the Polpo (octopus) appetizer.  Sadly, the Polpo was pulpy and chewy.  Yuk!  Our waiter was great about replacing the dish and suggested a salmon carpaccio.  It was very tasty, but nothing special.  

For main courses, our waiter suggested we have one of the three homemade pasta dishes so we went with the Tagliolini De Mare.  It wasn't my first choice, but the waiter steered us away from the "dry pasta" options to the fresh.  The seafood was inconsistent.  Some pieces of the calamari were chewy while others were tender.  Again, it was tasty, but nothing special.

We tried to order a sambuca and espresso after the meal, but they don't have a liquor license.   That was too bad!  Our waiter comped us our plain espressos though, which was a nice thing to do. 

Not sure if we need to go back again, although the mussels at the next table sure did smell good!
author: C R.

description:
Staff was excellent
Price excellent
Food very good...,
needs a bit more flavor, but a good value!
author: Ishi M.

description:
Celebrated my boyfriend's birthday here last Friday and it was both our first time, so I was a little nervous and hoped it was as good as the reviews. Well, we had a great experience. We made reservations at 8 pm and were 35 mins late and I thought they would have given our table away, but they didn't. We had a very nice table towards the back, but by a window. The place was full, but we got good service and the waiter was attentive and the food was delicious! We love seafood and brought our own white wine ($20 corkage). Wish they had a bar, though, where you could order cocktails, but they only have wine and beer.
THe bread was nice and warm. We started with the grilled calamari with chickpeas...tender calamari and very tasty....the perfect appetizer! We shared a Caesar salad; it had just the right amount of dressing and Parmesan cheese. I ordered the dish that was like a cioppino ,but with a lighter broth and it was delicious! My boyfriend had the halibut which was baked and very tender and moist. He also enjoyed his dish....he is very picky with seafood and hates overlooked, dry fish, but there were no complaints with this dish!
For desert, they brought a tiramisu with a birthday candle...a nice surprise. We ordered coffee with it and the coffee was good.
I will definely come back....want to taste the other dishes. The price is very reasonable. Make sure you make a reservation, as they can get busy.

Susie Q
author: maria J.

description:
This place was an amazing treasure to find. 

We ordered the Hand Cut Pasta with Lamb Ragu, and the Stewed Rabbit (forgive me for not knowing the Italian names). We also ordered the recommended wines by the glass for each. 

The lamb pasta was everything I dream about when craving a warm, hearty pasta. The noodles were perfectly cooked, made in house, and the sauce was outstanding in flavor and texture. The rabbit was tender, flavorful, and the polenta cakes that came with it were the perfect companion to soak up all the juices. 

The only drawback is that a bachelorette party arrived, and took much of our server's attention. We wouldn't have minded except that neither of us particularly enjoyed the wine, and would have preferred to exchange it. But this wasn't a big issue, just a minor annoyance.

While there we also saw the porcini mushroom truffle dish come out which looked stellar! Will definitely try next time.
author: Belén T.

description:
This is a very cute place that does not look at all like much from the street.  (In fact if you blink, you will totally miss it.)  The interior has a warm and intimate feeling.

The food was very good.  I had the arugula salad starter and pasta with lamb ragu main course.  Both were simple but very well executed.  The fresh pasta was perfectly cooked, and the lamb ragu was savory and flavorful.

Service was also very good--attentive, prompt and great with recommendations for the table.

I will certainly be going back.
author: Jen Y.

description: Been here three times and every time the service is super friendly and welcoming.  The decor is so cute and you wouldn't expect it walking down 3rd Street.  The food is good - not OMG WOW but a solid, enjoyable meal.   Good neighborhood-type restaurant and not too expensive.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Nice restaurant nestled right up against...a liquor store? Oh I love San Francisco. Anyway, went late at night, parking was a piece of cake, but I could see it being difficult earlier in the evening.
Atmosphere was nice, but not pretentious. 
Staff was attentive and fun. 

Bread was AMAZING. Nobody loves freshly baked, still warm, empty carbs more than I. 
Menu is split up into two sections "earth" and "ocean"
I had the Ravioli con pomodoro which were fresh, cooked to perfection and full of flavor. 
The rest of the party had the Insalata della casa (house salad), Filetto con fonduta al tartufo (filet mignon), Ravioli di cernia (seabass ravioli) and the Gnocchi Sorrentina. All were very satisfied. Definitely a place to go back to and explore the menu some more. 
Cheese and salumi plates as well as the lunch menu look quite delicious *drool*
author: Aaron R.

description:
Very out of the way, but VERY worth it.
The walk from Market seems far but I think it's just because it's desolate and dark but that's the price you pay for a complete gem!

Started off with some wine and the Italian cheese plate. Would definitely recommend. The wine list is stellar. The decor is beautiful. Reminded me of Boston's North End but prettier than most inside. This place was way better than anything in SF's North Beach...

The bread and pastas were beyond. My swordfish wasn't my favorite, but I might be spoiled by New England seafood...

Our server was nice, but for whatever reason kept replying to us in Italian or repeating our choices from the menu with proper pronunciation. I understand it wasn't meant to be rude, but I came for dinner, not for a language class... You're wearing Wrangler's, dude. Don't try to teach me proper Italian etiquette when ordering.
author: christine c.

description: Another great find for a very reasonable price Italian Restaurant for a excellent lunch not far from my office in Soma. Their lunch special are very good value and the restaurant feels very cozy. Unfortunately I had to take my lunch on the run, so I order Risotto Allo Scoglio which has a very modest amount of prawns, calamari, whole clams, whole mussels in a very light tomato sauce. Rice was very creamy and was only $14.00!! Very similar to a dish I had in Florence couple of years ago, but you can find it here in Soma!!
author: Wolfy W.

description:
this really is a hole in the wall.  located between the shell station and a pho restaurant sits la briciola.  i would have never batted an eye at this restaurant if a friend's bday was not here.  the decor is simple but the atmosphere warm.  you can forget you are in soma!

we shared an arugula salad.  decent size.  8 of us shared one!  and then most of us had the sea bass ravioli.  i thought it might be weird that it is filled with fish.  but it really is delicious!  the pasta is not paper thin but it is substantial.  the lobster reduction tastes like a rich lobster bisque.  

their tiramisu is also smooth, creamy and delicious.  i must come back to try some other things!
author: claudia y.

description:
Been here 3 times now and my favorite dishes that always are consistently tasty are the Tagliatelle ai porcini e tartufo (wild porcini, truffle pasta) and the Ravioli di cernia (seabass ravioli). Both have great flavor and the sauces are super yummy.

The first time I went there we also had the filet mignon and it was excellent!  Cooked to perfection and the sauce was plate-licking good.  However, the second time we got it, the filet mignon was definitely overcooked and tasted rubbery.

Also, a plus is they have some really great wines and they give you nice and hefty pours :)

I'd definitely go back for the ambiance and for the pastas.
author: Sharon T.

description:
La Briciola is just a few hundred feet from my office.  When I need to have a business meeting over lunch or dinner, La Briciola is an easy, reliable, go to destination.

Considering the part of town it's in - a few blocks on the "less classy" side of SOMA - the food will surprise you.  The pastas is cooked well, and the sauces are neither too heavy nor overwrought.  They have a solid wine list to work from, with some good selections by the glass.

I'm pretty fussy about Italian, and La Briciola delivers consistently good fare at a reasonable price point.  Well done.
author: Ian S.

description:
Eating in SF is always a treat. Eating it expensed is even better. It just screams for my fatty McFat side to come out. And boy, did it ever! 

I ordered the Rombo all'isolana, it was pretty good, the fish was cooked perfectly. (I think pan fired then baked for a bit.) It didn't feel oily and the portion size was perfect. My coworkers got the lasagna, paninini and the client got the chicken. The eater of the lasagna's tummy was really happy afterwards! The panini gobbler, was on a diet... aka did not embrace his fatty side, but still enjoyed it. Our client seemed satisfied with his chicken. He didn't really rave about it. 

BUT. this is where the extra star comes in... the dessert. Yes, we gorged ourselves on desserts for our lunch hour. We had the molten chocolate cake.  Delicious-o doesn't even begin to describe it. The whole thing was still warm so the vanilla ice cream was melting into the cake and mixing with the melted chocolate. (cue the drool)  We also had the tiramisu. Pretty darn good! Lastly, we had the gelato with strawberries, a classically delightful combination. All of us attacked the desserts like we were playing a game of hungry hungry hippos. I'm not sure who won, but we all left a winner. 

Additionally, because of all the sugar! I didn't experience any side affects of food coma. Thank you La Bricola for a great lunch! I recommend this place to anyone and everyone!
author: Amy W.

description:
Service was excellent, food was "meh."  Huge disappointment as we consciously chose this spot based on Yelp reviews.  We ordered two dishes on the menu that fellow Yelpers highly recommended and we were sadly disappointed.  

Bread and olive tapenade:  The fresh baked white bread was good although a bit on the yeasty side.  It paired nicely with the olive tapenade which I thought was a nice change of pace from the usual serving of olive oil found in most other places.

"Cesare" salad:  I'll admit that I'm a bit of a Caesar snob and that I understand Caesar salad isn't a truly from Italy, but regardless, if it's on your menu it should reflect flavors indicative of a caesar dressing  such raw garlic, tart lemon juice, salty anchovy, olive oil, parmesan and ground pepper...WE TASTED NOTHING EVEN CLOSE TO THIS....The romaine was chopped nearly to shreds as though it could have been used to dress an order of tacos (caesar salad romaine is chunky not shredded).  There was way too much cheese on the plate as if the cheese WAS the dressing.  The croutons weren't very flavorful.  This entire salad reminded of something I would eat at an outdoor family picnic, bagged lettuce and Kraft dressing from a bottle...

Sea-bass ravioli:  This dish was just okay.  I was excited to see nice chunks of lobster meat in the sauce, only to discover that they were overcooked and rubbery.  The sea-bass filling inside the ravioli felt a little pasty as well.  

Tagliatelle with porcini and truffles:  The mushroom sauce was very tasty and the homemade pasta noodles were decent, but for this price they should've been better.  What screwed up this dish was that the star of the plate (the porcini) was undercooked and there were exactly 0 truffles in the dish, only truffle flavored oil.  Don't call out black truffles in the title of the dish if there aren't any.   A few pieces of the mushroom "cubes" were nicely sauteed and had a melt in your mouth quality, but the majority of the mushrooms were hard and rubbery, like eating chicken gizzards. Had they been sauteed just a couple of minutes longer, the dish would've been a hit.  

We will not be returning. I'm also disappointed that so many "locals" raved about this place and the food was bleh...Either they don't know good food or they have the worst palates ever...
author: Cat L.

description: The service was outstanding, but the food was all over the map.  The appetizers were all great (best spinach salad, ever; soup also awesome), but the mains ranged from good (ravioli and halibut) to OK (mixed grill was overcooked) to barely edible (that tasted like Uncle Ben's rice, not squid ink risotto), the deserts were nothing special, and the coffee tasted like water.  I will not be back for such "hit and miss cuisine" since the bill came to 220 for 4 and we only had 1 bottle of wine.
author: Mark B.

description:
We have been to La Briciola several times.  We love it. Food is soooo delicious.
All the pasta is homemade and cooked perfectly.  Sauces to die for!!!  Seafood with the pasta is my personal favorite.  Oh, and did I mention the desserts?  The Panna cotta with the cherry sauce; good good!
The wait staff could not be more professional or knowledgable about the menu.   For us, it's like an inexpensive little trip to Italy.
author: Janet B.

description: The best part about this place was the atmosphere- perfect for a date night. The food was good but the service could use improvement. The meal was poorly paced- very rushed in the beginning but then our waiter seemed to disappear. Would probably come back based on the overall experience but definitely has room for improvement.
author: Katelynn A.

description:
A solid italian restaurant that impressed with their food, but I wasn't a fan of the atmosphere, it was too "normal" for my taste.

The Seabass Ravioli w/ Lobster was awesome, and I would get it again in a heartbeat.
author: Eric A.

description:
It was my turn to choose a restaurant and the Yelp reviews of La Braciola made this sound like a great choice (full disclosure: we couldn't get an 8:30 reservation at La Ciccia). The meal wasn't horrible and I would give it an extra half star if I could but it wasn't all that good either. In a city of great dining options a place like this will suffer from comparisons to great restaurants.

We arrived in SOMA at 8:30 and the place was practically empty. There were exactly 8 other people in there. An empty restaurant is such a dreary experience for me. The place itself is nice if not a bit sparsely decorated. The wait staff were attentive and friendly but then again what else did they have to do?

The menu is huge and I took a long time to decide because oddly enough none of it seemed all that original or interesting. Their wine list is equally big featuring many Italian selections. 
We began with the lamb ragu. It was watery and the ground lamb was hard to taste. Ragu (of anything) should be rich and savory but this one was very bland. What a disappointment since we actually ordered the wine based on this dish.

I had the involtino di pesce spada (swordfish stuffed with mascarpone and zucchini served with a tomato sauce). It was the most original thing on the menu and despite my negative reaction whenever seafood is mixed with cheese (crab being the exception!) I went for it. It was okay but this yelp review is now the only reason I will remember it. The vegetables/potatoes on the side were better than the main dish. The potatoes were roasted with salt and garlic; they were delicious and I could eat a plate of them!

My friend had the Ravioli di cernia (seabass filled ravioli). We both thought they were just so-so.

We ended with a tiramisu and it was the highlight of the meal (other than the wine!).

I give them credit for being a pioneer establishment down in lonely SOMA. I hope they improve.
author: Rob C.

description:
It's far from awesome, but it does have the benefit of being remarkably quiet (at least it is at lunchtime) so you can actually have a conversation with a group of people without having to raise your voice over loud music or other noise.
The food was pleasant enough, and the portions are sensibly-sized, rather than the giganto-epic gutbusters that many Italian restaurants in the area dish up. I had the Penne Pasticciate, which was OK - but hardly anything to write home about. The ground beef used in the ragu was a bit hamburgery, but it was perfectly edible.
author: John D.

description: Based on the numerous good reviews on yelp, I decided to try out this restaurant with two friends. Sadly, the service was slow and not friendly at all (despite the restaurant not being overly busy). The food was mediocre at best and my friend's filet mignon was definitely not cooked to his order. So overall, I would NOT recommend going to this place at all.
author: Steffen B.

description: I've eaten at this restaurant several times and have recommended this establishments  over 10 times.   I hate to give it 2 stars but the service and food have gone down over the last 2 years.  I made a reservation at 9pm on a Saturday, after waiting 30 minutes to be seated we then waited another 20 minutes to order.   The food arrived hot, good, but was bland lacked flavor and seasoning, bad.
author: Dionne M.

description:
I had an hour to find a restaurant that had:

- A table for 8
- Prices that averaged around or below $20
- Enough variety to satisfy a party of picky eaters and vegetarians

I'm glad I found La Briciola because it was excellent. The ambiance was pleasant and our server was attentive. We somehow were one of 3 parties there that had a birthday and the waiter took care of a special tiramisu with a candle.

The food was excellent as well. Our menu included:

Bruschetta: 3 kinds on the plate: tomato, zucchini and eggplant, and sauteed red pepper. All very good

Battered and fried vegetables: Kind of like a tempura.

A bottle of Montepulciano d'Abruzzo: Spicy and reasonably priced at $36. 

Risotto with calimari, ink sauce, and a scallop: The scallop was browned and pan seared, cooked perfectly. The ink sauce was peppery and rich, although the calimari wasn't the absolute best I've ever had but it was still quite good.

Gnocchi with cheese sauce:  Just the name of it screams 'order this dish' and it didn't disappoint.

Pasta with pesto sauce: I loved how the pesto sauce wasn't completely pureed. They left a lot of the the basil in larger shreds and it had a great fresh basil flavor.

The tiramisu had a strong orange flavor which some of the group liked, some of the group didn't care for. I was in the liked it group.

Good cappuccino.
author: rob. l.

description: I met a friend who came in from out of town here. We were seated right away even though we arrived a few minutes early for our Friday night reservation. We got some drinks and were left alone so we could start to catch up and we were not hassled to place our food order right away. After two rounds of drinks we finally settled on what to order. Our food was delicious. We got so caught up in our conversations that we did not realize how late it was and that they were getting ready to close. At no point though did we feel like we had to get out of there. I will definitely come back again.
author: Emily L.

description:
Cute place but it looks a little unfinished and empty.  
Service is helpful but definitely more salesly than friendly.
The food was great but WHY DID YOU PUT OUR DELICIOUS HOT FOOD ON COLD PLATES????  
Seriously... that is such a rookie move.  Our food got so cold SO fast that it made our tasty entrees (the crab ravioli were fantastic, when warm) become more of a bummer.  i have never eaten a restaurant entree so fast, just to enjoy the last bits of warmness before it cooled off completely.  
Not sure if I'll go back anytime soon because the wine prices were a little high and the plates were FREEZING COLD.
author: Plaid B.

description:
THe best Italian place in SF,  best Italian place Ive had in the US.

good dishes, great staff.

I will go there again and again
author: Scott C.

description:
well lets just say this was a 0 star non-dining experience. 

this is how it all started. me and a couple of friends were in the area on a Friday night. after trying to go to two other restaurants we decided to call to get a reservation. the question that we asked was "do you have any reservations for tonight" their response was "yes at 8 okay" that was only in half an hour and we were around the corner so we went.  we got there about 15 minutes early which was just fine by us. we sat at the bar and just waited. there were 3 of us and they had 3 tables with 4 seats each open. so we waited and waited. got a bottle of wine and waited. they kept telling us just a few more minutes so it was okay. a few people came in and were sat. just a few. so of the 3 open tables, there was still 1 table left open for 4 people.

 well after waiting until 8:20 (and being there since 7:45) we saw them move one fo the tables for 4 to a two top and they let the couple that came in after us sit and get served. after realizing that they had no intentions of letting us dine there, we decided to go. we told the server to just bring us our check. his response was a very enthusiastic yes! wow..... so we were there for over 30 minutes and the second we ask for the check they are too excited to see us leave. okay i see how it is. 

the bartender then  came to us and said "oh why are you leaving" well, we are hungry and we are getting absolutely no service and the server was way to quick to just let us go. he then said that we did not call for a reservation and that they value people who book on open table more than the ones that call in directly and that we had to wait.  unacceptable. if you did not  have a reservation available then dont tell us that you do. we would not have come in and waited. if the restaurant was packed i would totally understand having to wait. but it was not. there were 3 empty tables up until the second we said we wanted to go. 

horrible horrible horrible horrible service and i can not believe that they would treat us with such disrespect. i guess we were just a few shades too dark to be waited on...oh well. we gave our money to somebody who actually appreciated us.
author: Ashley H.

description: Great little Italian spot in SOMA. I met a family friend here for dinner and enjoyed some a few glasses of red wine, delicious baretta, arugula salad with the gnocchi for dinner. Everything was very full of flavor and tasty. It was a great spot to kick back and talk over dinner. I would go back again for sure.
author: Shanna T.

description:
I went here at lunch the other day and ordered what I typically use as my measuring-stick dishes for Italian food in the city: Penne Bolognese and a salad of some sort (usually a caprese, but this time I opted for a caesar). The results were more than satisfactory, in fact the food was really really good! The only reason I won't give this place a 5 star review is because I don't think that such a sharp increase in prices for dinner is warranted, but that is truly picking nits. The conclusion you should come to after reading this review is that La Briciola is a superior restaurant that is not in North Beach. A true gem in SOMA. 

I'm looking forward to my next lunch there!
author: Peter F.

description:
Went here before a MOMA event last night and was quite disappointed.  

The crepe appetizer was a good start.  Although it was stuffed with an ordinary array of veggies like carrots and broccoli, the rich porcini cream sauce with a drizzle of truffle oil had a nice earthiness and was enough to carry the dish.

The gnocchi in the next course missed the mark because they were too large and doughy.  The cream sauce was also uninspiring.  If you happen to come to La Briciola (which I don't recommend) and get the gnocchi (also not recommended) I would split the dish.  I'd say it's too heavy for most people to enjoy themselves.

The main dish was the real bummer.  Veal pounded thin and rolled with spek (a type of prosciutto) and fontina cheese.   The only real flavor of the plate came from a thick, floury white wine sauce that tasted like it  was born of a dry soup mix.  The side was a reincarnation of the same ordinary veggies found in the crepe: a sad little pile of roasted carrots, broccoli and potato.  The whole thing looked and tasted like it came from a hospital cafeteria.  The only difference was that it cost $24.

The service was a bit slow because the place was full.  The waiter was  friendly enough but seemed in over his head.  He was also the type of guy who made sure to throw in an Italian word with every sentence - I guess he thought it was charming.  Like when ever he said "Thank You" he followed it with "Grazie"; whenever he said "Enjoy" then came "Buon Appetito".  Seemed forced to me, especially since he didn't have an Italian accent when he spoke English.  

There have to be better places in the area to go.
author: Adam A.

description:
La Briciola (crumb, in Italian) is a nice little place with a distinctive Tuscan/Umbrian feel. The staff are attentive but not intrusive, the food is excellent, and the ambiance is simple and pleasant. We had the Carpaccio antipasti (true and excellent), the Straccietti with lamb ragu as primi (truly wonderful), and the rabbit and rack of lamb as secondi (staying to form with Tuscan tradition, these were great). Our son had the grilled mixed seafood plate, which was also quite good. Add a Nebbiolo from Piemonte and the meal was complete.

This was a birthday meal for our son, but we'll be back soon whether it's for another family dinner out or a business dinner where I want a quiet conversation in a slightly out of the way place.
author: Douglas K.

description:
Avoid the gnocchi -- if gnocchi are usually little pillows of wonderfulness, these are memory-foam/Temperpedic pillows -- the ones that really HURT when somebody whacks you with one in a pillow fight.   

Gnocchi are the reason I'm giving 3 stars and not 4.  OTHERWISE La Briciola is a very solid neighborhood restaurant (and I'm super glad it's in my neighborhood) -- it's a great choice if you're in the mood for pasta but you don't feel like dealing with all the various hassles of North Beach.  

Ambiance is especially nice -- welcoming decor, great staff, excellent service.  Our server was very knowledgeable about the wine list and helped us pick out an interesting Italian wine (otherwise with Italian wine I have to kind of point randomly at something and hope it's good).  

Food is competently prepared, well seasoned, and super reasonably priced for the quality.  The pastas (apart from those gnocchi!!) are good although I can't say great.  Definitely worth checking out if you're in the neighborhood!
author: Jaina S.

description: Great food. Perfect flavor. Service was slow, but pleasantly so. Got the risotto with saffron, which was had great texture and consistency.
author: Geoffrey H.

description: I love this restaurant -- have been to Italy half a dozen times and this is authentic Tuscan food as I understand it.  Everything we had was amazing, especially the cold cuts appetizer, which is hard to find of that quality in the city.  Service is great too.
author: Soma C.

description:
Very small portions. $22.50/person
The 6 of us had McDonalds after

I had the sea bass ravioli with lobster reduction- 2.5/5, i felt gross after eating it, don't know why.
My bf had the mushroom pasta with truffle oil - 2.5/5, a very boring /dull dish

One good thing is its very easy to find parking around there.
author: Cindy L.

description:
My new favorite Italian spot!

I was looking for an Italian place in SOMA and by recommendation from someone, i decided to try this place out. The service was great! My friends and I didn't have reservations or anything, but they were able to accommodate us on a busy Saturday night. 

This place is a great spot for a date. The decor and ambiance was very cute had that warm feeling to it. The food was delicious! I ordered the shrimp and broccoli pasta and it was amazing. I really just picked that randomly from the menu because i was indecisive and didn't know what i wanted to order. We all shared a few bites from each others plates and we were all very happy.

I definitely recommend this spot to everyone.
author: Rosalynn D.

description:
I've dined at Briciola twice so far and each experience and each bite keeps on getting better and better. The Torinian owner and his staff make people feel at home, as if we were in "Mama's kitchen" - The food is delicious. I've tried the lamb ragu, some of their salads, a few appetizers - their zucchini appetizer is to die for! 

I totally recommend this restaurant if you're going on a date or if you're going to throw a big birthday party for a friend - it's just perfect.

The ambience is gorgeous, the candle-lit room is calming and the integrated arches make for a wonderfully aesthetic dining experience.

This is my first Yelp review. I was so blown away by the food, service and experience, that I just had to share it with the Yelp community!

Now, go eat!
author: Adriana G.

description:
3.5 stars

This is a nice addition to the SOMA restaurant map.  I had walked by La Bricola several times and thought to myself this is an odd spot for an Italian place, half a block away from the freeway overpass and not much else around.  My party arrived at about 10:30 p.m. on a Wednesday for a late dinner.  The dinner was great and I would go back for sure.

Like many other San Francisco noveau Italian places (SPQR-A16-54 Mint), La B uses fresh local ingredients in their cooking.  You can really taste the freshness in all the dishes.

We started with a round of appetizers.  The ministroni soup topped off with some shaved parmasan was good.  I took a bite of my friend's caesar salad and though that they could tweak the dressing a bit to add more of an anchovy taste.  The brushetta was excellent - in particular the porcini mushrooms were a nice complement to the traditional tomato and basil flare.  Another friend ordered a trio of raw fish - salmon, halibut, and swordfish - was tasty but I think the Japanese got the Italians beat when it comes to raw fish.  Lastly, the beef carpaicio was tasty and went well with the basil and shaved Parmesan.

For our pasta course - I had the ravioli stuffed with sea bass - this dish was the highlight of the entire meal.  The sea bass was not drowned out by the other flavors or the creamy lobster reduction sauce.  A must.  I also sampled some squid ink linguine with fresh squid which was also great if you are a fan of the ink.  For vegetarians, try the pesto linguine with roasted potatoes, cut green beans, and asparagus - the pesto was excellent.

Our second course was not as impressive as the pasta.  I ordered the filet.  I found it to be a bit bland  The portion was large - 10 onces at least.  I would have much rather prefferred a smaller more flavorful portion.  My friend ordered the lamb chops which were much better.
To be honest, I could have easily stopped eating after the pasta course and that is probably what I would do in the future.  

The  wine list is also excellent and reasonably priced.  We had two bottles for just under 100 bucks.  The 2005 Brancaia Italian (Tuscany) Red "Tre" was excellent.  It was smooth and went well with our appetizers and pasta.  The next bottle was an Alexander Valley Cab Franc which was a pretty standard cab - good but not as good as our first.

All and all, I would go back for sure would stick to the pasta and appetizers.
author: Moe J.

description: La Briciola is a classic lesson in not judging a book by its cover.  We were walking the neighborhood one afternoon, and due to long lines at another restaurant, decided to make a change of plans.  Seeing an Italian restaurant, my hungry fiancee strongly suggested that we go to La Briciola--I was hesitant due to the exterior look of the place, but sure enough, as is the case approximately 97% of the time, my fiancee was right.  Once you get inside La Briciola, you can tell that the place is special.  The service is welcoming, and the interior feels more like Italy than SOMA.  Every course we ordered (salad, pasta, entree) was outstanding for both of us, and the prices (especially for lunch) were fantastic.  I'm really glad we stumbled into this spot.
author: Ty D.

description: This place is a gem. I really loved their food. Reason why it's not five stars is because the service wasn't the best and the location was a bit odd. I will definitely come back. Love their bread with real olives with olive oil (the best!). I wanted to take that home with me. The food was good but I mostly remember the olives with the olive oil. Yum!!!
author: Care O.

description:
I have to say the service was AMAZING AMAZING!!!  Shortly after sitting down, a very stunning waitress came and took our order, a few minutes later, a dish came to the table that neither my friend or I ordered, we were perplexed. We asked the waitress about it, and it was "on the house". What a nice surprise!!
but...the food was just ok, I was so sad! My steak was overcooked and tough, and our pasta was not that tasty. I would have loved to give them a 5 star rating just on service alone, but had to be honest about the food.

I was very excited to try out a neighborhood Italian place, but was sadly disappointed. Pazzia is still my favorite "go to" Italian restaurant for the hood.
author: rebecca c.

description:
I'm a super picky eater, almost to the point of annoyance. To further complicate things, I'm also a vegetarian. Dining out can be a challenge - especially with this perplexing trend among SF restaurants of serving all types of offal, hooves, snouts and whatnot on their fancy ass foodie menus. My god, it's the stuff of nightmares! But I digress.

Not so at La Briciola. I was delighted to see a ricotta and spinach stuffed ravioli on the menu served with a simple tomato sauce. HEAVENLY.  The sauce was perfectly balanced to bring out the flavor of the tomatoes without relying on too much salt.  A pet peeve of mine is over-salted sauces. Allow the fresh ingredients to sing on their own without relying too much on the salt shaker -- and that is exactly what La Briciola does.  The dish made me very happy.

The service is excellent with the owners tending to your every need and making you feel welcome. A warm and inviting atmosphere soothes and refreshes after a hectic day.   You can't help but live it up in there and drink too much wine - it's a fun place.  After the bliss of copious wine, good food and company, I think I remember ordering dessert. Something creamy and made of burnt caramel, but the details escape me.  I am positive I ate the whole thing and liked it.

They have a ghost in the restaurant too!  And no, that's not the wine speaking.  Go see for yourself.
author: Lulu C.

description:
I took a chance on La Briciola for a work lunch with six colleagues. The other reviews looked good, so it seemed like a good bet.

The food is tasty, but the service still needs some work--at least during lunch hours. I called the day before to see if we needed to make a reservation, and I was told no. When we arrived, the staff seemed a little overwhelmed to see us. There was a long gap of time between when the first and last person were served--which was a little awkward for our group.

The Seabass Ravioli is very good, as well as the Sogliola Alla Mugnaia (Petrale Sole). The portions tend to be on the smaller side. Be sure to ask for bread when you order--they might forget to bring it out.
author: Jane R.

description:
We had a really hard time deciding on this rating. After all, if this place was in San Mateo or Oakland, it'd easily be four stars. 

But let's forget about our self-indulgent rating system... let's talk food. The food here was fantastic. A had the tagliatelle while K had the clam linguine (her favorite). Both very good.

We can't really remember much more about the meal. We just know we had a good time and we'd come back again. On second thought, maybe we just had too much wine...
author: Kel S.

description:
Solid 4 star restaurant.  

"Gem" is absolutely the right word to describe this place, which is almost underneath the Bay Bridge approach.  It's cute, cozy, smells good when you walk in the door... all very welcoming.  

The food is good.  Well prepared and presented, with appropriate portions.  My roommate and I started with the burrata, which comes with the-perfect-amount-of-saltiness-and-sprinkles-of-basil cheese, a small arugula salad, and a couple slices of prosciutto.  It was totally awesome and obviously right up my alley.

For entrees, I had the Straccietti al ragú di agnello (lamb).  The lamb ragu sauce was great- lamby, gamey and rich- and wasn't too salty.  The pasta was for the most part very well cooked, but there were a couple pieces of fused, semi-hardened chunks indicative of the pasta having been cooked and recooked.  Well worth $17.

My roommate had the Risotto al nero di seppia calamari, with ink sauce and a scallop.  The presentation on this dish far exceeded that of my dish, but we both remarked on how large the portion size was.  Nevertheless, quantity did not come at the price of quality.  The dish was extremely flavorful and at least the roomie says the seafood tasted very fresh.  I might have to order this at some point.  Again, well worth $18.

The service was good, and our waiter kindly waived their $18 corkage, which resulted in him getting a slight more generous tip.  Thank you for that.  The wine list is decently sized but not terribly impressive.  For my price point, lots of super-common $10 retail bottles listed at $38.  Bring your own bottle, and maybe they'll waive the corkage, or maybe they won't.  But it will still be a better deal.

I'm looking forward to coming back here.
author: Karla R.

description:
"The saffron wasn't yellow!" - the quote that we left on our check.

* * *

We went to La Briciola with my mother and sister tonight - frankly, it was a mixed experience: 2.5 stars.

To begin we ordered two appetizers to share, the "fagottino ripieno" (vegetable filled crepe) and the "tagliere di salumi" (a salami plate / antipasto), and both were quite good. High marks for the appetizers.

Of the four entrees, two were very good, the "agnello al brunello" (rack of lamb, medium rare) and the "grigliata mista di pesce" (various fish and seafood). One was only so-so, the "straccietti al ragú di agnello" (lamb ragu), with the flavor of the lamb completely disguised by the sauce. Unfortunately, had it been hamburger I doubt we would've known the difference.

It was the fourth entrée, though, that was really troubling. We ordered the "paccheri con gamberi e broccholi" (paccheri pasts with shrimp and saffron sauce), but what came out was the "paccheri con salsiccia e rape" (paccheri pasta with sausage). The server quickly recognized the error - perhaps it was not the first time? - and whisked away the plate. 

The plate was returned in just a few minutes, this time with shrimp. In retrospect, it should've been amazing that they cooked new pasta so quickly, but we didn't figure it out until the end of the meal - finding a few small pieces of sausage at the bottom of the plate and realizing that the "saffron sauce" had been white, not yellow! 

When we asked the server directly whether the pasta had not actually been prepared with a saffron sauce, whether anything had gone awry, he went to great lengths to tell us that it had (and not to eat a saffron sauce that isn't yellow - whoops!). Now, obviously the staff was in a tough spot - other entrees had already been served when the error was discovered, including medium rare rack of lamb, but it doesn't seem right to deceive one's customers.

We still coughed up $125, but the meal didn't seem quite as worth it afterward.
author: Michael F.

description: My husband and I love italian food and this restaurant will be in the list of our recommended spots to friends who are visiting SF. Great wine list and authentic italian dishes! One more nice thing, it's in our hood so we will be coming back often.
author: Danee P.

description:
I have never even seen this place! But I was craving Italian, wanted to try something different and wanted something in SOMA. LA BRICIOLA came up and decided to give it a try. 
They were very welcoming, accommodated my friend and I to sit further in the back, very cozy and pleasant. 
The waiter was very helpful and the staff was never late refilling our water glasses. 
We ordered a couple pasta dishes, they were very tasty and the pasta was delish! 
Will be back for sure!
author: Priscilla E.

description:
OMG!! Go here! A lot! The food is amazing. I wasn't adventerous and had the lamb ragu. It was top quality. The service was very friendly and genuine.
The do charge by the glass for iced tea and didn't give me a spoon to stir with.
So, why stars? 2 words. Birth Day. Nearly every single time I go out to eat, someone has a birthday and inflicts that stupid song on all the other patrons. Can't we eat in peace? This ain't Chuck E. Cheese folks, grow  up. 
Other than that, the place was amazing.
author: Greg H.

description: A great place for Birthday party or to take your girl. The food its really italian style and great wine list, try the Caiarossa wine or the Sapaio from Tuscany really amazing wine .. The food The meat and the fish are great, so depend of you, i love the steak but even the grill fish are amazing.. Enjoyed and have fun ,cheers
author: Cris V.

description:
Every dish we got was DELICIOUS! A lucky find :)  My former coworkers and I got together for dinner in the city tonight (gosh, I miss them so much!). I arbitrarily picked a place near the Caltrain station - who would have thought it would be so amazing?! 

We started off with a bottle of Pinot Noir and warm bread dipped in garlic, sundried tomato and olive oil. The dipping sauce was seriously addictive and the bread was perfectly crunchy on the outside and soft and moist on the inside.

T got the mushroom tagliatelle with white truffle oil. The flavor of the truffle oil was 'mouthgasmic.' (Oddly, I was eating truffle oil last night with mac n' cheese. It's been a truffle oil start to the week!)

I ordered the lamb ragu, having been convinced by the yelpers calling it out as "the thing to get." It really was very enjoyeable, rich and tomatoey, but still not nearly as good as that dang truffle oil.

N, who is apparently now vegetarian (when did this happen??), opted for the baked veggies antipasti. Very rich, delicious but probably best shared.

Finished off the meal with a traditional tiramisu with fresh cut strawberries.

Thanks guys for hanging. I miss you and everyone else :( :( :(
author: Samantha C.

description:
I know... I know....

I probably should have gone somewhere new for italian.  I'm still a relative virgin on the fine italian dining experience but hey... why leave something that you KNOW is good?

Came back, and brought the woman again.  Started with a different salad this time... wish i rememebered the details, but it was spinachy with some cheese crumpled about.  Delicious.

Owner actually recognized me from last time (+1 wohoo!) and dropped by with a small bruschetta.  TASTY! It worked, next time I'll probably start with that.

For dinner I went with the gnochhi while the girl had a meatless ravioli (hopeless I know)

the gnocchi came out in a bubbling brothing ceramic plate (+1 for the plating) and was melty gooey and tasty.  They had walnuts in the sauce, which was new for me.  I won't lie, there might have been a little too much cheese for me (probably my attempts at weight loss talking here).

The raviloi was spinach and riccota (i think...) and though they HAD an awesome veal raggu sauce on the menu, my gf went vegetarian.  It was tasty, but personaly i think the veal sauce woudl have tied it all together.

The Tiramasu and dessert wine were just mean.  My gf ordered it while I was in the bathroom (i don't usually eat dessert), and it was a torturously delicious experience.  Every bite i said "no more", and then had more.  Moist, flaverful, this wasn't your typical stuff.

I still love this place and the ambiance.  I'll keep coming again and again :)
author: Joseph F.

description:
I'm giving La Briciola 4 stars: 3.5 stars for the food and 4.5 stars for the service.

I liked the ambiance inside this place, even though the location isn't great. We had read that if you mention Yelp, they give you a free appetizer. We were really eyeing the Burrata, and were thrilled when the waiter (possibly the owner?) let us choose any appetizer from the menu for the complimentary appetizer.

As there were 4 of us, we ended up ordering 2 bottles of wine: a $28 SanGiovese and a $33 Chardonnay. I thought the SanGiovese was really good, though it was a bit warm (as a result of it being hot that day?).

We ended up all ordering pastas and sharing them family-style. We ordered:

* Risotto alla monferrina arborio (rice, sausage, saffron). Not sure why, but I didn't really like this dish much. The sausage pieces seemed a bit too large and the taste wasn't that great.

* Tagliolini di mare (mussels, clams, calamari, shrimp, cherry tomatoes). I thought this was the best dish from the four we tried. The seafood was good, and the pasta noodles were extremely fresh, not to mention the great taste.

* Ravioli di cernia seabass filled (ravioli, lobster reduction). This was the dish that I ordered, and I thought it was a little bit too salty for my liking, though the raviolis were clearly fresh.

* Straccietti al ragú di agnello (hand cut pasta, lamb ragú). This was my 2nd favorite dish. I'm not a lamb fan, but the taste was actually pretty decent; not very lamby. The hand-cut pasta, though, was phenomenal.

For dessert, we ordered a bowl of strawberries with gelato (Fragole con gelato) and some chocolate lava cake (not on the menu). Nothing special to report on the desserts. The lava cake was actually baked all the way through; the lava didn't "flow", so to speak.

Overall, the food was just okay, but I really liked the atmosphere and though the service was pretty good.
author: John C.

description:
My friends and I had high expectations upon eating here for the first time, given the rave reviews.  The evening started off well, with pleasant and attentive service.  However, upon ordering, we were told that one of the dishes - the pesto gnocchi - was unavailable that evening.  To compensate, we were given an order of bruscetta to compensate.  

It took quite a while for the food to come - over an hour.  We also noted that almost every table in the restaurant was experiencing the same - everyone had drinks and bread (some had their salads) but other than that, no main courses.

In terms of food quality, it was hit or miss.  My Caesar salad had no dressing, and my main dish, the gnocchi with marinara, tasted watered down.  By that I mean that the marinara sauce was bland - no tomato taste, no bite.  Additionally, the mozarella cheese was rubbery, as though it had been reheated one too many times.  However, one of my friends had the lobster ravioli, which turned out well.

It's entirely conceivable that the evening we were there was a fluke, given the odd behavior.  However, the (lack of) quality of the food compounded with the pricing means that I unfortunately won't be returning to this restaurant.
author: Emerald N.

description:
I love any place that is one block from work, and takes reservations. Tuesday evening at 6pm. There were enough patrons for a weekday and I enjoyed that it wasn't too loud or busy as I was meeting up with a friend and wanted to catch up.

Down and dirty we ordered food. Seafood ravioli and sausage/saffron risotto. Both were hearty, tasty, and filling. No frills place. Great service. Get it done here!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Happier than happy here! Was searching yelp frantically for a nice, but not super high priced, restaurant to take my mom to when La Briciola popped up with so many great reviews that I felt confident trying it tonight. And I'm soooo glad we did!!! My mom was very impressed as well and her boyfriend commented that it has the ambiance and feel of an intimate New York restaurant, which I agree with.

Located in an area that I wouldn't normally venture to for dinner, which is also nice - to get out of the crowds, the rut and easily find street parking! This is a hidden gem. The service was spectacular. Our waitperson was attentive, Italian, polite and cute to boot.

The food was scrumptious. The caesar dressing was very good but I often forget to ask for dressing on the side as I don't like as much as restaurants tend to add. Mom and I split this and the steamed mussels and clams dish which was so good that I asked for a spoon to finish the broth. Her boyfriend had the warm seafood salad which was also spectacular - I ate most of that as well. I don't usually like calamari but the dressing and shaved fennel left my palate begging for more. He also had the chickpea, broccoli, sausage soup and after I tasted it I almost locked him in the bathroom so i could finish it.

Dessert was ice cream with espresso and out of this world, even though it seems so simple. 

I will definitely eat here again and recommend it to others. The menu is so substantial that we had a hard time deciding which delicious thing to order.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Nice simple elegant decor. Traditional style menu with Apps, First Course, Second, and Dessert. You can pick and choose "from the earth" or "ocean" menus to whatever pleases your palette. 

My friends and I came here for a large birthday party. There was a mix up with another smaller party sitting at our table and we were waiting outside wondering when we would be seated. Finally the waiter realized they weren't the right party and kindly asked that party to move to another table. 

It was also a rare super hot night in SF and with no AC in the restaurant, needless to say, we were all drenched in sweat. Yes, kind of gross, but there was nothing we could do about it except ask for more ice water. Lots of ice. Nonetheless, "the food was quite exquisite." lol...

- Swordfish: firm, rolled w/ zuccini, shrimp, tomatoes, good flavor
- Seabass Ravioli: yummy! i only had a bite, but it was good
- Lamb Ragu Pasta: delicious! fresh pasta, tender flavorful lamb
- Filet Mignon: nice cut, tender, the meat itself was not that flavorful, but the sauce was really good & black truffles are always good!
- 2003 Trebbiano Le Crete, Veneto: excellent, slightly sweet, mildly acidic

Service was very accommodating and friendly to our large party. We kept adding more and more people to our party and they didn't make a fuss about moving tables whereas other restaurants would have simply said no. We did take up half the restaurant and it wasn't too busy for a Friday night. The food timing was good and all came out at once, besides one dish that came out much later. Overall great experience minus the heat.
author: Linda C.

description:
I liked the atmosphere, decor, and service at La Briciola.  The location is a bit odd - you sort of need to be going there specifically, otherwise you'd probably never end up there.  I would go there if in the neighborhood, but may not go out of my way to get here.  

They bring bread to the table accompanied by a very delicious olive oil with minced olives.  The bread was just okay but the oil was great!  There were four of us and we started with the caesar salad and the spinach salad.  The caesar was tasty and nicely dressed.  The spinach had a lemony vinagrette and honeyed walnuts and a touch of crumbled goat cheese.  I thought both salads were good.

For main courses, we had the seared tuna, two roasted chickens, and the halibut.  The tuna was very nicely done - served rare with a sesame crust.  The halibut was tasty but I thought it was slightly overcooked.  The chicken was flavorful but came with plain broccoli and roasted potatoes which were ice cold on both plates.  The waiter brought additional hot broccoli and potatoes when we pointed this out.  

Overall, I thought the food was good but not extraordinary.  We were served complimentary glasses of peach prosecco which was delicious (and not on the menu).
author: Carrie L.

description:
I recommended this place for my boss to try and he came back saying the food was wonderful. We had a team lunch the next week and I completely agree with the boss. I don't have many cravings for Italian food, but I really enjoyed the food here. very flavorful and filling. would definitely come back on any occasion to eat their yummy food. 

so far I've had the gnocchi with duck ragu and the pennette al granchio con la rucola (shreaded crab penne in a lobster reduction)...uber yummy!
author: Nhu T.

description:
When you walk in Briciola you immediately fall in love. The ambiance, the service, and just the love you receive throughout the night from the owner of the place who goes out of his way to make you feel like family. This place just opened and half the patrons that walked in were greeted by first name and a big hug....love it. The owner as well as most of the servers have thick Italian accents which only adds to the overall experience. 

Beyond the service I was really happy with their wine selection, the bread and dip they serve before your meal, and our appetizer which was a sort of meat tray  (agliere di Salumi coppa~spek~prosciutto~salame~olives~marinated vegetables) which was more deliscious with every bite. 

My bf had the filet mignon~fontina cheese~black truffles. A-MAZ-ING! Every bite was juicy, bursting with flavor from the sucullent meat and black truffle, and cooked to perfection. 

Unfortunately I can't rave as much about my dish. I had the Assorted seafood (crab, calamari, mussels, clams, shrimp, salmon, and swordfish) and it was a bit dry and bland  quite frankly. It came out piping hot (was litterally still boiling) and beautifully prepared which was nice. I was just so excited for this dish, our server did a great job on selling me on it, and the fact that it came out less than amazing was a bit dissapointing and the reason for 4 instead of 5 stars. 

Regardless of my mediocre dish I still look forwards to going back and possibly trying the ravioli or rack of lamb.
author: Kristy M.

description:
I loved the food, it was delicious. I had the halibut (from the ocean menu) but felt the quantity was less for a $22 dish. Others in our group also felt that the quantity of food was less, hence the one less star. 

The ease of finding parking was amazing, the location was not amazing but did not make you uncomfortable. Expect to spend atleast $40pp with food and booze with tip and taxes. 

PS: The waitstaff is very nice.
author: Jeev S.

description:
Excellent food. Excellent service.
The pasta di mare (seafood) was awesome!
author: Yaniv L.

description: If you're looking for old fashion spaghetti with red sauce & meatballs keep looking.  This restaurant is truly the best example of the new Italian cooking I've experienced in 30 years. DO NOT overlook the, Tagliatelle ai porcini e tartufo  wild porcini~black truffles~white truffle oil (Crepes) as an appetizer although I could eat several orders as a meal.  The baked baked halibut arrived as the hotted dish I ever gotten and, oh by the way along with having heavenly flavor it melted in my mouth!  Attentive service and some excellent house wine nailed it for my wife and I.  WE WILL RETURN, from Chicago!!
author: Mike P.

description:
Yay! I'm so happy to have such a cozy Italian restaurant in my 'hood.  We just went to Italy a month ago and this place made me feel like I was back there again.  Our server even greeted us with a "Buon Giorno" and I overheard him speaking Italian to a couple nearby.  Cool!  Service was attentive but not overwhelming.  This was beginning to feel like the Italian counterpart to Fringale (French) around the corner.

I had the linguine alle vongole (linguine with clams) that was light and flavorful.  My husband had tagliatelle ai porcini e tartufo (tagliatelle with mushrooms and truffles), which was savory and hearty.  We also shared the agnello al brunello (rack of lamb) that was mouth-watering and finger-licking good.  I actually nibbled the bone and licked my fingers. :) 

I'll definitely be back to try more items on their "Earth" and "Ocean" menus.
author: Nina L.

description:
Overall, I had an excellent dinner with my bf at la Briciole.

- the food was truly excellent. The menu had a lot of options, and a lot of original ones. We had the beef carpaccio, the grilled calamari and the risotto with ink sauce and we enjoyed every bit of it.
- the waiter (genuinely Italian) was really nice.
- the ambiance was great. Excellent for a date, there was room between the tables, it wasn't too dark and the music was kept to a minimum, and they gave us a corner table. All things that I appreciate.
- prices are very moderate

The only "not so great" point was the dessert. We tried the profiteroles (not like real profiteroles, by the way) and the panna cotta, and both were below average. Seeing that I had only eaten half of my dessert, the waiter offered to give me something else. Since I wasn't really hungry anymore at that point, and wasn't feeling confident about the other desserts anyway, I didn't ask for one, but I do appreciate that he offered.

I would definitely go back if I were living in San Francisco, and would simply have dessert elsewhere or at home.
author: Sophie P.

description:
Sigh. I wish there were more restaurants with the quality, price, and ambience that La Briciola offers.

My old coworkers and I used to come here during lunch because it felt like such an oasis from the harsh and noisy hustle and bustle of SoMA. I loved chattin' it up with the Italian waiter, swirling lemon in a pristine glass of ice water, and filling my belly up with perfectly cooked bolognese. It's a good place to go if you're starving too because their bread and dip will tide you over til the main attraction arrives. Lunch specials will only set you back about $12 and are the perfect portion size for a young lady, so if you eat a lot just think of it as a really satisfying small meal (you know, being healthy and eating six small meals a day instead of three large ones).

The decor makes me feel like I'm somewhere in Europe. I can definitely see it as a date place at dinnertime. Not the awkward, nervous-fancy date, but more of the "aw I'm impressed you took me to this cute restaurant" kinda place. Hint hint, boys :)
author: Claire C.

description:
Great restaurant.

The customer service was great. After we ordered then mentioned that it might take some time to get the food ready so they gave us some tasty toasts.

The atmosphere is good. I liked the walls made of small bricks. It's not very intimate though, despite their nice efforts. It could almost be a date spot if there was a little more charm.

The food was very good. We both really liked what we had and the price was correct.

It's in a very weird (as in, not great) location in SOMA. It's pretty far from everything and the surroundings are almost sketchy for a lonely lady.
author: Marc L.

description: This is a nice little neighborhood Italian place. The menu is pretty typical.  I went for dinner and had the nocchi, it was all right. Get a reservation to ensure you can get a table because there isn't a ton of space.
author: Lauren B.

description:
I have no idea why someone would rate La Briciola less than 5 stars!

 I have lived and worked in Italy 3 years and La Briciola is just a great as the finest Ristorantes of Tuscany. 

I dined with a party of 5 and had a wide selection of the menu from appetizer to dessert; wine to espresso. All of the menu is fabulous. The wine list is great and the coffee/espresso is the best.

You are in Italy when you dine at La Briciola. Alessandro and the team are Italians and know how to serve with the warmth of the Italian people. What an experience.
