You want authentic Italian food with the dining experience of the best of Italy? Go to La Briciola!

New Patron for Life.
Roberto Q.
author: Robert Q.

description:
We came here for dinner and had a good experience.
We had the following among the three of us:
My hubby really enjoyed the Belgian beer Duchess du Borgogne-great addition to the menu.
Two of us had the hand cut pasta with lamb ragu and the consensus was that it was ok.  We were expecting shredded lamb not ground lamb.
I had the mixed fish grill which was very good.
The bread was excellent as was the olive tapenade.
Service and ambiance was fine.
author: Lizete S.

description: Had a very good expereance here. Amazing food great wine and friendly people. Took a date here and could not of been happier. Save yourself some time and make a reservation.
author: Jason B.

description:
This week I went to La Briciola and was pleasantly surprised. My great grandparents were from the Piedmonte region of Italy so I was very interested in how La Briciola prepared their cuisine.  

 La briciola means breadcrumb, but you certainly get more than that on your plate! One of my indicators of a good restaurant is how it serves veal.  I had the veal scaloppina  al limone and it was very tender.  My husband had pasta with a variety of shell fish and calamari- very delicious!  My other indicator of a good restaurant is the texture of the calamari and it was perfect.  
Luciano, our waiter, was warm and friendly.  He was very accomodating since we were off to a ball game and we had little time! The atmosphere is lovely and has a tucked away feeling from the noise of the street.  
I would like to go back for a more leisurely meal and try other items. Thank you La Briciola for a wonderful meal and great service!
author: Jennifer P.

description:
SOMA veterans know La Briciola as the spot that used to have a giant tomato facing the street, which has somehow disappeared into oblivion.  From the outside, it seems out of place--an authentic, well-kept Italian restaurant--next to two Asian restaurants and a liquor store on the block.

My coworkers and I called in ahead of time to make sure we had a table, and then we walked on over for lunch (that day was the birthday one of my coworkers).  The friendly waiter greeted and seated us and then handed us the menus.  The dishes were listed in Italian, with English-friendly descriptions next to the names.  I've never had risotto before, so I chose the risotto with saffron and sausage.

Oh my freakin goodness...it was awesome.  The creamy sauce mixed in with the rice and sausage was all good.  I can't really even describe how good this dish was.  I'll just say that I feel like I now have a high standard of how to measure a great risotto.

Sure, the prices are a little above what one would normally spend for lunch, but it's well worth it.  Bravo, La Briciola, Bravo.
author: Marlon E.

description:
Last night I went to this restaurant and I really can't say there was anything that was much of a disappointment. They have quite an extensive wine list if you're interested in getting a bottle. This place was very simply decorated and was very clean. The service was great, minue the fact they never came to refill my coffee I had after dinner. 

One of my friends had the caesar salad which looked fresh and was a decent size. I started with the Fagottino ripieno vegetable filled crepe with wild porcini sauce and a white truffle oil. This was very rich and amazingly tastey. It was more than enough for the three of us. Between the three of us we had the Tagliolini di mare mussels, clams, calamari, shrimp and cherry tomatoes tossed with garlic and olive oil. The second dish was the Linguine alle vongole with fresh clams in a white wine reduction. Both of the pasta dishes were very fresh and the pasta has to be homemade. The third dish was the Rombo all'isolana baked halibut with fresh tomato sauce, olives, and sliced potatoes. This fish was delicious and very flavorful. 

Everything we had was delightful. The food was hot and the presentation and detail was great, right down to the silverware. 

I would definitely go back to this resturant the next time I come to San Francisco. It wasn't insanely expensive and the experience. I really couldn't come up with a reason to not rate this place five stars.
author: Maria P.

description: A simple place to get good Italian food.  Very friendly waitstaff.  Don't expect super creative food but just a solid experience.  Great place for a business lunch.
author: Mark G.

description: We arrived for our  7:30 party of 9 reservations a few minutes late and were welcomed graciously. The service was outstanding and the food incredibly good. Grilled calamari appetizer was delicious. The staff was very attentive to our needs - and made every accomodation possible to please us.  This  is authentic Italian in every way- Favoloso y Superbo.
author: Lisa A.

description:
Unfortunately, my experience here can be summed up by one word: mediocre.  Everything on the menu sounded good, but it didn't taste as good as the description.  I was hoping there would be a great new Italian restaurant in our SOMA hood, but Pazzia is still better.  

Pros
* Good selection of wines 
* Nice decor on the inside.  Complete 180 from the looks of the outside.  
*Ravioli - Nicely cooked, yummy lobster reduction sauce
*Frutti di Mare - Good!  Tons of seafood

Cons
* Service - slow!  There were maybe 5 other tables when we were 
there.  
*Caesar - okay.  A little too heavy on the dressing
*Pastas - Inconsistent.  One pasta was super al dente, the other was too mushy.  
*Halibut - dry
*Tiramisu - just okay.  Nothing special, and I LOVE dessert normally!
author: Christina C.

description: I LOVE, Love, love, loveeeee Italian food. This place let us make a reservation of 10 20 minutes before we all got there and it was AMAZING!! They put a huge table together for us and the waiter was so patient and great with us. We started with bottles of wine and the waiter poured for everyone at the table. Then we got to our ordering. I got the Tagliolini di mare with calamari, clams, mussels, and shrimp. It was in this delicious, savory red tomato sauce. I couldn't get enough bread to soak that up. All of the other dishes at my table smelled and looked good too especially the ravioli.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: What an amazing little restaurant!  We ordered the grilled octopus appetizer and had the lamb ragu and seabass/lobster ravioli as our entrees.  Everything was dynamite.  Wine was very reasonable priced.
author: Cecilia S.

description:
We spent a month in Italy this summer and dining at this restaurant puts us right back over there.  The food is wonderful, the service charming and the atmosphere warm and intimate.  the neighborhood is not the best (SoMa under the freeway) but it does seem to be safe.  Park on Harrison and walk down 3rd (well-lit).  the Stracciette al ragu (pasta with lamb sauce) is fantastic and their Minestrone is the best we've ever had.
Definitely a 5 star in our book
author: Ida D.

description:
I went to this place a couple of weeks ago.  I thought the food was very good, but the service blew goats.  I had a couple of antipasti (the salumi and the octopus with bean), and my friend had the ravioli.  The octopus was delightful.  Service was initially fine, but after we ordered and had some bread and tapenade, things went a bit off the rails.

There were four other occupied tables and two waiters. and a guy who was doing the bread/water/busing (whatever that function is called).  Our waiter came by to see how everything was, and took off before I was able to request more tapenade; we were out, but had plenty of bread, and I had put the empty dish on the outside edge of the table to be in plain sight for such an occasion.  I called him back and he brought a half-filled dipping bowl.  I started to ask for more right then, but didn't.

When he brought the plates out the bread basket and tapenade were empty, and he didn't even ask if we wanted more of either.  After waiting for a few minutes, thinking he would have at least asked the table guy to give us more bread, I signalled the waiter in vain, then went over to the table dude (who was busy clearing another table) to please bring more bread.  This while our waiter was chilling, standing in clear view of our table.

Whatever.  I figure the guy was preoccupied with more important matters in his head.  And we didn't order a bottle of wine.  I'd give it another shot, as the food was a solid 4/5.
author: Mike T.

description: Every time I try a new (to me) Italian restaurant, I always have the gnocchi. I find it is a great indicator as to how good the rest of the menu will be. On my first visit to La Briciola, I of course did just that. Wow(!), I was impressed and loved how fresh and delicious the gnocchi was made!!!! This is a must try, if you love fresh house-made Italian.
author: Andy S.

description:
4 stars 5 stars really? 

Try 1 star.  I love food, I love italian food and what I had tasted worse than Chef Boyardee.  Really, I went on a Thurs night, did I get leftovers?  4 of us went, none of us enjoyed the meal.  It's the first time I couldn't finish my meal at a restaurant...and I'm chubby eater.

At least w/chef boyardee I know what I'm getting.  I'm pretty sure my pasta was frozen as well as the sauces.  It was bland, noodles overcooked, gross.  My friend had the linguini and it just tasted like salt.

Let's talk dessert.  No one really wanted any but I have to try the tiramisu, I mean it's tiramisu! Surely you won't dare to screw that one up?

Holy God I paid the bill and left soon after.  It was terrible, terrible, terrible.
author: Michael S.

description:
One word, AMAZING! This is really one of the best Italian restaurants in SF. Don't even bother trying to deal with North Beach; come down to La Briciola in SOMA where the people are nicer and the food is MUCH better. Every dish I have had here has been, well, amazing. I especially love the lamb ragu. They also have some great wines. 

The service is on another level. You really feel at home here. The staff goes out of their way for every table to make you feel welcomed and taken care of. No one is rushed here. You can sit and enjoy your meal and feel like you are at a friends house for dinner. You never have an angry staff member hovering over you to leave. 

I really can't say enough. Just  come and enjoy the wonderful food and atmosphere and see for yourself what a treat this place really is!
author: Adam R.

description: We had a wonderful dinner here to celebrate my sister's birthday.   I am normally not a big fan of Italian, but this is Italian done superb.  The hand cut pastas are out of this world and I daresay the lamb ragu here is better than Perbacco.  We shared four starters and four desserts (with expresso) - all delicious.  Warm seafood salad was a must...Service was ridiculously good and the seating was intimate for our party of four.  I highly recommend this SOMA spot.
author: lucy w.

description: Great meal. Service was attentive, but not annoying. Enjoyed the Tagliatelle ai porcini e tartufo. Pasta was perfect, and the sauce was so good I sopped up the remaining bits with the complimentary bread. Also enjoyed the Pinot Grigio they serve by the glass (maybe it was 2010 Pinot Grigio Caposaldo?). It was quiet, maybe because it was a Monday night, but enjoyed a change from the usual San Francisco meal out with noise at a maximum.
author: Luke P.

description:
The food was mediocre at best.  I ordered the tuna, which I thought would be hard to screw up.  It was cooked much past the advertised "seared" and was a very fibery piece.  It came with a bunch of steamed and tasteless veggies and potatoes.  I feel like I wasted a meal here, except for the good company and good service.  

I hate to complain when restaurants are generous, but they gave us at least a loaf of bread cut up with oil, for two people!  I don't like the idea of all that bread going to waste.  

Like someone else said, Pazzia is better and in the neighborhood.  And really, so is Buono.
author: Amy D.

description: Had the linguine with clams to go, it was delicious and I'm sure it would've been even better if I had eaten in.
author: Dean C.

description:
spectacular spectacular!

with a cool menu that is broken out by meats (from the earth) and seafood (from the ocean), la briciola was a restaurant where nearly everything on the menu looked amazing.  

the sfogliatine con gamberi e asparagi (italian for jizz in your mouth delicious) was so damn good.  i would bathe in the sauce if i could just so that when i sweat, i could lick myself.

my orecchiatte pasta was good, but not quite as good as barbacco's orecchiatte.  this is the only part of the dinner that prevented it from a 5 star rating.  the taste and texture was all just slightly below that of barbacco, though still very good. 

my girlfriend's straccietti ragu (parpadelle wide noodles) was also comparable to the ragu over at barbacco, which was just alllllllmost just as good.  

all in all, i love la briciola and consider that one of the very few solid restaurants i'd go back to over and over again in the soma/south beach area.
author: Jeff N.

description: Excellent food and gracious service - highly enjoyed a very long, relaxed weekend dinner here with another couple.  Everything that ended up on our table was superb - our favorite starters were the seafood puff pastry and the octopus.  For entrees the pasta dishes took top honors, with rave reviews for the gnocchi from the vegetarians and the lamb ragu from the carnivores.  The other very pleasant surprise was the solid selection of Italian wines - great quality and very reasonably priced.  We'll definitely be back.
author: Kurt K.

description: A true gem with an unassuming exterior but a delightful interior decor. There are nooks and crannies that add privacy to a large space. The walls and ceiling are well-dampened to cut down on ambient noise. The food is well-prepared and tastefully laid out. The grilled calamari and pan seared tuna were done to a tee. The place was ideal for our romantic dinner, but would serve equally well for an evening dinner/interview. I shall return.
author: Kenneth B.

description:
Birthday dinner last night was lovely, especially once the all-female-with-annoying-voices group left.

To drink:

Prosecco Fantinel, Friuli, Italia  40
delicious!

To start (shared, mind you):

Burrata mozzarella-butter cheese~Parma prosciutto~cherry tomatoes~arugala         14
yum!

Sfogliatine con gamberi e asparagi puff pastry~asparagus~shrimp~crab reduction  14
snooze alert; sauce had no flavor.  borING.

Crostini misti di polenta chicken pate~porcini mushrooms~sausage~polenta           13
aiiight.

Main event:

Agnello al Brunello  rack of lamb~green peppercorn~Brunello red wine reduction    26
AMAZING!  lamb perfectly tenderly deliciously done.  vegetables scrumptious and buttery.

Lovely finish:

Fragole con gelato vanilla ice cream~strawberries                             8
happy ending indeed.  not that you could mess this one up, though.

Great service helped earn La Briciola 4 out of 5 stars.
author: Em P.

description:
Service was very personable and reasonably speedy.

The ravioli, gnocchi, and orecchiette were all just "okay".  None of them would merit ordering again.  For the price of the food, I wouldn't go back to La Briciola.
author: Kevin L.

description: I enjoyed the wine and service, but the food wasn't as great as what I was expecting. Tried the lamb ragu and it was pretty dry. Needed a bit more sauce, imho. I think others in my part thought the same. The desserts were solid though, so I think I'd only come back here for a pre- or post-evening drink or dessert in the future.
author: Alan S.

description: Went there before seeing Totem and arrived just as they were opening. We were the first ones there and while we were waiting for the rest of our party, we sampled their cheese platter and salami platter, which were very good. They have some nice wines by the glass and they even gave us a complimentary appetizer of baby squid, which was very tasty. I had the rack of lamb and it was delicious and cooked medium rare perfectly. The others enjoyed their meals as well.
author: Michael W.

description:
My new office is in SoMa and I was so relieved to find that there's a restaurant with authentic Italian cuisine so close by.  My girlfriend and I went to La Briciola last night for dinner and really liked it.

The dining room is warm and contemporary and we were served by a native Italian (makes for a much more authentic experience, I think).

We had the calamari to start and both loved the texture.  It was masterfully cooked with just the right amount of crunch on the outside and chewiness on the inside.  The flavor, however, was a bit bland.

My entree was the straccetti with lamb ragu and it was absolutely delicious.  The pasta was perfectly al dente and the sauce was flavorful and just right.  Soooo good!

My girlfriend had a seafood risotto with crab and asparagus and said that it was very good, but not great.

There's a pretty decent wine list, though the number of wines that can be had by the glass is a bit limited.

Dessert with a very yummy plate of profitteroles with perfect pastries and rich ice cream.

We were disappointed in the calamari but still loved the place and I'm sure that we'll go back soon.  I'm giving La Briciola a very solid 4 stars.
author: Matt C.

description:
If I were to describe La Briciola in a quick sentence, I would probably say that it's like "a kid playing dress-up in Mommy's clothing". Every aspect of this restaurant, from the webpage to food to the location, embodies that theme. The first thing I checked was the menu online, which was hidden among a sub-par website that looked like it was designed by a high school student in the 90s, complete with cheesy background music. Normally, I wouldn't be so critical of a webpage, but this place gave off the feeling that it was fancy, yet none of the installments really lived up to its expectation.

The Food: The menu had lots of fancy ingredients like swordfish, rabbit, sunchokes, etc, but overall was mediocre. The plating also was sub-par and made a difference between it being a "grown-up" restaurant.
 
[Appetizer] Sfogliatine -- A puff pastry filled with a shrimp, crab, and asparagus reduction -- Honestly, this was like chicken pot pie but with seafood. The puff pastry wasn't the light phyllo dough kind, but a heavier version that encased the filling kind of like a hamburger. The filling itself was just all right.
[Entree] Sea Bass Ravioli with Lobster Reduction -- This was just okay too. The raviolis were large, but the filling was only 40% of the entire thing. Also, with raviolis, oftentimes the flavor of the filling gets lost amongst the sauce and the dough. Something like sea bass, which has little flavor itself definitely blended in with this dish. The one redeeming part of this dish was the lobster reduction. Tasted like lobster bisque and was pretty yummy!
[Entree] Rabbit Stew -- This was the best dish of the night! It had great flavor and a good mix of sides along with the rabbit itself. Having never had rabbit, I thought it was pretty good - although a few bits were inconsistently cooked and a little tough, but overall, I really enjoyed this!
[Dessert] Tiramisu -- I really like my tiramisus rummy. This one was good, but nothing to write home about, although with the size of it, it actually tasted lighter than it looked, which is good.

The location was also something to be desired. Tucked between two grungy shops with bars on the windows in a seedy neighborhood, this place really didn't seem like it belonged. 

All in all, I thought it was okay and probably wouldn't go back again for a while.
author: Penny Y.

description: I do not remember what the name of my dish was called. It was okay, it wasn't really that flavorful though. I kind of hated it, I didn't really like the noodles, but I like the seafood even though it didn't really taste like anything much. My friend got the roasted chicken it was okay, she hated it though. This restaurant is really cute though!  Even though the food wasn't really that good, I think the thing with the most flavor that I had here was the bread dip!
author: Janet Z.

description:
What a cute name - La Briciola (translates as The Crumb)
Came with my BF for a late lunch on a windy Sunday afternoon and was pleasantly surprised that we were the only customer.

The owner was thrilled that a true Italian came to dine.  He was attentive and talkative.  It was nice to chat with owner.

We came when they had just opened for less than two weeks.  The food was OK but probably has changed significant since we last stopped for a meal.  Would definitely come back to check it out.
author: Veritas V.

description:
This restaurant has become one of our favorite Italian restaurants in SF- excellent food and service.  If you like halibut, must try that dish.  It's superb!  We've eaten there twice in 3 weeks.
We just returned from Italy and France.  We prefer Italian people who are warm and friendly.  Much like the atmosphere and ambience of this restaurant. Frankly, the food is better here than in Italy.  If not for Yelp, I would not have found this restaurant.
author: Rena C.

description:
Decided to try out my neighborhood Italian restaraunt and it did not disappoint. The place is large enough to be comfortable and the ambiance is romantic. I had a great "date night" with one of my bff.

Service was great. Waiter was very friendly and knowledgable and what to recommend since it was my first time. 

I had the Pennette al granchio con la rucola crab~arugula~cherry tomatoes. It wasn't what I expected since it came out without sauce and more just tossed together than traditional pasta (when i think of pasta i think of sauce). The crab was really fresh and the dish was very light. My friend and I shared the bruschetta and it was really good. The bruschetta is not your traditional chopped tomatoes over toast but 3 pieces of toast: 1 with mushrooms, 1 with eggplant, and 1 with tomatoes. We both agreed the tomatoes was the best one.

My friend had the Risotto alla monferrina arborio rice~sausage~saffron . It was too rich and after a couple of bites she had to stop eating. 

The basket of bread was not good. It was very dry (like day or two old) and the dipping sauce was EVVO w/ minced olives. Not my favorite so I skipped on the bread.

Not sure if i would visit this place often. I much rather head over to Pazzia.
author: Terry D.

description:
My sister and I only had the first course meals: Ravioli con Pomodoro and Linguini Alle Vongole.  The food may come off almost as bland to us Americans, as it did at first to me.  However, I gradually found my linguini to be flavorful, actually, and very light.  My sister appreciated her ravioli for its authenticity, as it reminded her of some of the meals she's had in Italy.  Neither of the meals were not too greasy or "Americanized," and unlike many other restuarant foods that leave me thirsty and tired, I actually came out feeling healthy and happy.  

Our waiter, who probably was the owner or the manager, was very kind and let us dine before the restaurant opened.  His thick Italian accent and mannerisms matched the decor of the place.  The place was nicely decorated without giving off a snooty vibe. 

This restaurant definitely had what I would imagine to be the ambience and the flavors of Italy.  It is not the cheapest restaurant out there, though, so I would reserve it for a date or a get-together with friends/co-workers.  I plan on going back and trying a full 4 course meal someday.
author: Guri G.

description:
Walking down 3rd St and catching a glimpse of the exterior of this place, you would never think it could be so cozy and elegant inside. With plenty of candlelit tables scattered throughout the dining room and the back wall fully racked with rows and rows of wine, I was impressed with SF for having such an upscale looking restaurant without the upscale prices. 

The management did a wonderful job of accommodating our large party of 16. They tried their best to fit us all onto one elongated table, but it surely would've been an uncomfortable arrangement being all squished in the back corner. We're were satisfied with our 2 tables back to back to each other. Service was on point. The waiters were all friendly and helpful and stayed on top of making sure our glasses were constantly filled. 

I was debating between the risotto with calamari, scallops, topped with ink sauce & the seabass stuffed ravioli with a lobster reduction. The thought of "ink sauce" reminded me of Mario Kart, so that turned me away and ultimately persuaded me to go with the ravioli...and it did not disappoint! The sauce was delightful and nicely topped off with bits and pieces of lobster meat. Each bite of the seabass stuffed ravioli was more gratifying than the last as the homemade pasta instantly melted in my mouth. However, I couldn't say the same for my friend's salmon filet with saffron sauce. I sampled a tiny bite and noticed the saffron gave the top portion of the salmon quite a kick, but the meaty part of filet was completely bland. Another surprise was that our waiter did not ask how we wanted our flet mignon cooked when he took our order. Typically, I would assume the meat to be cooked medium as a general standard, but the steak came out well-done! Oh what a delicate tender slab of meat ruined from being overcooked. There should be a law that filet mignons cannot be cooked above medium...

The only issue we had last night was that it took foreverrrrr and a daaaay for our food to come out and when it finally arrived, it wasn't piping hot. I believe that having so many patrons in our party affected the quality of our food, and though we can't really blame the chefs in the back of the house, I still wish the wait wasn't so long. Regardless, I'd be willing to come back and give them another try, but definitely with a much smaller party. 

My rating is actually 3.5 stars, but I'm rounding up because they totally won me over with my entree and the sparkling red wine.
author: Michelle W.

description:
Thanks to Yelp for this fabulous find...I wouldn't have made my way to this SOMA gem without your help!

SF has a lot of Italian wonders but this place is the real deal- better than the deluge of lesser quality places scattered around North Beach. They also have a great and reasonably priced wine selection. 

My friend and I had the following (and would definitely have it again):

Bruschette assortite zucchini~eggplant~fresh tomatoes~toasted bread     
- This was complimentary but I'd definitely pay for this dish next time. Great flavors- very savory and perfectly seasoned.

Burrata mozzarella-butter cheese~Parma prosciutto~cherry tomatoes~arugala  
- Rich & creamy. Definitely a dish to share.

Ravioli di cernia seabass filled ravioli~lobster reduction  
- I basically licked my plate clean. 'Nuff said.

My Vegetarian friend had the Tagliatelle (ai porcini e tartufo  wild porcini~black truffles~white truffle oil), which I tried and loved.
author: Christina C.

description: Don't let the outside keep you from walking inside. This is a wonderful place to eat with inviting atmosphere. I felt like I was back in Italy, at a local family run resturaunt. Everything was excellent. The service, the food and the people. The food is as close to homemade as it comes. The atmosphere is easy going with a comfortable level of chatter and laughs. I will definetly go back and if you haven't been, you must visit soon.
author: Bryan B.

description: Great food.  Great wine list.  Service was a little slow.  But we didn't have a reservation and they were able to find us a table.  Small spot, quiet, intimate.  It's a good spot if you are looking for traditional Italian food.  I'd recommend it, I'd also take more friends here.
author: Matt B.

description:
La Briciola came to the rescue since I couldn't expand my reservation at Range and we couldn't get much else on short notice.

I started with the smoked salmon w/ capers. Delicious and well executed. Pretty big pieces too, certainly enough to share.

For dinner, I had the rolled swordfish with veggies, which was really good. Swordfish can often be overcooked since it's so meaty, but this was soft and juicy, complemented with a nice sauce (forgot what was in it, mushrooms perhaps?).

They have a reasonable wine list, but only a few by the glass. I had a couple glasses of the Castle Rock Pinot Noir as I had had it before and didn't feel like having any white wine.

For dessert, we split a tiramisu as we were all pretty stuffed. Mmm...I love tiramisu. Pretty standard, not bad, but I've had better. :P

Thanks to my friend Nicole for finding this place and making a reservation on short notice. :) 

We had a nice dinner here with a high school friend who was in town for a conference. It was a very reasonable dinner for three, we split it and I think it was about $90 (or $60/pp). Of course we couldn't let our friend pay, as he's doing a MD/PhD and is STILL a student after all these years. ;P
author: Kenny J.

description:
I couldn't pronounce anything on the menu here, but I think everything is Italian for "delicious." 

Let me just qualify that.  The pasta with mushrooms that I got was very good, but it was too rich for my taste.  That said, most cream-based pasta sauces are too rich for me and I should have known better.  And man, they definitely do not skimp on the mushrooms!   

My husband's ravioli (just the plain ravioli) were delicious.  The tomato sauce was spot on - not too sweet, not overcooked, and the right amount of fresh basil.  

Our company was very pleased with their orders. I'm not exactly sure what they got (one was fish?), but they liked it so much that they plan on coming back up to SF from Sunnyvale just to go here for dinner. 

For desert, we ordered the coffee one. I think it has "caffe" in the title.  It is simply ice cream with coffee.  I didn't realize that.  The coffee was excellent and the ice cream was high quality.  But $8?  Please.

Speaking of prices, I was a little annoyed that the website menu didn't include the prices.  Our non-meat pasta dishes were in the teens ($14 and $17, I think), and the dishes that included fish etc could range up into the 20s.  Deserts ranged from $7-9. The menu was arranged into first and second courses, but honestly, I think a single course should fill most people with moderate appetites.  I think we'll probably come back when we're in the mood for some Italian again.
author: A H.

description: I've passed by La Briciola a number of times since it has opened and it has always intrigued me and tonight we finally ate there.  The interior was pretty basic but cozy.  The brick on the walls, small bar and wine racks in the back had a nice feel.  It wasn't too fancy too which was good.  The meal was good and the service very good.  The olive dip sauce with the bread was delicious.  For the main meal I had the crab pasta and it was good although lacked a bit of flavor as there was no sauce.  There were good amounts of crab in the dish too.  Some pieces needed to be taken out from the shell but otherwise it was all ready for consumption.  My fiance has the salmon pasta and liked it but thought it was a little too heavy on the salmon.  I think I'd try it out again for some of the other meals as we had a pleasant experience.
author: Blake B.

description:
Visiting from TX.  I realy enjoyed the atmosphere and the food.  Some of the best italian food i've had.

Worth the trip
author: Nathan L.

description: I simply love this restaurant the food and service are GREAT! If you want to have a real Italian experience that's the place.
author: Simona F.

description:
Hooray for La Bric! It's so nice to have a place that feels like a friendly neighborhood place with great food and reasonable prices. And it's one of those places where you can get in and eat fairly quickly, or linger for hours over a glass or wine or three, without getting a dirty look for hogging the table.

I'd give more like 4.5 stars if I could...

Best plates IMHO are their bruschetta, meat sampler app, calamari (delicious!),  halibut, penne (lamb or beef), and tiramisu. 

Pros:
-Great, friendly service. Owner Alessandro remembers folks and treats them like family. 
-Very reasonable prices, esp for their lunch specials. 
-Simple, soothing decor. 


Cons: 
-Other folks I've taken think that some of the dishes are a little heavy or bland. But I've gone with maybe 15 different people in the past few months, and overall everyone gave it a thumbs up!
author: naomi a.

description:
My fellow yelpers, this place is the real deal. It is SO cute (decor) and the food is fantastic! And parking is not an issue! The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because they were too short staffed to really be attentive with service. 

We had the mussels and clams as our appetizer. Then for the meal we had two different pastas, which were excellent, a seafood stew, and lamb chops. Everyone was happy! 

For dessert, there's ice cream with strawberries and whipped cream (so good) and the tiramisu--I could have eaten 3 of them. 

Total bill including wine, tax, tip was $38 per person.
author: Joyce L.

description:
Husband and I came here for dinner last week.  He had the Caesar salad and the pasta with lamb ragu.  I had the grilled squid appetizer and the lamb chops.  
Husband's Caesar was pretty standard stuff.  His pasta, however, was pretty damn good.
My grilled squid appetizer was really nice, with a garbanzo puree and some arugula.  Really simple, but really tasty.
The lamb chops were really phenomenal.  Perfectly cooked, with a really tasty green peppercorn sauce.
My only gripes are that the bread before the meal is not very good, and the vegetable side that come with the meat dishes is pretty uninspired.  All the meat dishes come with the same generic vegetable medley.  Better bread and more interesting sides would really help make this place better.
author: Michelle A.

description:
Sorry to say we didn't get to eat here because our car got the window smashed out around the corner. Don't park on South Park Ave by the park. I guess several cars get broken into EVERYDAY here.
Our friends did enjoy a lovely dinner here though.
author: Lori S.

description:
Came here for dinner for my boyfriend's birthday, after watching Cirque du Soliel a couple blocks away. Walk was less than ten minutes from the show!

Restaurant was relatively quiet when we got there; not a very busy Friday night. We were seated quickly (I made a reservation just in case). We ordered:

Steamed mussels and clams: appetizer; was pretty good, though both of agreed that we've had better.

Potato gnocchi: I don't remember the names for these dishes, sorry! Boyfriend ordered this and commented on how delicious the sauce was. I had some and it was delicious; potato-y balls of goodness!

Seafood pasta: Noodles were softer than I expected! Tasty, but it made me wish that I had ordered something a little more "unique" because it tasted pretty...standard.

Waiter was very friendly, and gave my boyfriend a good wine recommendation (that he wouldn't stop raving about throughout the meal). Strangely enough though, service was pretty slow for a fairly empty restaurant. We had to flag down the waiter to order and to get the check at the end, and it took a while for the dishes to come out. Bread refills were fairly slow as well. I would suggest coming here if you have the time for a "slower" meal.

Solid 3 stars, minus 1 star for slowwwww service, minus 1 star for food that's good, but not amazing, and thus not quite worth the priciness. Ambiance was lovely, though; perfect for a date. If we are ever in the area again, we will probably be back!
author: Sharlene C.

description:
Love the Italian pop music on the website...reminds me of working long hours at my gelato store, owned by a real Italian! (Those are rare these days...)

But the restaurant felt a little too American. Too clean, too quiet, too much poise. That could be a good thing for others.

I love the risotto, beautiful in taste and color. 

I still would rather hang out in North Beach if I'm paying these prices--a little too much for college girls.
author: Hana J.

description: 4 stars for - Tagliata di tonno al sesamo : pan seared tuna~sesame seeds~vin santo~shallots, others are just ok.
author: Susan H.

description:
When I first saw it, this restaurant menu really reminded me of some places in Piemonte or Liguria: typical antipasti from the centre/north of Italy, separate lists for meat/vegetable or sea-oriented pasta's, many different options for meat and fish. I definitely have a soft-spot for places like Briciola (... let's call it homesickness) and I was eager to try it out.  Mission finally accomplished with my gf and another 100% Italian couple.  Going to the point, here follows a summary of our culinary journey.

We start like savages, wildly attacking the superb black olives patè with the (averagely good) bread. 

Appetizers:
0- damn, I forgot to mention I'm a Yelper so I missed the bonus :-( 
1- bruschette with tomatoes (average, no garlic flavour at all, few tomatoes), red and yellow peppers (my fellow diners said it was good, I didn't taste it, I hate sweet peppers), eggplant and zucchini (disappointing, the vinegar flavour was too dominant and actually I found it completely out of place).
2-  Sfogliatine con gamberi e asparagi: this delicious warm puff pastry with a cheesy filling made me feel as I was back in Torino ...

Main courses:
1- Gnocchi al sughetto d'anatra: this plate was rather weak. Both the sauce and especially the pasta were simply bland.
2- Ravioli di cernia: good sauce, good filled pasta but a bit overcooked (I suspect that this dish was ready much earlier than it was served to me ... what a shame).
3-Farfalle con salmone: my friend did not like them at all, saying that they were tasteless (I cannot confirm it, since I haven't sampled them).
4-Coniglio in umido con polenta: awesome presentation, excellent tomato based sauce, good overall taste but my other friend had some small reservations on the rabbit.  Personally, I wish I had tasted such a wonder :-(

No dessert this time, since we were late for the cinema.

The service was flawless and everybody was very friendly. In particular, I appreciated the enthusiasm of the owner when I told him that I was from Torino. He then behaved like the Holy Inquisition asking me from where I was exactly, from what street ... kind of cute after all! In fact, the guy comes from Grugliasco which is a small town in the suburbs of Torino. Ehi, that was great: meeting an almost neighbour on the other side of the Ocean!

I definitely enjoyed the overall experience and I would be back, but 
what we got this time was just a little above average, while we would have expected it to be absolutely top notch. 

3 and 1/2 for now
author: Andrea L.

description:
I found La Briciola by doing my usual Yelp search for something new.  We were in the mood for Italian, and this was only 8 blocks from my pad.

The ambiance is really nice- pleasing decor with high ceilings and open space.  The service was friendly and attentive.  The pricing was par with comparable restaurants. The food was outstanding. 

Our four course meal included:

Cesare Salad- Delicious dressing, crisp lettuce, tasty parmesean.  

Frittura di calamari - The fried calamari was very tender, flavorful, and served with tasty marinara dipping sauce.  

Filetto con fonduta al tartufo- the filet mignon with fontina cheese and black truffles was wonderful.  The sauce was lighter than I expected from a cheese sauce and didn't leave me feeling weighed down.  The roasted veggies and potatoes on the side were also very flavorful and fresh.

Caciucco di viareggio- This cioppino-like dish was amazing.  The broth was extremely flavorful yet not too heavy.  The broth was lighter than the tomato based cioppino broth, and the dish was loaded with fresh seafood:  crab, calamari, mussels, clams, shrimp, salmon and swordfish.  There was so much we actually left some behind to leave room for dessert.  This was hands down the best dish of the night, though I would order every dish we had again.

Tiramisu- traditional, good, ample portion.

Fragole con gelato- traditional, fresh strawberries, nicely sized portion.

We're planning on going back soon to try some of the other menu items, though this time around we won't be quite as gluttonous and may make it a one course adventure.
author: Michelle M.

description: Very good! Very fast service. Lasagna was delicious! Rich, but not too much so sauce. Minestrone soup could have used a bit more beans, but very tasty. Olive oil for bread dipping had chopped olives. Very nice!
author: David C.

description: Really salty pasta.  I've been sick with indigestion for a few days after eating there, presumably because of the oil.  The bread is great.  Our waiter was not especially friendly, and forgot to get our dessert.  Maybe I just got really unlucky this time.
author: Yvonne H.

description:
My wife and I had dinner at this nice establishment this past Friday night. Thank god for Open Table otherwise it never would have been on our radar. 

As for the restaurant, when we walked in we were greeted by the nicest host/waiter. Yes, here one man does it all. 

We started off our meal with a Caesar Salad. I quite enjoyed it as I liked the bitter taste but my wife wasn't too keen on it. I have to admit, the bitterness isn't for everyone. I think next time, I may stick with the Spinach Salad. 

We both were in the mood for pasta (which is homemade by the way) so we stuck with the First Course. I had the Paccheri con salsiccia e rape (sausage and broccoli)  which was prepared to perfection. My wife had the Paccheri con gamberi e broccholi  (shrimp and broccoli)and enjoyed that as well. 

For dessert we shared an order of the Profitterolles. Unless you are hoping to pack a few pounds on, share one order of this most delicious dessert. 

Because the service between our First Course and Dessert was a tad slow, our waiter proactively made nice by giving us each a complimentary glass of Prosecco. It's amazing how far such a nice gesture can go.

For anyone looking for a nice mid priced Italian meal, keep La Briciola on your short list.
author: Steve M.

description:
We were walking back to the T after a show at the Comedy College after we had eating a light dinner of appetizers about 4 hours before at a place downtown and needed to refuel.  We were looking to sit at a bar, have a glass of wine, and get some seafood.  We could not have found a better place than La Briciola.

We ordered some clams and mussels, the trio of bruschetta, and a bottle of wine from Santa Ynez. Each item was wonderful.  The trio was my favorite.  The wine was very reasonably priced.  

The hostess/owner ( a very pleasant young lady who is quite easy to talk to and seems genuinely interested in seeing her guest are having a great time at her establishment) gave us a complementary champagne flute at the end of the meal.  It was a wonder end of the evening...or so I thought

We never get dessert, and I mean never....but we decided to go for broke and got the tiramisu....it was simply amazing.  

All in all, this was a great place to have a modestly priced restaurant experience without feeling like they are going cheap around the edges.  I highly recommend it....
author: BRADY K.

description: Nice neighborhood place, comfortable setting without all the high power interior.  It's about the food, and the food delivers.  Varied menu.
author: Mark H.

description:
Came here for lunch with my sister, bro-in-law (who is a chef), and my wife for a nice leisurely Wed lunch.  What an incredible little place!  Total neighborhood vibe and attentive and proud waitstaff.  

I had the grilled chicken lunch special and it was simple, but awesome.  The fries were perfect and the mini salad was a nice addition to the palate.  It was extra simple, but the quality was where it should be - let the ingredients do their thing, which is waht I love.  My bro-in-law had the veal scallopine which was amazing... extra light sauce, lots of flavor.  Other guests' pasta dishes were spot on.... pasta al dente and the sauces fresh and perfectly slated.  ONe diner noted the "nice touch to slice vegetables thin so they aren't overwhelming and a flavor and texture complement to the pasta." Why don't more places get this right?  I wonder....

The whole menu looked great and the prices were very reasonable.  I would like to try out for dinner sometime soon.  There's absolutely no reason this place isn't packed at lunch.  The value is a 10 and the food was a 9.  Great place...  you can't lose on this place.
author: Tim T.

description:
The last time I had Italian food this good and truly authentic was on the back streets of Venice.  On top of that I've taken my wife here for a romantic meal, been in a small group and organized a large family dinner of 9 people and a young kid - every time they exceeded all of our expectations. 

Anyone who respects and enjoys the subtlety of hand made pasta, smooth sauces and an excellent wine selection will find this place exceptional.  However, if you're looking for a standard 'Americanized' Italian joint that serves giant dishes of spaghetti or chicken parm you'll probably be disappointed.

I've also taken two vegetarians and a vegan to this place and they raved about the variety and quality of their options.

The excellent food combined with their impressive versatility makes for an absolute treasure.
author: Samuel C.

description: The service was friendly and very authentic, as was the atmosphere. The sea bass ravioli was tasty, though I was starving and could have used a bigger portion for the price. The restaurant is a little misplaced, being in a dirty area, but is a lot nicer on the inside than it appears outside. Great place to get a good meal before a ballgame.
author: Kevin C.

description: Both the food and service was fantastic both times I have been.  I highly recommend the Scallop/Lobster/Swordfish Lasagna and the burrata with prosciutto.
author: Zach S.

description: Quaint restaurant usually filled with locals . Warm service complements the simple, well-executed Italian classics. Wine list not exceptionally extensive. MUST TRY ITEMS: Agnello al Brunello, Tagliatelle ai porcini e tartufo
author: aj s.

description:
SOOO yummy! And quite romantic too. I went for a girls night and it was the perfect (and intimate) place to catch up and giggle over wine and ravioli. The wine was fabulous and the waitstaff was so, SO, sweet. We truly had a lovely experience. We ordered family style and they were quite patient and helpful (even divided the plates). 

Will most definitely return!
author: SLH H.

description: We had an amazing dinner last night.  Great buratta and excellent sea bass ravioli.  Would definitely recommend and our waiter really made it a great experience.  Try and request Alessandro!!  He was an amazing waiter.
author: Shawn M.

description:
I'm going with a 3.5 stars. Pretty solid but not phenomenal; I'd come back though. The atmosphere is simple but warm and the food is pretty good- the caprise salad we had to start was fresh and good- not the best I've had, but very good for sure. 

Our meals didn't wow us- my man had the pesto linguine, which was good but not a huge portion (for $16) and not enough of the fresh green beans and potatoes (which were both very good). I had the halibut, which I was expecting (from the menu) to come with a few more veggies and potatoes, but it was pretty much just the fish in a sauce (but the sauce was really, really tasty). The fish wasn't the best for me- seemed a bit too fishy for halibut (maybe not as fresh as it could have been)? But then again I am very picky with the few fish I do eat. 

Also, this is a little thing but it is an Italian restaurant- the bread they bring out to start, while soft, is not very good- a good homemade rustic Italian would go a long way to set the mood right. 

Overall, a nice little addition to the neighborhood but not necessarily something to go out of your way for.
author: Kristen L.

description:
I have mixed reviews on this one... 

quality of food: ***** 
quality of service: * 
decor: ***** 
value for the dollar: *
The was good, we started with bruschetta, I had never had it that way before, but it was good. Then we moved onto fried calamari, which was also very tasty. I had the stewed rabbit and my girlfriend had the chicken, my dish was very good, but my date's chicken was VERY salty, not good... If our waiter had stopped back to ask us how the food was, we would have told him. 
The tiramisu was ok. At least the wine was good... 

Recap: 
If 2 couples at a table spend $204.00 you should at least ask us if we want a refill of our coffee... 
We shouldn't have to ask to see a desert menu... 
We shouldn't have to ask for our check...

just a reminder to wait staff:
good service = good tip (20% or more)
poor service = poor tip  (5% or less)
author: C J.

description: Yummm. Great italian food with amazing classic Italian dishes such as their rolled swordfish, or their homemade pastas.  The service is also great, perfect for family dinners or a date.
author: Holly M.

description:
Decided on La Briciola and not 54 mint.  Was able to get a table for 12 at 8pm friday when I called wednesday morning (awesome!).  Had an awesome dinner with 10 great friends (only 11 in total in the end).  

Service: 5 stars
The waitstaff were extremely attentive, helpful, and courteous.  They were constantly refilling drinks, took the patience to explain and help choose plates, and were not the least annoyed when it was time to split the check on multiple credit cards and a handful of cash. 

Food: 3.5 stars
Most of the table shared appetizers and got their own main course.  I shared all three courses with my bf.  I tried a bit of everything, but my stomach was uncomfortable throughout the entire dinner (eff you trader joe's brussel sprout samples!!!) We got the house specialty appetizer which is this pancake-like thing wrapped outside of veggies in cream sauce, linguine with clams, and the lamb.  Other appetizers I tried- calamari, deep fried veggies (pretty much like tempura battered stuff).  I liked the pasta, it was yummy and the lamb was decent too. 

Other: 4 stars
location: easy to find parking, not so easy to find place (some of my friends had trouble)
price: the entire meal plus plenty of alcohol was only $45 each including tip and tax, awksome!
bathroom: only one for the entire restaurant but nice inside

I would definitely come here again.  The people are so nice and I really want to try the food again, when my stomach doesn't feel like shit.
author: Skye W.

description: An impromptu drop-in led to a nice find.  The staff is extremely friendly and the pasta dishes was outstanding.  Appetizers and desserts were average.  The price is moderate.  A good place for a moderately priced dinner.
author: Laurence H.

description: I was pretty meh about this place. I ordered the gnocchi, which were terribly undercooked.
author: Anna J.

description:
Went here with my girlfriend for dinner on a Friday night.  It's nestled on an unsightly block next to the freeway, a convenience store, and a rather sketchy looking asian restaurant of some sort, but manages to create its own little aura of class and pleasant evenings.

We didn't have reservations and it looked pretty crowded, but the staff politely and quickly seated us at the bar, which was fine with us.  Food was really delicious, although we stuck with the "first course" pasta menu rather than the heartier meat dishes.  We shared and excellent and reasonably priced glass of Chianti, and had a thoroughly enjoyable experience.

My only comment is that this is really a $$$ sort of venue, so I'm putting in my vote for $$$ for dinner.  Maybe their lunch specials are different.
author: Alex P.

description: Cannot recommend this place highly enough!!! Service, food, ambience - everything gets 5 stars!
author: Rohan D.

description:
My wife and I had a very nice dinner at La Bricola.  We started with soup (I had the Zuppa Contadina, my wife had the Minestrone), then split the paccheri with broccoli rabe and sausage and finished off with main courses (no room for dessert).  The soups and the first course were all excellent and just the right size.  For the main course my wife had the rack of lamb and I had the bistecca, both served with sauted vegetables.  My wife really liked her lamb.  My steak was good, but didn't quite match up to my favorite bistecca meal (which was in Florence, so can't complain too much).

In addition to the great food, the ambiance of the restaurant was very relaxing and friendly.  Service was great and we just got to relax and enjoy the meal.  Definitely a great place for a relaxed and tasty dinner!
author: Richard M.

description: Great, quick dinner on a business trip. Did not expect great food so close to a highway underpass, but then again one has to ditch a lot of assumptions when visiting San Francisco. My penne with crab were simple and delicious. My friend had ravioli with lobster and was equally pleased.
author: Gabriele D.

description:
Kinda quiet on Tuesday lunchtime. 

Appetizer: 

Crostini misti di polenta chicken pate~porcini mushrooms~sausage~polenta - Well prepared pretty good. 

Main : 

Coniglio in umido con polenta stewed rabbit~tomatoes~olives~rosemary~polenta - Good but Rabbit was a bit anorexic. 

Rombo all'isolana baked halibut~fresh tomato sauce~olives~sliced potatoes - Perfect. 

Staff are very peasant. 

I would try the lunch specials next time and go in the evening next time.
author: Niall M.

description:
This place is amazing!!

My mom was coming into town so I was needing a place to take her for dinner. A friend suggested this place, raved saying that the restuaranct had just opened the food was to die for. 

I went online to check out the menu and I think for the first time in my life I truly had no idea what dish I wanted more. I wanted to order everything!

The ambiance is relaxing, romantic,  and italian of course. 

Service by italian waiters who were extremely attentive but not bothersome. My mom even made a comment about how she loves olives and the waiter comes out with a small dish of huge green olives which of course made her really happy. 

In our dinner party we had the following dishes which I would highly recommend:

Tagliatelle ai porcini e tartufo  wild porcini~black truffles~white truffle oil

Sfogliatine con gamberi e asparagi puff pastry roll~asparagus~shrimp~crab reduction

Farfalle con salmone smoked salmon~peas~brandy reduction

Linguine alle vongole fresh clams~white wine reduction

YUUUMMMMMM!!!!

I really hope this place gets discovered for what it is. I can't wait to go back.
author: Harmony P.

description:
Went here yesterday with the homies for lunch.  I had the Prosciutto Crudo panini.  Friends had the bolognese pasta and the one with bacon in it.  Both tasted pretty fresh and tantalizing.

Lunch specials are the shit.  Apparently, this place gets exponentially more expensive at dinner time, but the lunch entrees range from about $8-13, so, very reasonable!

Service was attentive, but not overly so.  To add to the authenticity, the waiter spoke with an (Italian?) accent and threw in little Italian words like "grazie" and "formaggio."  Well-played, sir, well-played.
author: Jen C.

description: I wanted to like this place.  Unfortunately, the food was quite disappointing.  I would go to Zuppa over this, any day.
author: kityee a.

description: Delicious, romantic and the perfect ambiance for a dinner date.  I love this place for good Italian and superb service.
author: Au N.

description:
We were looking for a neighborhood spot for Italian the other night, and recalled that we saw an Italian place open up in the space that had the giant tomato.  We decided to check it out and were pleasantly surprised.  

First of all, the service is great and the staff are very eager to please.  Go there if you want someone to actually help you decide on the menu, and not be snooty about it.

We started with a squid and white bean dish that was excellent.  Great sauce and just right squid.  

I opted for the sea bass ravioli with lobster sauce.  However, the sauce was really large chunks of lobster!  My one and only had the porcini mushroom pasta.  There were a ton of porcinis on the plate!  We were very pleased.  

The wine list was decent, and had a number of good options by the glass.  The staff comped us a couple after dinner peach cocktails, which were very good, but i suspect were new opening specials.  

Overall, we had a great experience and hope this place gets discovered, since it deserves to do well.
author: Greg K.

description: It has a nice, classy ambience that you would expect for a nice Italian dinner. I have to say the portion sizes are just right- not too big but leave you feeling good and not heavy. You won't need to take a doggie bag home like most Italian restaurants. I got the pasta with seafood- shrimp, mussels, squid and it looked great and tasted great. It was in a light sauce that was perfect and didn't make me feel too heavy. I'm used to the creamy alfredo sauces where I can barely finish half my meal before feeling stuffed. We also loved the ravioli which was soooo good and again the perfect amount and light. The desserts were superb. Remember to mention yelp to get a one free dessert. The waiters are great; whenever we got they always throw in something extra. The chocolate lava cake is a special and not on the menu and had to be the best. The cream puffs were also good but more filling.
author: Sheena S.

description: I came here with a party of 8.  I was pretty excited since I never been to a traditional Italian restaurant in the US before.  I ordered the Straccietti al ragú di agnello which was the hand cut pasta.  When I got my food, I was disappointed to find such a small portion in front of me.  Although the food was delicious, you definitely need to order an antipasti, primi, and secondi and expect to pay over $60 per person to get full.  The other downside is the service.  Although this place employs some of the friendliest staff I met, be ready to be ignored when it gets busy.
author: Dean W.

description: We decided on the restaurant after finding it on yelp.com, reading the very positive reviews, and its location to the Cirque du Soleil show close by.  As many, many other reviewers exclaimed, the restaurant food and service were very good.  We had the halibut, clam linguine, and fried calamari.  All three were very good and cooked to perfection.  Often I shy away from ordering halibut because too many overcook the fish, but not here.  It was extremely moist and seasoned to our taste.  Likewise, the clam linguine had plenty of fresh clams and yummy sauce.  The fried calamari was lightly battered and fried to perfection.  Best of all, our waiter, Alejandro, provided professional, friendly, and efficient service, not to mention the other restaurant staff that were friendly and welcoming as well.  Returning to this restaurant is a DEFINITE.
author: Anson D.

description:
Service was awesome, food was amazing. first restaurant i wanted to give a 5 star review.


great for dates too!
author: Kara E.

description: Great homemade pasta, lamb ragu, seabass ravioli and burratta!  Walking there was a bit interesting, but the inside is simple and nice.  Good for any occasion ... romantic dinner or business get together.  Pleasantly surprised on our first visit!
author: Brett E.

description:
I hosted a birthday dinner for 20 people here for my husband and worked out all the details via email with Rhiannon, prior to ever visiting the restaurant.  Rhiannon was so professional and helped me pick out a prefix menu that wouldn't be outrageously expensive.

Our friends were beyond impressed with the food, the service, and the price.  The restaurant is small, but they provided an area that was solely our table and group.  The service was outstanding and the night was a success.

I HIGHLY recommend that Gnocchi.....delicious!
author: Ben N.

description: I recently planned a company dinner at La Briciola to kick off a conference held at the Moscone Center. I needed someplace within walking distance, reasonably priced with good food for a diverse group of around 40 people.  I have to say, La Briciola not only met all my criteria, but surpassed my expectations! Not only was the food and wine selection excellent, the service was great and the staff were well attentive to our group and the venue provided a very nice atmosphere. Working with Alessandro was a pleasure and I would highly recommend this restaurant for any group or small party looking for outstanding Italian food and great service in San Francisco!
author: Kristen K.

description: I had homemade lasagna there and it was amazing! The service also vey good. I will definitely go back there again.
author: Maggie S.

description:
1 star for a fabulous edition to the neighborhood. Now if only the greasy spoon diner straight out of 1968 and the "crack head central" liquor store next door could get it together.

1 star for the waiter who brought us out a complimentary bruschetta plate when they accidentally brought us one person's salad entree as an appetizer. And it was amazing.

1 star for the lovely ambiance. The waiters are all Italian and speak a very charming, non-smarmy Itanglish. 

My boyfriend said his filet mignon was as good as those served at Harris' however my fettuccine alle vongole pretty bland. I'd order something else when I come back!
author: Eli B.

description: The ambiance and the food make for the perfect romantic dinner. My boyfriend and I spent our one year anniversary and it was simply beautiful. I got the bruscetta to start and the Lamb Ragu. So delicious! I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Step aside bacar, you have been replaced by La Briciola as my new neighborhood favorite.  Actually the position was vacant for a couple years.  

We stopped in for dinner Saturday night and found a vibrant dining room with an eclectic mix of customers.  We were offered seats at the small bar while our table was prepared, and were seated 5 minutes later.  Overall I thought the service was exceptional.  

The food was also exceptional.  We started with a spinach/goat cheese/walnut salad.  The walnuts were nicely caramelized and the ratio of salad to dressing was perfect.  We also had some rolled zucchini and eggplant stuffed with ricotta and topped with bechamel sauce.  I would have put a red sauce on it.

Then we moved on to a pasta with a beautiful mushroom and truffle sauce.  The pasta was cooked perfectly and the dish was delightful.

For main courses, we had a halibut in a tomato sauce.  GF said it was delicious.  I didn't make it over there because I was busy with a filet mignon with fontina and truffle sauce.  It was prepared to a perfect medium rare and the sauce was stunning.  I should have licked the plate.

The wine list was filled with good value wines.  We were drinking prosecco and barbera from the by the glass menu.  Both were very good.

Minor complaints probably not worth mentioning, but sort of.  The music was too low to be background music.  It was at that volume that keeps dragging you in wondering what instrument, language, song, etc.

They could use a little better orchestration at the table.  It looks like they are running a really thinly staffed floor.  On the bright side, anyone passing by would fill water or take away dishes.  On the down side, it was sort of chaotic.

So, welcome to the neighborhood.  We hope you stay a while.  See you soon...
author: Stu M.

description: Wow for excellence in food.  My girlfriend and I can live off the bread and olive oil.  We love the olive oil and wished we could have taken a bottle back home.  I had the Grigliata mista di pesce.  Everything was grilled and cooked perfectly.  Simply done and very delicious.  I would love to come back and try the rest of the menu.  A great Italian restaurant to eat if you are in SF area.
author: Henry L.

description: Cute interior, great, authentic Italian waiters, nice, large selection on the menu.  Very good minestrone soup, and our pastas were fresh, homemade, and the sauces were fantastic.  We'll definitely be back!
author: David B.

description:
food was average 3 stars but what really set this italian restaurant apart from other eateries in soma are the service and the atmosphere. 

our waiter was great! he was super friendly and knowledgeable. i am generally not a big tipper; i tend to hover around 10-15%, but the service here was so good and i had such a good evening of service that i tipped 20%. 

another really cool thing about this restaurant is that you feel like you are in italy. all the waiters here are italian and speak the language. it really makes the place feel so much more authentic.

lastly, the atmosphere was great. i came here with an out of town friend, but this place is perfect for a date. the lights are dimmed, it isn't noisy and the place gives off a romantic feel. almost like a scene from "lady and the tramp"... only no trouble making siamese cats :D
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description: For food, it's better than 3 stars, but not quite 4.  For service, it's 4 stars.  Good place for lunch; would not be my pick for an evening meal.
author: Firas A.

description:
We decided to try this place after sampling their food at an event recently.  Our toddler son was with us, so we went at 5:30 pm, hoping to get a table and finish early without disturbing other diners.

The service was quick and friendly, decor simple and tasteful, and the food was delicious.  My husband got the pasta with ink sauce, which was excellent.  My seafood pasta was very fresh and light, but a bit bland.  I probably could have added some salt/pepper but I devoured it too fast.  :P

We'd love to go back and try other items on their menu.
author: Shoyi C.

description:
Wow... La Briciola was superb

Bread and olive oil- Olive oil with diced olives? The olive flavor was very distinct, but the diced pieces were reddish. very good, we had 2 servings.

Insalata della casa- probably the best house salad I've had in a long time. Fresh, bright green leaves in a light and flavorful vinegarette.

Frittura di calamari- I love calamari, and always get it, THIS calamari was excellent. very lightly breaded, fresh and tasty pieces of squid, cooked perfectly, with a warm marinara sauce.

Ravioli di cernia (seabass filled ravioli with lobster reduction) Not my dish, but my boyfriend loved it. 

Petto di pollo ai porcini (chicken breast,wild porcini mushroom sauce). Chicken was super tender, mushrooms very flavorful, perfect portion, grilled broccoli and potatoes lightly seasoned - grilled to perfection. Mushroom sauce was excellent, melts in your mouth. 

Their menu offers Primi (first course) and Secondi (second course) so the portions are smaller, but with an appetizer, bread and salad, one course was plenty for us. 

We also enjoyed a bottle of Artezin- the only red zin on the menu but a great choice that complimented our food.

Parking lot right past the restauraunt on Stillman, to the left, and the attendent leaves after 7 so we parked for free.
author: sandra d.

description:
Good casual, cozy Italian with no pretense and a touch of warmth.  Bread is soooo soft and delish - always a plus.  Comes with a yummy olive tapenade / olive oil combination that isn't too heavy on the olive.
Burrata appetizer and carpaccio are good.  Had the pennette with crab that was very simple, light, and good.  (Best part - they didn't skimp on the crab!)   Would come back with a small group (4 or under).
author: Cathy L.

description: Amazing food!!!!  Hands down!!!! From the seared Ahi, to the rack of lamb to the home made pastas and bread!!!  Im in love!!  Service is excellent and the staff and owners are friendly and professional!  I had my birthday dinner there and was delighted!!!  Highly recommend!
author: Stacy P.

description: The portions were just right - enough to be satisfying but you certainly don't feel "full" afterwards. Prices for this type of restaurant are about on par with other San Francisco restaurants. The interior of the place is nice. It's small, intimate, cozy. Perfect for a dinner outing for two or a small group. I went with a group of about twenty people, and the restaurant was a little too small for a group of my size. Service was fantastic, easily the best thing about the establishment.
author: Joe A.

description:
in San Francisco and most other places you are rushed out of a restaurant. at max you've probably spent an hour and a half at most sitting down for a meal. at La Briciola you get the true italian experience. you order your appetizer, pasta and entree. the time between each of those courses is at least 30 min. it's a slowed down version of the dinner we know. i'm sure they expect us to take our time and enjoy the food and the company, which is quite refreshing.

i can't remember everything i had there but i recall everything being very good. i also recall a lot of truffle accents in their dishes, which i am all for. truffle? count me in! the burrata was buttery and the tagliatelle was oozing with truffly goodness. the server was kind enough to give us a dessert sampler which i'm still not sure of the reason, but i'm not one to turn down free dessert. 

i would definitely recommend this restaurant.

side note: as a kid, i always wanted to go to the restaurant that had a huge tomato poking out from it's entry way. i never got a chance to eat at that restaurant but it  has now converted into La Briciola so i guess i didn't completely miss out!
author: Regina C.

description: Perfect place for wine and cheese at the bar, a romantic date, or a boistrous going-away party. Excellent service, a menu I could live off of, and great cheese and wine offerings. In my neighborhood and thus a new favorite and regular spot. Go here. Eat cheese. Drink the Sangiovese (it's a steal at 27 a bottle). Then decide to pack up and move to SOMA just to be closer to this gem.
author: Autumn K.

description: Good service and good food! Their spinach salad and halibut were delicious!
author: Cara H.

description: Service was good and very friendly. However, the food was bland and rubbery (fish.) I can't see how this place is 4 stars.
author: Norman F.

description:
Order: Caciucco di viareggio crab~calamari~mussels~clams~shrimp~salmon~swordfish    25

Pro:
-parking is okay
-nice atmosphere
-nice waiters
-min wait time

Con:
-no crab showed up in my food!
-pretty much a whole plate w/o any veges
author: Jenny L.

description:
Had a dynamite dinner at La Briciola on a recent vacation weekend with the spouse.  Booked an early reservation (6:15) and arrived even earlier (5:30).  Restaurant, as expected, wasn't yet full and we were given the choice of nice tables either in the front near the windows or the back near the service kitchen.  Chose the back, and as the place started to fill up, were happy with that location.  Quiet yet not too quiet.

Our server, Gian, was really good, attentive, and knowledgeable about the menu and wine list.  We got the seared octopus w/cannelini beans and barley to start - excellent; the octopus was firm without being rubbery and very flavorful.  Wife had the lamb ragu with hand cut pasta and the pasta was out of this world.  I got the rack of lamb, which was crispy seared on the outside and just right medium rare on the inside.  

The restaurant is a bit of a hike on the SOMA side of Third Street if you're coming from Union Square or the Financial District, but it's walkable and, hey, you can eat and drink more.  Prices are reasonable for what you get - both for the food and wine.  All in all, a really classy place and we will be back.
author: David M.

description:
I live in the area so I'm super excited about this new restaurant!!!
We were walking home from dinner when it started raining - right as we approached the door of this mysterious new... restaurant?  
We walked in for a glass of wine and indulged in 2 glasses of marvelous moscato.  The restaurant is really lovely inside, they put a lot of work and love into it and it shows.  Unfortunately we didn't get to try the food but the service was wonderful and the ambiance romantic and welcoming. We are planning on checking out the Sunday brunch this week!
(wish you guys a lot of success! welcome to the neighborhood!)
author: Mrs. G.

description: Fantastic food & nice ambience. We come here almost every other day. Love the moderate portion too.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Awesome place. Tucked in that off the beaten path part of San Francisco but worth the journey. The gnocchi was the best I have ever had, really. Service was on point and the decor and ambiance was fantastic.
author: R H.

description: Help excellent, food so so I will not be going back, excellent wine and staff.  Mussels were miniscule with little flavor.  The lasagna was without tomato based sauce.  Not to my liking.  Salad and calamari where blah.  I will go to my tried and true Italian restaurants from now on.
author: Dorothy C.

description: A nice place with gracious service and good food.  I would go there whenever I want Italian food South of Market.
author: George P.

description:
I don't usually write reviews but this place is so worth mentioning... 

We had a party of 7 and loved our experience.

We made the reservation that day and they sat us right away. 

First of all, we loved... I mean "nothing is left on your plate" loved... everything we had. I'm not usually a lamb fan but I loved their lamb. They serve a very generous portion and it was by far the best lamb we had tasted since New Zealand where their lamb are fresh from that day. I had the sea bass ravioli which was great with lobster reduction sauce. The lamb ragu, the soup, and the starters were also fantastic. 

I loved our servers who were so friendly and timely. They treated us so well and even gave us a complimentary starter. 

They are my new favorite Italian spot. I *heart* La Briciola!
author: Yong A.

description: For the price, this place ranks as one of the best Italian spots in SF. Make sure you get the vegetable truffle crepe as an appetizer or you will regret it. Don't care if you don't think you will like it . . . you will. Also the filet is damn good.
author: Bradley K.

description: Tearing down 3rd street its easy to miss this place! The exterior doesn't give much away but once inside you are greeted to a smart casual dining room. The service is excellent and food is excellent. All the dishes taste fresh and are not too heavy. The potato gnocchi was light and tasty. Followed by the rack of lamb - the meat was perfectly done. Finish with the panna cotta!. I'll definitely be going back.
author: Kiran G.

description: This was literally the worst place I have ever eaten in San Fran. The service was miserable. Barely recognized once meal was completed. Ravioli was below par. Honestly I think they found a jar of tomato sauce and poured it over non cooked noodles hoping to charge 15 dollars without people noticing. Will not be going back. Save your dollars.
author: Martin F.

description:
Yay! We are so happy and lucky that La Briciola opened in our neighborhood! We thoroughly enjoyed our experience and meal last night. 

Taste: Quite outstanding! Fresh fish, hand made pasta, delicate flavors. Simple, delicious and light (not Americanized-Meatball-Italian).

Ambiance: We felt as if we were in Italy due to the combination of modern and rustic decor. The owners put a lot of effort into the detail and it shows. In fact, we were reminded so much of Italy that we spent the rest of the evening planning a trip back.

Well done! Mille Grazie!
author: Shelley C.

description: Classy Italian food. Good service. Happy to find this place as it was accommodating for a large group and not too overcrowded.
author: Gagan T.

description: Random location in Soma, the freeway is literally overhead! But the food at La Briciola is well made and authentic. There is plenty of seating inside and service is very good. I came here with a party of 9 on a sunday.  The cesar salad and seafood linguine were delicious!  Pricing is quite reasonable too. If you're looking for elegant italian food in Soma, go to La Briciola.
author: Ka C.

description:
My wife and I tried this restaurant out for the first time this past weekend.  All in all, I was pretty disappointed and will not be going back.

To start off, both my wife and I found it a bit odd that an Italian restaurant would have an appetizer (Fagottino ripieno) that included crepes (French).  We ordered it and it was tasty - probably the highlight of the meal.  I ordered the Halibut as my entree from the 'Second Course' menu and for $22 it was not only a small piece of fish but did not come as advertised with vegetables and roasted potatoes.  The fish was overcooked and had no taste or texture.  The ceramic dish it was served in arrived so hot - I think the fish continued to cook at the table.  

We also struck out in the wine department, with all three wines (Pinot Grigio, Barbera, Sangiovese).  The Pinot Grigio was over chilled and tasteless.  My wife's Barbera tasted off and after sending it back and getting the Sangiovese - it did not really taste any better,

The host was pleasant when we entered the restaurant and our waiter was nice but did not come by to check on how we were doing when we received our entrees.  The restaurant was half-full so I'm not sure why service was inattentive.

We won't be going back to this restaurant but instead will walk another block or so to the Italian restaurant next to where Bong Su used to be (forgetting the name)
author: Raul K.

description: Great food and atmoshere.  Good service and a good place to splurge.
author: Doug N.

description: My wife, my parents and I just ate at La Briciola and we really enjoyed it.  Don't let the exterior fool you, it's a nice, quiet atmosphere with great service.  We decided to do a lot of sharing so we started with the minestrone and the zuppa  ...as well as two appetizers, the assorted cheese plate and the seafood pastry puff.  I'm not a big minestrone fan but my wife absolutely loved it.  I preferred the zuppa, but honestly I could have done without either.  We ordered three main courses: the gnocchi contadina, the ravioli and the grigliato.  I liked the gnocchi (although the table next to us was reaching albout t the gnocchi triage).  The ravioli was delicious, but the star was the grigliato.  The swordfish was phenomenal and the salmon tasted like it had just been pulled out of the bay.  The calimari was good too, but the shrimp was a little mushy.  However, like I mentioned, the swordfish and salmon were just phenomenal and I would definitely order that again.  We finished up by sharing the warm chocolate cake for dessert.  It was a wonderful evening with attentive and friendly staff and I would highly recommend La Briciola.
author: Josh R.

description: I had a good time here and it was a smaller place but not small in the sense that you feel cramped. Everything was spaced out well.
