I thought the food and service were good, the host person was very nice and responsive to our requests. I would go back there again given the chance, maybe not a primary choice because I want to try more restaurants but if someone suggested La Briciola I wouldn't mind going back.
author: David G.

description:
Brought some friends here for dinner after reading reviews on Yelp. First time was amazing. My husband had stuffed swordfish and my friends had both had gnocchi. They are both gnocchi afficionados and wouldn't stop raving. The service was excellent and the the decor charming.

Second time was good, but not outstanding. Hubby's swordfish was smaller and not hot. 

The location is kind of odd, but at least there's parking. It's a bit hidden--you have to be looking for it right near the skanky liquor shop, but it's worth it.
author: L. B.

description: Out-of-place location, aka hard to find. But once inside, the ambiance was great and the service was highly attentive. The plates are fancy, and the food was great. Just a bit too expensive for my taste, aka this is a visit-once to try it out and eat fancy Italian kind of place.
author: Alice L.

description: The service was fantastic. The food was nothing spectacular, but it was solidly good. Unfortunately, in the case of this restaurant, this places it in the realm of "overpriced". I'd go back again if someone was eager to try it, but otherwise, probably not.
author: Jason L.

description: I recently hosted a dinner party for 12, all out of towners, at La Briciola and everyone raved about their dining experience.  From appetizers to homemade pasta dishes and finishing with tasty desserts, the entire evening was a success.  Reasonably priced, generous portions, and great service made for a fun evening.  Thanks Yelp!
author: Abel G.

description: My wife and I had an outstanding dinner at La Briciola last Friday. The interior is warm and stylishly decorated. The owners were very friendly and made us feel like welcome friends instead of first time visitors, and the waiters were excellent. Then came the food. The seafood ravioli was probably the best ravioli I've ever had in SF, Italy, or anywhere. This instantly became one of our favorite restaurants in SF.
author: Tad B.

description: The food was some of the best Italian I've ever had. The atmosphere was a little stuffy and we felt a little ignored because we didn't order any alcohol.
author: Cece B.

description: The fried calamari was surprisingly good. It was lightly battered and fried. Not greasy. However it needed more seasoning. We ordered the lasagna special and chicken with mushrooms for our entrees. Unfortunately, We had not seen previous reviews on the lasagna. The lasagna was soupy. There was no texture to it and it was bland. The chicken and mushrooms were mush and bland again. The mushrooms had a weird texture as if they were sitting around in the sauce all day. The chicken also had an odd mushy texture. The broccoli was incredibly salty. The only good part of the dish were the potatoes. Our entrees were not edible. We did not eat them and they were taken off the check. The service was also very slow. Our waiter never came over to ask how the meal was, we had to have the busboy send him over. The place itself was small, but well decorated with a good atmosphere. The food however was terrible and not reflective of pricing. The only reason this place got two stars is because of the decent calamari.
author: Dave R.

description: We went there for dinner once and are definitely going back. The appetizers are not so impressive. But my sea bass ravioli with lobster reduction was amazing. My husband liked his calamari risotto. The waiters there are kind and welcoming.
author: X L.

description:
Came here last night for a Grub with Us dinner and met some pretty cool people, BUT was highly disappointed in the food.  I was really hoping I'd like it since I live just a few blocks away and love Italian food, but it was not to be.  

The best part of the whole meal was the olive oil that came with the bread at the beginning.  I'd buy that by the bottle.  

In terms of the meal, we started with various bruschettas, which were pretty bland and on bread that wasn't toasted enough.  Then when we moved onto the pastas, the mushroom tagliatelle was pretty good, but the gnocchi was again bland.  There was nothing great about the sauce, actually, I would venture to say that a jar of Ragu would have had more taste.  Finally ending with the profiteroles that tasted somewhat stale, like they had been defrosted from a frozen box from Costco.  

Not to mention, there just wasn't enough food for everyone.  This could've been either Grub with Us or the restaurant's fault, but either way, it reflects really poorly on the restaurant when we all paid $30 for dinner (excluding drinks) and all went home hungry.
author: Olivia T.

description:
went here a couple weeks ago for dinner on my bachelorette night. 

the environment is very clean, atmosphere was nice, lighting a bit dim but staff was quite attentive. bread and water was refilled without asking. I do question why they take away utensils when they take away our appetizer plates but do not bring everyone back a set of utensils when entrees are served. 

everyone's food looked to be of quality ingredients. the servings are also good. i had the squid ink risotto that was described as "calamari~ink sauce~scallop," they reall do mean SCALLOP. no scallopS. there was this lonely little piece of scallop on the big plate. it wasn't even a WHOLE scallop, but half of one. if it's going to be there just for decoration, why bother putting it on as part of the dish description?? it's like saying parsley sprig. so yes, i feel like it was false advertisment. the risotto was also too salty for my tastes.

everyone else thought their food was okay, but nothing to write home about. i can't even remember what appetizers we had. here's the thing that bothered me the most though... most people had pasta dishes -- they were all served on COLD dishes. even the lasagna that in any other restaurant comes out with the "be careful, the  dish is hot" warning. no worries here. so halfway through we all had cold food. :(

if you were nearby and were starving, it'll suffice but i wouldn't make it a trip out here just to try it out.
author: sasa w.

description: Don't let the unassuming building facade fool you - inside is a great atmosphere coupled with very good service, all backed by solid food.  The sausage risotto was great.  I can't  wait to sample more dishes here.  Bonus: reasonable prices create a strong value.  Check it out, great restaurant.
author: Robin S.

description: Service was VERY good. The food was also yummy, though I can't say it blew my socks off....hence the 4 stars.  Perfect place for an early dinner before a ball game.
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
Oh yeah!! We stumbled in after a Giants game (I mean stumbled upon it really since how many $10 beers would it take for us to actually stumble...). The food was truly fantastic- top to bottom. warm fresh bread and yummy olive tapanade. DO NOT miss the veg crepes- really I should have just had this and a salad for dinner, since it was perfection...I just wish I had more room since my sweetie (don't feel too sorry for him) had to help finish my rolled stuffed swordfish (YUM!). He also loved his  sauted octopus ( I'm not a fan of the little suckers but the fennel in the dish was fab) and then he was moaning over his new york steak with black truffles... since he usually shares I know it was good since I didn't even get near it;-0. thant's OK. The attentive and friendlyowners kept filling my glass so I didn't care. I was full anyway. Nice to get some real portions!  
note-There were about 20  guys having a pre-bachelor party dinner, so I am sure it is good for groups- they all looked happy!
author: Spunky M.

description: i feel ashamed of myself for not making a review sooner for this place all you need to know is go here...
author: Gonzalo P.

description:
Great service, food and wine at very reasonable prices.  

I tried the chicken pâté on polenta with mushrooms which was delicious and the spinach gnocchi which was also delicious. The BF had the ear shaped pasta with beef. Minus 1 star for being in a location with absolutely nothing else around it (except for the W hotel 2-3 block down). 

Regardless, I'd definitely recommend this place for yummy italian!
author: Angela K.

description: Food was very good, but portion size a little small. All of us were guys and all of us left hungry. Bread was one of the best I've ever tasted. Amazing.
author: Bib G.

description: Fantastic. Location is a bit off the radar but that translates directly into a seat for my ass when I'm hungry for great Italian that does not try to make up for it's quality with quantity.
author: Patrick H.

description:
We just returned from an amazing dinner at  La Brciola. We had walked past it several times and after checking out the positive reviews on YELP,  we decided to give it a try.  The minute we walked in we felt as if we were being welcomed into the owners' home. The food was excellent. Each of us had something different - fish, pasta and lamb and everyone was delighted with their choices. 

Although the restaurant filled up while we were there, we were not rushed at all and enjoyed a leisurely meal. At the end of the meal, the owner graciously offered each of us a glass of  dessert wine. What a perfect ending to the evening. 

One of the owners told us that they had been open a little over a year. This restaurant  is a welcome addition to the neighborhood!!  We certainly plan to return.
author: Anne M.

description: *I believe this is one of the best Italian restaurant in SF (and I'm Italian !).
author: Federico S.

description: Outstanding. Quaint little place, homemade pasta was exceptional and all around, the food was prepared perfectly. Good wine list and knowledgeable staff. A little loud and cramped but in an intimate way, which is part of the charm. Will return!
author: Walter A.

description: I've been to Briciola twice now for lunch. I work right around the corner. The  first time I had penne in a ragu. It was awesome. The staff is friendly and the service was really prompt. On my second visit I had a lunch special of shell pasta in a sausage marinara. The portion was a little small, but that was ok. The pasta was al dente--just right. Service was really friendly and prompt. I really like this place. I'm from Boston so I grew up on Italian. I lived in the Central Valley for 10 years before coming to the Bay Area. I was literally starving for good Italian. Now I'm starving for good Mexican. I guess that's how it goes.
author: Jamie A.

description:
I am not sure why anyone would give this place such a high ratings, my experience was really bad. 
First and for worst, they allow DOGS in the restaurant!!!!!!!! I am not talking about outside by the door, I am talking about inside by the tables!!! Where is the Health department to close this place down!! that is just unlawful!! and frankly disgusting, to also see the Wait staffs pet the dogs as if not a big deal! gosh!! what happened to H1N1 scare?? what happened to sanitizing!!!! 
Now our food came cold so it was just not appetizing, but I will rate it!! 
Now the food: except the vegetable filled crepe everything else was really bad. Here is the list: 
1) Chick pea soup: red water, with five chickpeas and some ground meat in it, no taste nothing. 0 Star 
2) Salad: mix greens, with couple of tomatoes, average. 1/2 star 
3) Vegetable crepe: the only good food and tasty. you get two of it. 3 stars 
4) Vegetable panini: Cold bun, cold vegetables as if the vegetables were grilled the day before keep in the fridge and now put on the bun, really bad, french fries was OK. 0 star 
5) Veal: Three pieces of veal size of devil eggs, and cold cold vegetables. 
I didn't mind all of these if the service was good, but when we told the waiters that the food is cold, she said oh the panini is suppose to be cold!!!!!!!!!! Excuse me, this maybe your first time, but not mine having a panini!! Then she brought us a side of the vegetables. All she said was oh I told the kitchen!!! AND????? nothing. 
We got the bill and no discount. I am sorry I don't expected, but when you screw up at least either replace the food or give something. 
Anyway, the dog thing was a total turned off but the food was even worse. 
I am not ever going back there again!!! don't waste your time, money, there are plenty of places for good food, clean environment. THANK GOD this is SF!!!
author: Nina Z.

description: Awesome tasty italian food with delicious appetizers and super friendly staff. The place itself hides between a parking loft and a highway, could be hard to find first; it's a true hidden gem.
author: Tamas K.

description: In a town full of Italian and mediterranean restaurants you need to be good to survive as one of many. This little narrow Italian dressed up all chic in taupe and browns does not let you down. Great fresh ingredients well executed at prices that dont break the bank. The wine list is great and the BTG list is long on Italian gems, great Verdichio for example. Waiter was excellent, we had a glass of Barbera which was his recommendation but it was cooked a little, he opened a new bottle refreshed our glasses and gave us a half a glass each of prosecco for desert free as an apology for the poor condition of the earlier Barbera, which was a nice gesture and the fresh bottle was excellent anyway. The truffle and porcini pasta is fabulous, would agree with other reviewers
author: Tim B.

description: This place is great.  A good of friend of mine took me here because I was visiting from out of town.  I noticed that the decor was very nice and we arrived in the early evening to as the sun went down, the place really lit up.  A really nice ambience.  The food was fabulous.  the Gnocchi was soft and light which is always a good sign of an Italian restaurant.  The wine list was great and the owners are a great young couple and it is always nice to support a family owned place.
author: Danny P.

description:
We are retired & live in Marin County so do not come to SF often but a trip to this restaurant is shorter & less expensive than a 15-20 hour flight, 1-2 days jet lag etc. trip to Italy because we find the food here as authentic Italian and as good and better than many places in Italy. What is is my opinion worth ? I go to Italy at least once per year (my parents, grandparents & many relatives are born in Italy) and a main objective is to enjoy the food-as most people know, it is no place for a diet. 

I really appreciate that the principals are entrepreneurs as they did work for a very good restaurant in North Beach before their ventured out on their own and I like people who have the guts to follow their dreams. My immigrant family approximately 75-100 years ago worked many jobs 14-16 hours per day and I really admire LUCIANO who working for a major financial institution 5 days per week, also, with his lovely wife, RHIANNON, work many nights and weekends here. Along with delightful LUCA, another owner, and all the other Italian speaking waiterstaff, treat us and, I noticed, all customers like family. Its location, perhaps, does not make this a prime tourist destination like North Beach or Fishermans' Wharf where probably over 50% are non-repeat customer tourists as many locals don't want to deal with tight parking conditions in the area. I always feel that a successful neighborhood restaurant depends upon repeat customers so the food has to be good. I always notice ample parking here & many times actually find spots on same block on the street.

For those who have been to Roma in Italia you should recall that many of the restaurants in Piazza Navona, Piazza del Popolo, The Pantheon, along Via Veneto etc. have barkers outside enticing you to come in. Even here in SF's Northbeach you'll find people enticing you to enter. Many of these places are basic tourist traps. If you recall the movie/book etc. of "Alice in Wonderland", she enters the Looking  Glass (her mirror) into a Fairytale type environment. Here, at La Briciola, there are double doors to enter and no one enticing you to come in with "Buon Giorno, Buona Sera"---this will cordially be said to you here after you enter. Thus, it is not a walk by, spontaneous come in place but a destination point restaurant. This is a restaurant mostly visited by the locals &, I'm sure, recommended, or should be, to tourists by concierges of upscale hotels. 

The entire idylic setting is like a Trattoria/ Osteria or informal good food "ristorante" in a small village in Italia. Look at the website & photos. At the back is an arched room that makes me feel extremely nostalgic as if I were with my family years back in our dining room. The sights of the appetizing various plates of aromatic dishes and the warm and lively Italian atmosphere is the closest thing to being there. 

I want to add that for us a good dining experience is even more than the food and the entire well trained staff always make us feel like family and despite the place buzzing busy at times, we are never made to rush as happens in many places when they need turn the tables. Rhiannon, Luciano, Luca & others always return frequently to our table " Tutto Bene and Tutto a Posto" (is everthing OK ?) and also chatting with us. Without a reservation one night, we were still graciously accomodated and allowed to sit and wait at the lovely bar setting---it was so delightful, we ate at the bar & turned frequently enjoying watching the very proficient & friendly owners also assist the waiters when needed and walk the floor like orchestra leaders directing the musicians(waiters, cooks, bus boys etc.) to deliver a stupendous performance.

On a personal basis, there is a characteristic I especially like about them. When I speak Italian, they respond in Italian. When I speak English, they respond in English. This allows me the dignity of speaking the language of my ancestors, weakly or not, as many times their English is better than my Italian. 

WOW---the food, did I forget to tell you about the food !!! Hope nobody is waiting for me to describe some things I like on the menu. I do not find a need to mention specific food items. Many times when I like something I return & order the same thing but here there are so many delectible choices, and my wife always orders something different so we can share, we tried many dishes and look forward to trying more. In short, they were all very tasty . Believe me, I would not have written this recommendation if it were not so. Go for yourselves. See the online menu. It is very creative & enticing & the photos will show some of the atmosphere I've described. Again, want to escape to Italia for an afternoon or evening ? This is the place !!!
author: Mando R.

description: Came here on a Saturday evening with a party of 7, and we were graciously accomodated. Everything was great - from the ambiance of the restaurant, to the service, to the food. I liked how the restaurant was not overly crowded - in other words, they have ample space between tables, and it is relatively quiet so you can actually enjoy a conversation with your party. Service was responsive. I ordered the rack of lamb, which while it was not the best I have ever had in my life, I would give it a solid mark and recommend it if you are craving red meat. Others at my table ordered various pasta dishes and appetizers, and I heard no complaints. This place is worth a try and recommended.
author: Anderson L.

description: I was trying to make a reservation for a Tuesday night dinner near Caltrain. This was the only highly rated restaurant on Yelp that appealed to me and had availability. I was very happy with the service - our waiter had an adorable Italian accent and was excited to provide recommendations - and my sister and I really enjoyed our food and wine. Even with the craziness of a Giant's game about to start, the restaurant was peaceful and not crowded...the perfect spot to catch up. I'll keep this in mind for the future, especially the next time I go to a Giant's game.
author: Nicole V.

description:
Went for lunch and had pasta with pesto, pasta with eggplant + mushrooms and some kind of caprese sandwich.  Delicious food, especially the bread and olive oil, which had chopped kalamatas in it!  

The restaurant was surprisingly empty for lunch but the service was attentive.  The decor is cute too!

Plus we went for a bday and the waitress gave us a slice of tiramisu with a candle in it.. we didn't even ask for this!

I would come here again!
author: Bees S.

description: A great dinner choice! La Briciola is our solid favorite for an impromptu nice dinner out and we've been there several times. We always get the beef carpaccio, which is one of the better ones we've had in SF. All of the pasta and entree dishes we've tried there (pasta bolognese, lamb, fish, etc.), including dessert (molten chocolate cake), have always been very good.
author: Deena M.

description:
been here twice, both times for dinner
both times GREAT service, the owner is super friendly. it has such a warm, homey feel. The decor is amazing, i couldn't stop staring at the "indoor-outdoor" windows, if you've been here, you know what I'm talking about. if you havent, you should try this place

apparently the lamb ragu is wonderful and saucy 
I've had the mushroom and truffle pasta, very yummy and fragrant
the clams are also good, according to my friend

there are vegetarian crepes that look like little purses filled with vege scramble-like goodness, very creamy sauce with fragrant white truffle oil - a bit too creamy for my taste, but still very good

roommate got the crab pasta pennette (sp?), she liked it

the 2nd time i went was for a friend's birthday, they brought out a pretty hefty slice of tiramisu with a candle in it, they also sang happy birthday, super cute
we also ordered 2 chocolate souffles, also warm and delicious, more of a "lava cake" than a souffle. i prefer souffle served in the ramekin. acutally the more i think about it, this definitely was not a souffle, it was not poofy at all... it should be changed to "molten lava cake" but i guess that sounds less nice :P

i will def be visiting this place again
author: Mimi Z.

description: Gnocchi was Amazing! Enjoyed the atmosphere and the waiters. Great service and amazing food. Highly recommend
author: Jacob C.

description:
I went with a large group a couple of weeks ago and had a great experience.  We were able to secure a reservation for 9 people (including one child) earlier in the day.  Several people in our party arrived late, but our server was totally accomodating.  He kept our champagne chilled until the entire group arrived (corkage fee was reasonable).  Throughout the meal, he was incredibly friendly -- A+ for service.

The food was also excellent.  Rarely does a pasta dish stick out in my mind weeks later, but the lamb ragu was AMAZING.  I can't wait to go back and have it again.  Everyone else in the party was also pleased with their selections.  The chef even made a special simple pasta plate for the child in our group.

Even though La Briciola's location is a bit random, it's awesome and definitely worth the trip.  Easy parking in the neighborhood, too.  Highly, highly recommend it!
author: Sarala N.

description: Stopped in here for a light, early dinner and the thought it was alright. The starters were good, but the mains were heavy and oily. I loved the charm of the staff and I will be back again to try to give it another try because you never know when there is an off night. I say give it a whirl and decide if it's for you.
author: Miss B.

description:
What a find on our way to the Giants game. House made pasta just perfect. I had sausage and broccoli rabe, my husband had lamb and wide noodles.  The salumi plate with the olives and vegetables was a great appetizer; my husband had octopus with beans and fennel. 

Many "frutte di mare" dishes (octopus and calamari, etc.) on the menu.  Excellent service.  Good wine list.  This place should be jammed every night, but before it is, drop by for a plate of pasta at the bar on your way to the game. You won't need reservations.  Worth a trip, even in the off season!

I'd give it 4 1/2 stars.
author: Marilyn R.

description: Amazing gnocchi. Very good tiramisu. We arrived fifteen minutes late but they still managed to seat us. Service was very friendly. The food took quite a while to arrive, but the atmosphere was so cute that I didn't really mind much.
author: kim d.

description: I work in soma. La Briciola is my go to lunch for great Italian food and wonderful servers.
author: charles r.

description:
probably a 4.5 but bonus points for being walking distance from my apt (high five). 

service is always great, and everybody i take there loves it. my favorites are the seafood penne and truffle filet mignon. 

typically isn't packed so a good choice for walk-ins for those of us that don't plan ahead
author: ben c.

description: Appetizers were the best part - our main entrees were not very good.  Perhaps I ordered wrong, but the salmon pasta was a very strong salmon flavor - might as well not have had anything else in the dish.
author: Joshua R.

description: Tried it based on reviews and proximity to our hotel. I am glad we did. Not a stellar location by any means but the food, service and ambiance all made up for it. The four of us enjoyed a representative sampling of all they offered. We sampled meat, pasta and fish with nary a complaint. Reasonable prices and great service, made the kids feel right at home. If you find yourself in the financial district and have a hankering for great Italian fare search no further.
author: John K.

description: The food was very good, the service was excellent, and the overall atmosphere made the entire evening out special.  I would go again.
author: Linda K.

description: Great space, nice service and basically good food...hope this helps the neighborhood its in. It was nice to be able to get a moderately casual dinner without a long wait or reservation. It felt neighborhoody and relaxed.
author: Jason P.

description:
waaaay overrated!  

-the duck ragu was ok, but the gnocchi was too big, dense, and chewy.  
-the mushroom and truffle pasta with truffle oil, had too much truffle oil and no shaved truffles until we asked for them.  (even then they gave us a miserly small plate of truffles that were cut, rather than shaven.)  the overkill and abuse of truffle oil continues!
-the lamb ragu...was actually delicious, but the portion looked like a kid's size meal (age 3) and the hand cut noodles were overcooked.

we had wine, appetizers, a main course and passed on dessert.  the food for the price was offensive.  the waiter that shaved parm-cheese on my ragu said, 'bon appetite'...in an italian restaurant...i guess i could go on and on, but i definitely won't be returning.
author: Scott C.

description: I was surprised to find this restaurant right by a gas staion in SoMa. I wasn't sure what to expect but I was pleasantly surprised.  My friend and I had a glass of wine each and started with the burrata appetizer.  It was solid.  It was enough to whet our appetites and then we shared the risotto entree and lamb ragu one.  The lamb ragu was so much better than the risotto.  I felt the risotto was three stars, lamb ragu was four stars and the ambience was four and half stars.
author: Sarah C.

description: Great food  Service was a bit slow but very friendly
author: Jim G.

description:
I went to this restaurant with a group of 10 for my birthday dinner. It was AMAZING. 

The food was terrific. I ordered gnocchi, and each bite was a perfect potato pillow with a wonderful sauce. One of my friends said his steak was probably the best steak he has ever had. This comes from a person who eats a lot of steak and who has worked in many fine dining restaurants. Others ordered the ravioli, risotto, orecchiette, and seafood lasagna. All was delicious. 

The bread is a wonderful way to start the meal. They serve it with olive oil mixed with olives. I'm not even a fan of olives generally, and I loved it. 

The owner himself was our server and couldn't have been nicer. He took wonderful care of us and ensured we had everything we could have wanted in a timely manner. 

Overall, this is a terrific restaurant, well worth the hike from downtown. Parking was plentiful on a Saturday night, and it was an easy walk from Market St. also.
author: B J.

description:
charming little unassuming place. 

food was great, service was amazing. everyone here is so nice! 
i had the baked halibut and it was absolutely delicious. 

would definitely go again.
author: Michelle K.

description: I can't recall exactly what I ordered (it couldn't have been that great if I can't remember; maybe I ordered the wrong dish?), but there was no lasting impression on me.  So a solid 3/5 stars.
author: E b.

description: A beautiful restaurant. The dominant color of the dining room is cream, very tasteful, very warm and nice. There is a cozy bar off to one side - looks like a bit of a tight space, but I've been here twice now and there are always people there. The service is top-notch, professional and fun. Food is delicious. I'm not a crepe-head but I recommend the "fagotini" vegetable-and-cream-filled crepes here.
author: Michael E.

description:
What can I possibly say about the amazing food, impeccable service and general warm atmosphere?  This place is amazing - so amazing I often refer to it as my own kitchen, yes we eat there that often!

If you want to have dinner with a Milanese family - why travel to Milan when  Rhiannon, Luciano, Gian Luca  and Alessandro will welcome you with open arms at La Briciola.

Now for the food - we have tried most things on the menu.  Here are a few personal favorites - I promise you will not be disappointed.  
For the starter:
The seafood pot pie - (aka.Sfogliatine con gamberi e asparagi)  and the veggie crepe (aka Fagottino ripieno) are freaking phenomenal.  The burrata is also a must, must have.  

Soup: Zuppa Contadina is awesome.  Hearty veggie soup with great bread.  Enough for a light dinner but don't stop here - order pasta!

Top 3 pastas: Their pastas are freshly made and super tasty. Remember this is not Southern Italian no super heavy red sauce here!

Hard to go wrong with any choice but here are the best:
seabass ravioli - sinfully good.  Pasta is homemade fresh light and creamy. 
lamb ragu - Straccietti al ragú di agnello.  Order a great Chianti to go with this - just ask Gian Luca what he would drink.  
Tagliolini di mare is my 3rd favorite but my husband would argue for ravioli with ragu to make the best of the best list. 

Other entrees: would highly recommend the rolled swordfish - yum or the Caciucco di viareggio (absurd amount of seafood)!  Not a huge fan of the halibut (a tad dry).  We love the pasta so much we don't venture into the secondi part of the menu often!

Dessert: 
We rarely make it to dessert.  However, big fan of the vin santo with biscotti.  The biscotti is some of the best I have ever had and the vin santo is smooth and complex with a nice finish.

Go - enjoy "our kitchen".  I promise you will soon wish that the La Briciola gang was part of your family.
author: Stacy N.

description:
An absolutely charming restaurant, run by a sincerely dedicated and warm staff.  The food is delicious and unexpected.  With a Northern Italian influence, the menu offers foods from the "Earth" and the "Ocean."  It was very hard to pick from the many great offerings; but I loved the vegetable filled crepe, the pasta with sausage and broccoli rabe, and the olive tapenade that was served with the bread.  The dessert I had was strawberries with a very good vanilla gelato.  It was a lovely finish but could have used a little sauce or liquor of some kind to make it more interesting.  Great wine list.  
This is a worthy destination spot---I will go back.  Parking is easy.
author: Christine S.

description: Great food.  Great service.  Some things were a little too salty - otherwise it's one of the best places I've been to in SF.  Perfect fresh cheese, great quality produce.  We were seated right on time with our reservation - and the service was attentive throughout.
author: Bruce W.

description: Good food, wait staff never rushes you, simple, spacious and not a tourist trap like north beach.  Really nice owners.  Downside is that it is under the freeway so not great outside ambiance, but inside is great.
author: Katie A.

description:
In many ways, this place reminds me of the "Paradise" restaurant in Stanley Tucci's film, Big Night: everything felt 'right' about the place, but it was empty.   I had half a mind to peek behind the counter to see if Tony Shalhoub was cursing into my risotto, but the chef wasn't amused when I called him 'Primo'.  

The food is authentic Italian.  The  menu was elaborate and extensive, with seafood ("Ocean") and meat/poultry/vegetarian ("Earth") options.  We tried their Vitello alla Valdostana, which translates as veal-wrapped around fatty bacon (spek) and cheese (fontina) - it was similar to a chicken cordon blue, but SO much tastier.  I dubbed it cheesy veal num nums, but the chef wasn't moved to make this name change (I encourage all Yelpers to request this dish by this proper name - strength in numbers, people).  The Agnello al Brunello (i.e., rack of lamb) was cooked to perfection, and met my standard of being good enough to pick up and eat off the bone, lip smacking and finger sucking a must.  Their two steaks (T-bone and filet) were decent, though not of the same quality as the lamb or nums nums.  Their pastas (drool) tasted hand-made and fresh, especially the truffled Tagliatelle and the pecorino gnocchi (more drool).  

From the ocean, the grilled squid were cooked to perfection - just beyond al dente and short of chewy.  Only Italians manage to really nail this dish. The halibut, cooked and served in the pan, was heavenly.  At least, I assume so, because my friend (the pig that he is) inhaled it and mopped up the sauce.  Speaking of mopping up, the bread was meh - nothing special.  If they want to kick this place up a notch, they'll cover this detail and pull in some great, crisp crust Italian baguettes (or French - no one will fault them for being un-Italian in this department).

My only real complaint was that the risotto didn't taste as though it were made just prior to being served - it was not as warm as the other pasta dishes, and they went overboard on the saffron.  Curse you for cutting corners, Primo.   Given that the restaurant was empty except for our table of five, I wondered for a moment whether they'd be able to handle the demands of a full house, and I'm curious to see if my rating holds up when the kitchen is running at capacity.  

The dessert menu was sparse - profitterolles, tiramisu and flan - and I was a bit surprised not to see more options, especially considering the extensive menu.  We weren't moved to try anything, but judging from the authentic quality of the main courses, I would hope that the desserts stand up to the rest and perhaps less is more.  

The service was authentic Italian.  Our server's recommendations were helpful, his descriptions were spot on, and his hair gel was glistening.  We were waited on hand and foot, and he aimed to please, which reinforced my image of Stanley Tucci's character, 'Secondo' running the show.   The wine list was decent, and the prices were reasonable.  If it were up to me, I might recommend sizing up the options a bit and adding some small batch or hard to find Italian wines.  As it was, the list was good, but there were no exciting surprises.

The location is authentic SoMa, meaning the neighborhood isn't one you'd normally frequent were it not for this place (it's practically under the freeway).  You're not likely to loiter around outside waiting for a table, but they've got a quaint beer/wine bar to make up for the fact.  It's only a few blocks from South Park, however, so it's well worth the trek.  The interior is warm, clean, and very inviting.  I might suggest that they dim the lights a bit more as the ambiance would have been kicked up a notch.  All told, this place has the appearance of a gem, and I hope it sees a pick-up in customers.  It certainly enhances the neighborhood, and I hope the neighborhood can hold onto it.
author: Nils E.

description:
This is a a very traditional and authentic northern Italian restaurant, with a mostly italian speaking staff and a menu that reflects some of the best dishes of the region.  Being traditional, they have a menu with first (primi) and second (secondi) courses.  Thus, the portions seem to be sized to allow you to eat both courses, therefore by US standards that are on the small size.  Although not the absolute best italian food I've had, it was very solid and I would not hesitate to take an Italian colleague there.   

On to the food, I had the linguini cinque terra... redolent of pesto that is characteristic of LIguria.  Not as strong as some I've had, but both the pasta and the pesto were fresh... and the pasta perfectly al dente.   The minestrone was even better, the broth rich and the vegetables still perfect.  The dishes are not overly salty here...  

I had the swordfish, rolled and filled with shrimp, zucchini and tomato... very good.  The gnocchi were also very good.  

(And btw, to a reviewer below, crepes are found in Italy, crespelle to be exact.  Especially in Northern Italy)

I'd rate this as 4.5 stars, but put 5 to balance out the reviews.   We also ate at the bar, as it was booked on a Sunday night.   Would love to see more wine from the region available by the glass...
author: Greg K.

description:
I've been made aware of this restaurant from yelp reviews, and I'm really happy I finally had a chance to check it out! 

I went there with my friend last Sunday for dinner. We were actually quite disappointed from the Wine exhibition at the SFMOMA (really horrible...) and definitely needed a good dinner to cheer us up! Finding the place wasn't that hard, although the neighbourhood is somewhat dodgy. We got there pretty early, and the restaurant was still almost empty. The atmosphere there is really classy and elegant. We got a table in the back of the big room, which was really quiet and very enjoyable I think. 

We ordered a bottle of Sicilian red, which i have to say was nothing special. It was maybe the single minus that night. We shared an Antipasto Misto for appetizer: the Prosciutto was the best part of it, and also the Speck was good, although I'm not such a big fan. 
As for the entrées, I got the T-bone steak, which really tasted amazing, so different from what you get at American Steak Houses and Grills. My friend got the Filetto with black truffle sauce, which he also liked a lot. We also got an espresso and a very good Tiramisù, creamy and generously poured into espresso as it should be. 

A funny group of Italian people joined the same part of the room later on, and it was really funny to overhear their comments on food and wine; btw, they also did not like their (white) wine that much, which really makes me think it's better to avoid ordering wine there: you'll be amazed by the food instead!
author: france d.

description: We ate at this restaurant last night.  Yes, as another review stated, there weren't many other customers there.  In fact, we were the only ones for about 45 minutes.  That said, the food was delicious, especially the buratta.  Presentation is excellent, and each dish we had was wonderful.  We asked our server to combine the salami and artisanal cheese appetizers for the table, and it arrived attractively presented on a wooden board (which is usually how it's done elsewhere but one never knows).  Three of our party shared an excellent bottle of wine.  Our water glasses were promptly refilled.  We are visiting from NY City, and La Briciola makes the grade far as we're concerned.  Try it!
author: Anne M.

description:
Really 3.5 stars. La Briciola, I have mixed feelings about this place. 

Starting with the environment, it was cozy, clean, and comfortable. The waiters were friendly and attentive, constantly checking on us and refilling our water. Unfortunately, one of them was a bit incompetent. When he collected our bread plates after appetizers, he left some of the utensils behind. Then when he came back, he only gave some of us dinner knife and fork. I was left with a butter knife and salad fork to eat my entrée. I didn't even noticed until my friend asked why my utensils looked different from hers, but I had fish so it didn't require cutting anyway. 

Service aside, I didn't find their food to be too special. I thought that my Rombo all'isolana (baked halibut~fresh tomato sauce~olives~sliced potatoes) didn't really have much real flavor. I mean I could tell that it was fresh, quality fish. I just was expecting the sauce to have more tomato flavor but it was just salty. With a few tiny pieces of tomato sprinkled on top. The fish, which was roughly 4 ounces, was pretty much the entire dish. I was like...where are my potato slices? They were hiding under my gravy! THAT was how thin they were. In fact, most of them got stuck to the bottom of the dish from the baking process. When I read "sliced potatoes", I was really expecting something more substantial but apparently they were only for decorative purposes. Guys, you need to work on the accuracy of your menu descriptions because that totally wasn't what I was expecting.

My other friend had the Petto di pollo ai porcini (chicken breast~wild porcini mushroom sauce). She said the sauce was good, but I saw her cut the chicken and it looked really rubbery. 

To be fair, their bread was really good. They also had a large selection of wine, but I don't really drink. All the appetizers were great though. We had:
Bruschette assortite (zucchini~eggplant~fresh tomatoes~toasted bread)
Sfogliatine con gamberi e asparagi (puff pastry~asparagus~shrimp~crab reduction) This was my favorite, I should have ordered another one!
Calamari grigliati (grilled squid~arugula~chick pea pure)

And others in my group seemed to enjoy their dishes. They all ordered some type of pasta or ravioli. Hmm, note to self, only ever order pasta from Italian restaurants in the future. So if I ever decide to come back it would be for the appetizers, and I would try something else that is not fish.
author: Irene F.

description: Dad and I easily got 6:15 reservations on a Wednesday. One of the best Italian meals I've had in ages. The bread is unbelievable, the olive oil has amazing flavor -and I haven't even ordered yet. The burrata was the best I've had (and we've been trying every one) with a nice side arugala salad on the plate. I ordered the linguini with clams - good. A healthy portion without being teeny nor crazy huge. Dad had the leg of lamb - extraordinary. Our server was one of the owners who was kind and friendly. Excellent red wine and we were happy campers. We told them we had theatre tickets and they got us in and out in an hour. Note - the alley just past the restaurant has one hour parking until 10 pm. Across the street, the parking is 2 hours. Warm atmosphere, clean bathroom. Will go again with the whole family.
author: A. Y.

description: Very affordable panini and pasta on the lunch menu. I had the linguini with garlic and olive oil and it hit the spot. I suggest vegetarians get the veggie panini. It comes with salad and fries. I was jealous of my coworker's. The service was great for our party of 8 even when the rest of the place was occupied. Next time I come back I will have to try dinner. This is just what South Park needed!
author: Regina S.

description: Nice little Italian restaurant in SOMA.  We went with two friends for a Sunday dinner and were pleased.  The service was solid and the complementary bread with olive oil and sundried tomato was nice.  The linguine alle vongole, risotto al nero di seppia, and tagliatelle ai porcini e tartufo were all good.  Was hard to choose what to order, so we want to come back and try more!
author: Jordan W.

description: Chef Gian Lucca makes the best food, real Italian here.  The service is excellent, the atmosphere is relaxing and comfortable.  I have eaten here on several occasions and have never been disappointed!!!
author: Chris S.

description:
I wanted to like this restaurant, really I did. The location is convenient and parking was not a problem. My wife and I arrived on a Saturday night at about seven (with no reservation) and were seated immediately. So far so good.  Although the restaurant was only about half full, service was slow from the start. Everything took 5-10 minutes too long to come out. My mixed salad was nothing special, but was not bad. My wife liked her Caesar  Salad, but again nothing special. I had the sea bass ravioli in lobster reduction which arrived warm but not hot. The Ravioli was good but the portions were small (perhaps this is why they are so generous bread basket?)
My wife's cheese ravioli was unexceptional and not nearly as tasty as what I had ordered.  After we had finished our entrees we waited a good 10-15 minutes for our plates to be clear, despite having made eye contact with our waiter several times; I guess he just did not want to clear our plates. Alas, dessert was unexceptional as well. The desserts looked great but the cream puffs I ordered lacked any real flavor ( I immediately regretted blowing the calories.) Finally, price point was good. Dinner for two with drinks totaled about 95 dollars. I might be convinced to give this place another try, though I left unsatisfied.
author: Eric R.

description: The arugula salad I had was simple but delicious. The big disappointment was that they overcooked the tri-tip: I ordered it medium-rare, but they cooked it what I would consider well done. A very sad fate for a nice steak. Our food took a while to arrive (the atmosphere is nice so we didn't mind), but other than that the service was excellent.
author: Krishna D.

description: Fantastic food and excellent service! Very nice environment, not too loud, with the right lighting to make people comfortable. I d like the prices to be a little lower. Great place, overall!
author: Alex P.

description: great food. good service. let us hangout till after closing without too much disturbance.
author: Gaurav M.

description:
I went here for dinner on a Friday night and had a fantastic experience.  

I recently moved to SOMA and still haven't been to most of the restaurants and bars in the area.  A few of my friends were in town visiting on a Friday night and wanted to have dinner in my neighborhood, so I wanted to take them somewhere they'd be impressed by but I also wanted to try somewhere new.  I asked my next door neighbor for recommendations and he told me about La Briciola.  His exact words were (via text): "Great Italian.  Cozy atmosphere."  Sounded good to me.  

We were a group of seven and showed up around 8:30 p.m. without reservations.  The restaurant was about half full and we were seated right away by the very friendly Italian host/waiter.  This was of course immediately impressive since most places on a Friday night at that time have a long wait.  But I think the fact that the restaurant wasn't full was due only to it's location.

The server was friendly and accommodating throughout the entire meal.  He brought us menus right away, and was always available when we needed him.  We spent more time talking than looking at the menu at first, so it was a while before we even ordered drinks, but the server was patient and we were never rushed.  He also made an excellent wine recommendations (a bottle of Pino Bianco and later glasses of Pino Grigio).

The food was delicious!  We ordered the arugula salad, cheese gnocchi, linguine with clams, seabass and lobster raviolis, and risotto with calamari, scallops, and ink sauce (there were a few other dishes but these are the ones I actually tasted).  There was not a bad dish among them.  I particularly liked the seabass and lobster raviolis and the squid ink risotto.  The seafood was flavorful and well-cooked, and nothing was too salty.  The sauces were rich and creamy.  I also shared the tiramisu with a friend, which the server told us is homemade and was fluffy and tasty (I probably could have ordered my own...).  

Success!  Everyone was impressed, and I now know of a great Italian restaurant in my neighborhood.  We really got the whole package--excellent service and delicious food.  The restaurant is small and the lighting is low, so the ambiance is comfortable and relaxing (and would be perfect for a date, I saw several in progress around our table).  I will definitely go back here again whenever I get the chance.
author: Meredith H.

description: Fantastic staff and good selection of Italian wines. Supper was really lovely.
author: James S.

description:
Good service, nice decor.  Food and menu were very authentically Italian.  Food was very good, but not a knockout.

I started with the insalata del campo, which was very good indeed.  I also had the minestone, which was disappointing - a bit too much like something that came out of a can (although I'm sure it certainly did not).  Bread was good, but not great.  Nice olive spread accompaniment, though.

I followed it with the tagliatelle ai porcini e tartufo.  Very good rustic flavor, very good but not fantastic.  Accompanied it with a delicious Barbera, which is unusual to find by the glass.
author: Ritch G.

description: Excellent excellent service.  Very cozy inside.  Great for a date or dinner with friends.  Took yelper's advice and got the sea  bass ravioli - not bad.  I don't know why I didn't expect there to be cheese inside, but there was.  The truffle pasta was also quite delicious.  My favorite part of the evening was really my waiter -- so energetic, so attentive and knew his wines and food.
author: Alias A.

description: TERRIBLE!  Yelp you did us wrong!!  Don't waste your $$ or time.  Poor service and mediocre food.  Came in with seven people and waited well over an hour for our food.  The restaurant was not even full!   Pasta dishes dry, service slow.
author: Patricia R.

description:
I am torn between three and four stars. Here's my experience...we made reservations for four and then had to call ahead with a fifth when my in-laws brought their three year old grandson. The restaurant was very accomodating and helpful and adding an extra person was no problem. We shared an order of the assorted bruschetta - pretty good and a little different including a mushroom based bruschetta. I would have liked the toast to come out a little toastier though. We ordered the large assorted meats and thoroughly enjoyed them. Their minestrone was one of the better I have tried. My husband ordered the pesto which we thought was only so-so (a little stingy on the pesto sauce and they put potatoes and green beans in it which was a little weird). We've been to the Cinque Terra in Italy where this dish is popular and didn't see anything prepared like that. I ordered the gnocchi which was very good if a little on the heavy side - if you like creamy cheese sauce than you will definitely like it. We asked for a little side of meats for the little one and I think they brought it out at no charge and it kept him mostly happy through the meal. The service was definitely on the slower side - we waited a long time between our soup and our entrees (perhaps that was authentic and reminiscent of Italy!). I wouldn't dine here if you are in a hurry. The dessert was decent - an ice cream puff with chocolate. 

This restaurant was walking distance from my sister's place so I would likely go back if I am in the area but probably wouldn't make a special trip of it.
author: Shannon W.

description: The ambiance is nice and quiet, service seems pretty professional and the restaurant is tucked away in a low-key block off 3rd so much that I almost missed it when I was walking there.  I was hoping to find a hidden gem, so maybe my expectations were high.  I got the sea bass filled ravioli with a lobster reduction sauce, it was decent though I thought the lobster flavors overpowered any hint of the sea-bass itself, sad since I love sea bass.  Friend got the hand-made ravioli with lamb ragu sauce which again was just ok.  I may go back just to give it another chance, but nothing to write home about.
author: Alan P.

description: Living so close to La Briciola could be very dangerous for my wallet and waistline.  My first experience there was almost perfect...  They have a pretty good variety of pasta, seafood, and meat  dishes that I haven't seen on most Italian menus, and they all sound delectable.  We had the spinach salad, ravioli, halibut, and a complimentary antipasti platter - everything was very fresh and incredibly tasty.  And their tiramisu has three layers of espresso-soaked lady fingers, so it's more moist than others I've had.  Great service as well - we were the last ones there by a long shot and never felt rushed to leave.  I'm definitely planning to make it back there.
author: seema s.

description:
Jeez - finally an Italian place that doesn't suffer from the San Francisco-ization of Italian cuisine. No foie gras terrine with basil infused gelato and chicory route essence. No $39.00 entrees, no $20.00 appetizers, no CIA grads vying for the position of line cook or the next James Beard award. 

Just fantastic, reliable Italian cuisine with flair and creativity, yet without abandoning traditional flavors.

I was impressed by a few things here:

First, the food. I know it seems weird, but the hardest dishes to prepare are seemingly the most obvious. Stracietti with meat ragu - basically pasta with meat sauce. The flavor was OUTSTANDING. The pasta was cooked perfectly. Also had the linguine vongole - thank you!!! The best restaurants in the world mess up vongole - not La Briciola. The veggie crepe appetizer was nothing short of terrific. Desserts, wine list, etc. all right in the pocket.

Service was perfect - and from real Italian waiters who are nice and not smarmy.

Ambiance is dignified and private.

A winner...and a relatively unknown winner, at that.
author: D B.

description: A decent place on the quiet side of SOMA. It's probably more bustling during game days, but the night we went, it was not busy. It was only two of us and looking at the layout, parties larger than 6 or 8 are not easily accommodated. Food was delicious - buffalo/tomato, gnocchi, lamb ragu pasta, and tiramisu. Staff was very friendly though a little slow. In fact, I had to rearrange my own chair to get seated. Not to be overly picky, but it's not quite 4 stars. We will be back though.
author: Veggie S.

description: Just wrapped up a fabulous dinner at La Briciola.   Food was delicious, service was exemplary, and ambiance was elegant and simple (as others have already pointed out).  The Fagottino Ripieno is not to miss (don't try and pronounce it, just point ;).
author: sundeep a.

description:
I went here after reading all of the yelp reviews.  I think this was one of the first times that yelp has failed me.

I went here for dinner on a Friday night.  The place was pretty empty but I still decided to give it a go.  The service was slow the whole time.  Not sure why because the place was pretty quiet.  The food was fairly average.  Nothing stood out, except that they serve the same side of veggies (boiled to oblivion) and potatoes for all 20 of there "earth" dishes.  Some thought should go into what would be the best side for a particular meal.  I had the lamb chops and they were very unevenly cooked.   Mama's cooking is good unless it ends up being bland and overcooked.

I think what they really need to do is cut their menu in half or even more and focus on making those dishes exceptional.  Focus on quality not quantity.
author: Brian S.

description: Great Italian restaurant. Food delicious and excellent service.
author: Dina L.

description: Absolutely fantastic restaurant! Their service is impeccable. I went with a group of 7 people. We started off with the artisan cheese spread. This was rather scarce but still very yummy. We also order an assortment of cured meats that came with olives and bread sticks. They kept replenishing the fresh warm bread because we kept eating it so quickly. To accompany the bread was olive oil with some ground olives swimming at the bottom. For dinner I had some assorted seafood with pasta with a white wine reduction. A couple of the mussels/ clams were lacking in the meat department. A very good meal. I would definitely come back.
author: Kelvin L.

description:
Amazing food, wine, and service. It's my favorite Italian place in the city.
The homemade burrata appetizer was absolutely delicious and fresh and you really get the feeling that the staff is there to make the customers happy.
author: Ana S.

description: Excellent. We found this place on the web and were delighted with the food, service, and wine. Nothing short of excellent!
author: L L.

description:
Loved the service and staff and the food was sublime. Had the seafood risotto and it was great. Lamb ragu was also v good and just enjoyed the service and relaxed atmosphere. 

Try it out for sure and see what you think, but i'll be back there for sure!!!
author: S G.

description: Really good food.  Attentive staff.  Nice atmosphere.  Waiters always smiled when they helped us but weren't overbearing.  It was a first date and made it nice to be able to just talk with the other person.
author: Tyler D.

description: Salad (Insalata del campo), appetizers (Carpaccio di manzo, Frittura di calamari, and Sfogliatine con gamberi e asparagi) and main courses  were all amazing!
author: Ryan C.

description: Authentic Italians serving authentic Italian cuisine. Crepe appetizers and eggplant bruchetta were excellent. Reasonable and varied wine list, friendly service equals an outstanding new addtion to the italian restaurant landscape.
author: Logan C.

description: Came here with my boyfriend and had a very good dinner experience. Intimate vibe and great service. They have really really tasty pasta dishes. It's a little hidden gem in an otherwise bleak neighborhood under the freeway.
author: Janie Y.

description: Showed up around 8:45pm on a Saturday evening as a party of 3.  The place was packed, but within 10 minutes they had a nice table for us.  We all enjoyed lovely meals.  I started w/ the pomodoro e mozzarella, good but not great.  I wish the tomatoes had been a little tastier.  My mom had the  puff pastry roll with asparagus and shrimp and a crab reduction.  This was fabulous, possibly the best dish of the evening.  The last app. was the arugula, tomato and shaved parm salad.  The other guest seemed happy.  The entrees were rack of lamb, perfectly cooked and delicious, the lamb ragu of fresh cut pasta.  I liked it, but I was expecting shredded lamb not ground lamb, so it wasn't exactly what I wanted.  The past was great.  The last dish was the chicken breast w/ porchini mushroom sauce.  That was very nice.
author: Heather S.

description: My cousin, who is in the wine distribution business and knows every single Italian restaurant in the city, took us here before a Giants game. It was incredible, from the way we were greeted to the food and hospitality. We ate one of the best dinners ever, and enjoyed an authentic Italian atmosphere. I used to live in Florence, and this is definitely an authentic Italian - from the menu to the atmosphere to the Italian speaking owner and servers. You would never know from the outside what a charming restaurant this is, but I urge you to go in! You will enjoy a delicious dinner without the feeling of being rushed - another authentic Italian restaurant quality! Cin cin! Salute!
author: Kathryn P.

description: Took my girlfriend here for our anniversary. Food was very good and the service was second to none. The outside of the restaurant wasn't very nice, but the inside made up for it. It was romantic and peaceful. Tons of candles lit everywhere which made it relaxing. Parking is the only downside. I had to pay $10 for parking a block away. Other than that I would recommend this place to anyone who likes really good Italian food! They also put their check in something really fun. I won't post it here because I don't want to spoil it for any new customers!
author: Ryan V.

description: Plus two more stars!! This place is awesome!!!!!  The food is great, the staff is great, everything is great!! Good job guys/gals!
author: Sonia G.

description: the pasta is very good here, and service for take-out is really excellent.  easy parking on weeknights, especially late.
author: eshwar k.

description: Great food every time.  We are big fans of the lamb ragu and octopus dishes - but they all have great strong flavors that play well together in every dish.
author: Joris P.

description: These guys are the real deal: charming, inviting, hospitable. Great wine list. Nice range of Northern Italian dishes. And most importantly, do NOT miss the house-made pasta with sausage and broccoli. One of the best Italian dishes I've ever had anywhere.
author: Abie H.

description: We ate here opening night on May 8th, 2009 as we live directly across the street and have been watching the last few weeks as they transformed the space into a beautiful restaurant! To start off the meal they provided nice italian bread to dip in olive oil with minced olives. For an appetizer, we split crepes in truffle oil which was to die for! So good and so unique. I followed that up with pasta in pesto sauce which had vegetables mixed in, that  was also delicious. I'm excited to have a restaurant of this caliber in this neighborhood! Really nice staff too, they mentioned they will be opening for lunch and on weekends, including Sunday. I will be going back.
author: Rajiv D.

description:
Very cozy, hole in the wall restaurant that could come right out of Manhattan.  The inside is great for either a business lunch, casual dinner with friends, or a romantic dinner.

The menu offers something for everyone and the wine is reasonably priced.  We shall return.
author: Rick H.

description:
I discovered la briciola almost by accident, My girlfriend and I live in the neighborhood and on the way to the ball park we noticed this new italian restaurant. We checked the menu and decided to give it a try. What a great surprise! The food was incredible, my girlfriend had salmon in a saffron sauce and it was to die for. My pasta was great too, homemade with lamb meat sauce.
The inside of la briciola is very romantic and it invites you to stay long time and relax enjoying delicious food and great italian wine.
The staff is very sweet and friendly too, making you feel at home.
My girlfriend and I are so excited we live only 3 blocks away, can't wait to visit soon again.
You guys rock!!!
author: Jae N.

description:
At last a quiet place with great real italian food that won't break the bank.
This place has been a number of restaurants over the years while I have
lived around the corner.  I wasn't sure this was going to do any better
than the last few attempts, but to my surprise, it's really wonderful.
We go out to dinner often and usually to the better places around town,
but always wished we had a local hangout to just dive into without 
worrying about those "weeks in advance reservations.  The portions
are large, including the salads.  I don't usually write reviews but this  place was worth the trouble.
author: John C.

description:
We live across the street from this restaurant, and I have been excited about trying ever since someone started painting over the graffiti and redoing the space!

My bf and I went here for dinner last night, and I thought it was delicious. The space is beautiful inside, with sunny yellow paint and dark wood accents. The staff is lovely and helpful, and the owner and his wife are super friendly and knowledgeable.

We split a Caesar salad (big enough for 2!), I ordered a Sea Bass ravioli in a lobster reduction, and it was superb. Very fresh-tasting, with yummy chunks of lobster in the cream sauce! Lots of fresh herbs, too. 

My bf ordered "vitello a valdostana",  rolled veal with fontina cheese. He was happy with it, and it came with Yukon potatoes and fresh vegetables. 
For dessert we split the "affogato al cafe" which was vanilla gelato with espresso over it, very tasty!!

We also had a great bottle of Chardonnay; and found the wine list to have lots of choices. Most are full bottles, though, only a few to order by the glass.

We'll definitely be back, they told us that they do brunch on Sundays, and we're always looking for new brunch options in SoMa.
author: Kelly C.

description: The food was good, the service was friendly, and they were able to accommodate a large group.  However, I ordered the gnocchi and, while it was very tasty, the portion was small for the price.  Maybe it wasn't that it was small, it was just sort of, well, boring.  It was a bowl of gnocchi in a forgettable pesto sauce and nothing else--no vegetables, no meat, no garnish. The atmosphere is cute (good for dates), but fill up on the free bread because the meal might not satisfy.  Maybe if I had spent more money I would have enjoyed my meal more?
author: Britany F.

description:
A hidden gem in an unexpected location.

It is clear that the owner and/or chef takes a lot of pride in what's coming from the kitchen.

Service was warm and attentive without being intrusive.  Ambiance is cozy and clean (check out their 100 on their health score).

Food was impeccable and flavorful.

Make sure you try the vegetable crepe appetizer (even if you are not a crepe type of guy/girl).  Pastas are made in-house and are nicely balanced and portioned.

We will definitely be back!
author: Randi S.

description: I took my wife here for our 11th year anniversary, and it was worth it. T-Bone Steak was perfectly prepared and the chicken had a delightful flavor as well. Service was cordial and non-invasive. Try the Strawberries with gelato! YUM! Atmosphere was good, although the music was REALLY cheesy (in a bad way). The fried veggies with marinara was delightfully light and delicious. Check it out. Good stuff.
author: André C.

description: The food was really pretty good, probably a 4.5 stars. But, this is the sort of restaurant that is trying for good, full- service, but it failed. Our server was beyond rude and would roll his eyes at us the whole time. Then, a big group came in--it sounded like we were in chuck-e-cheese. Averaging the service and food, I'm being nice with a 3 overall. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.
author: Diantha L.

description: Very good Italian food in the traditional style. Service was outstanding. Not a $$ rating though for price - this place is expensive, make no mistake about that. But if you the bucks and want good Italian cuisine just a few block from AT&T Park this one is worth a try.
author: Steve W.

description: Very pleasant environmment to have an italian meal with friends. Prices are reasonable and I have no problems with service. The only reason why I give it 4 stars is the ravioli I had was not the best I ever had but still very good. I also had the seared tuna entree, wine, and salmon appetizer which I liked alot. Close to transportation, about half way between Bart and Caltrain and would dine again at La Briciola.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Skip the bread they serve before the meal--it's not worth filling up on.

However, do try the risotto alla monferrina! It's flavorful, and the rice is cooked to perfection.
author: Nefaur K.

description: I've eaten here since they opened last year.  The owners are very friendly and accomodating.  The decor is warm and inviting.  The food is tasty and authentic Italian (southern, I think.) I would definitely recommend for groups or an intimate dinner for 2.
author: Remi P.

description:
This restaurant is one of the many gems of the San Francisco food scene, where one can get a delicious, contemporary Italian meal, with a better quality of food and service than one could find in North Beach.

The food was very good - we had three appetizers and two entree's, all of which were delicious, wonderfully prepared, and beautifully presented. I recommend the vegetable crepes.

The atmosphere was great - not to formal, but not too casual. We were able to joke around with the host, and feel comfortable and welcomed in his restaurant. The waiters were attentive, but not overbearing.

Over all, the combination of the food and atmosphere is well worth the price. La Briciola is one of the best Italian restaurants in San Francisco. We've been there three times, and three times we've had a great experience, and wish to recommend it to you as well.
author: Minoru M.

description: My brother took me here to celebrate a promotion. The wine list was comprehensive, the food was extremely well prepared, and the service was impeccable. Definitely try the tiramisu, it was some of the best I've ever had.
author: Dave B.

description: Squisito! You can find good Italian food in many places in SF- this is definitely a gem! Don't be fooled by the outside or location; once you enter, you are in for a treat. Treated like honored guests- i was early and offered a beverage at the bar. Upon being seated, we were unsure of the appetizers and they made a 'misto' for us that was delicious & varied. the involtino' was delicate, with a tomato sauce that was tasty but didn't overpower the swordfish. My companions raved over the halibut, gnocchi & filet, which cut like butter. The wine list is extensive, and we had a wonderful barbera.  Though the place filled quickly, we were never rushed & felt like welcome friends at a dinner party.  Don't miss it!
author: kate b.

description: The food is always amazing, the service more than friendly,  the atmosphere warm and inviting.
author: Celeste S.

description: Come on people, this one of the best Italian restaurants in SF. Very authentic, very detailed presentation with robust taste and aroma. If you got the money and a obsession for a great experience go!
author: christopher c.

description: I wanted to stay and order my entrees again they were so good!  The halibut was flaky and mouth-watering.  The tagliatelle with mushrooms and truffle oil melted in my mouth.  So glad my friend and I shared.  Service was attentive.  Can't wait to go back and try their other entrees.
author: Phyllis B.

description:
My wife and I dined here last week while in town for the Fancy Food Show.  
1.  Very nice, cozy but not too small neighborhood restaurant in industrial area.  Took cab from convention center hotel, about $6.00
2.  Greeted quickly and seated near window, nice atmosphere. early diners (5PM)
3. Little slow on wine service
4.  Great bread, freshly made.
5. Wonderful Italian sausage soup, just the right portion.
6. Appitizer was a vegetable pot-pie and was delicious!  Really different, we shared and had plenty.
7.  Wife had the seafood plate.  Swordfish was to die for but the shrimp while tasty, were cooked with the shells on and had to be eaten by hand.  Too messy for fine dining.
8.  Gnochhi with pesto sauce was good, nothing really special
9.  I only drank half my glass of wine and ordered a different one next round.  I commented to waiter I didn't care for it but he didn't ask why.  My guess (and I know wine) is the bottle had been left open for two or more days...wine had that medicine taste which indicates it's heading south.
10.  Great panacota dessert!
Overall, good restaurant, service was good but not over-the-top by any means.  It started out as a slow dining night but several large parties came in later.  Considering how slow it was, I would have expected the owner or chef to make the rounds but never did.  Would I go back?  No but only because in SFO you have so many choices.  Would I recommend it?  Sure, it's good but not great.
author: Gold S.

description: I stumbled upon this place as its on my walk back and fro to work. It looked like a cute little gem of a spot and as my bf and I are absolute lovers of Italian food we decided we should check it out. The owner (I'm guessing)/ manager was such a nice gentleman and checked to make sure that we were well taken care of throughout the night. As for food, I say stick to the pasta dishes. I had the sea bass ravioli and it was pretty darn sweet. My bf had the lamb and it was not all that great. It tasted pretty tough and a bit dry. Cute, cute ambiance. Definitely worth checking out if your in the area but to come completely out of your way to try? Eh, I don't know if I would have taken a $10 cab ride for it!!
author: Andrea Y.

description: We really liked this place. Quaint and romantic, friendly staff, great service, good food, easy parking close by. Would definitely go back!!!!
author: Joe T.

description: Great neighborhood restaurant.  Very friendly and attentive service.  Prices were very reasonable, and portions just right.  I ordered the lamb ragu - I generally don't like lamb, but the waitor recommended it - was not disappointed!  Everyone at the table ordered a different item - all were happy with their meal.
author: Julie P.

description: Currently one of our favorite Italian places in the city.  It's a cozy place, a bit small but the food and service is good.  Our faves:  porcini~black truffles, the  filet mignon with fontina cheese and  truffles, the hand cut pasta~lamb ragú. One of the best tiramasu I've had.  The vin they offer is good.    Good food at a reasonable price.
author: David M.

description:
My husband and I ate here on accident the other night, but were pleasantly surprised by what we found. The atmosphere inside La Bricola is intimate, but not too date night-ish. We had the calamari which was pretty good, the spinach salad with walnuts was yummy too, but the arugula salad was by far the best of the appetizers/salads that we tried.

The pasta with mushrooms was also amazing and the rolled veal was very good.

We definitely plan on making a return visit and love that SOMA has another great restaurant for us to enjoy.
author: K L.

description: Given all of the positive ratings on Yelp, I decided to try this place to celebrate something job-related with my husband. We are brand spankin new to SF and hail from Toronto via Seattle and Boston so right now Yelp is our only restaurant resource until I get a better feel of the city. I gotta say...meh. It wasn't bad or anything, but it wasn't great either. I had the lamb ragu. It was good but I could recapitulate it at home. Same with my husband's sausage risotto and our profiterole / tiramisu dessert. I think we will explore other Italian options in the city outside of SOMA.
author: Sheena S.

description: Just finished dinner here. Met the co-owners who both work the dinning area and provide a great atmosphere and meal. Very authentic. Even as tourist we felt like a local. I highly recommend this place.
author: Nathan B.

description:
A South of Market recommendation from a wonderful friend, Briciola has a wonderfully bright, yet cozy atmosphere. Candles, white tablecloths and white cloth napkins calmed me instantly. This weeknight was not extremely busy, but there were a few other tables filled with diners. That is a better sign that the empties Laine and I have experienced at times in the past. Upon my friend's suggestion, we let the waiter know who had sent us and this was followed by delivery of Tagliere di Salumi, coppa spek prosciutto, salami, olives and marinated vegetables. Full of flavor and a nice way to begin the meal, we were very appreciative of the gesture. As I am steering away from meat, I concentrated on the marinated vegetables and olivees and they were phenomenal. The fresh bread and olive oil also met my expectations for fine Italian dining. Bread is a good meter by which to judge a restaurant. The menu has a lot of options, many pastas such as, ravioli, gnocci, linguine and many more with wonderful sounding variations such as pesto, string beans and potatoes or sausage and broccoli rabe. I was having a very hard time deciding, but after pondering and asking Alessandro's opinion (our friendly, very pleasant waiter), I ordered the Ravioli di Cernia, seabass filled ravioli with a lobster reduction. Upon its arrival, it also had baby prawns in the lobster reduction. Can you say oh my! Honestly, this was one of the most interesting pasta dishes I have ever consumed and what taste. Very different and all of the flavors complimented each other like nothing I could have imagined. The portion was generous and I was happy as a clam. Maryland ordered the Agnello al Brunello, the rack of lamb, green peppercorn and Brunello red wine eduction. Her plate was completely filled with succulent-looking meat and vegetables. She was excited and very pleased with her selection as well. Because we love dessert, we had to end with something dolce and the Profitterolles alla vanilla, pastry puffs with vanilla ice cream and chocolate had our name written all over them. This is such a wonderfully
presented and fun dessert and Briciola did not disappoint. We were fully satisfied and so glad my friend had given us this wonderful suggestions. Prices are reasonable for fine dining and Briciola specializes in Tuscan and Piedmontese cuisine. I will definitely visit Briciola again.

~Alex
author: See T.

description:
Nothing new to add from the other posts.  The fagottini was a delicious appetizer.   I liked my main course which was a seared tuna.   The group of 8 I was with very much enjoyed their meals, and even my picky 6 year old asked us to box the linguini bolognese that they custom made for him.    The server was kind enough to cake on the grated cheese upon his repeated requests.

Very kind staff and for me the atmosphere is what I like which is not pretentious and nice, soft lighting.
author: Bryan T.

description:
My wife and I went to La Briciola on a Tuesday night.  We didn't expect anyone else to be there on a rainy weekday night but after a while it started to fill up.  We realized that is was due to the excellent service and food.

The host knows his regular clients by name and chats with them about recent travel and holiday plans.  The waiters are professional and serve without being noticed.  The music is true Italian, at just the right volume.  But without question, the best feature is the food.

We had the Ravioli di magro spinach and ricotta filled ravioli~veal ragú $15 and the Petto di pollo ai porcini chicken breast~wild porcini mushroom sauce $17, along with Spinacina spinach~honey caramelized walnuts~goat cheese $9 and Insalata della casa mixed greens~vinaigrette dressing $7 salads.  There were several other combinations we wanted to try, so we will be returning.     

The only reason to give this restaurant less than 5 stars is the location, not a place you would normally go to.  They should move this restaurant somewhere in a neighborhood, perhaps Fisherman's Wharf or North Beach; if they did, they would double their business.
author: Jerry G.
